revision.comment: Small grammar improvements, plus reconciled inconsistencies between US and UK English
revision.text:
[[Image:FritzYngvarMoen tombstone.jpg|thumb|right|250px|Fritz Moen's tombstone, surrounded by [[John Christian Elden]] (defender during reopening of the case) and [[Tore Sandberg]] (private investigator)]] '''Fritz Yngvar Moen''' (17 December 1941 – 28 March 2005) was a [[Norwegian people|Norwegian]] man [[Miscarriage of justice|wrongfully convicted]] of two distinct [[felony murder]]s, serving a total of 18 years in prison. After the convictions were quashed, an official inquiry was instigated to establish what had gone wrong in the authorities' handling of the case, and on 25 June 2007 the commission delivered harsh criticism to the [[Norwegian Police Service|police]], the prosecution and the [[Courts of Justice of Norway|courts]] in what was immediately termed Norway's worst [[miscarriage of justice]] of all time.
Moen was deaf and had a severe speech impediment. He was also partially paralysed, but had normal intelligence and good memory.
== Initial conviction and sentencing ==
Moen was convicted for two separate rapes and murders, both in [[Trondheim]]: * Torunn Finstad, who was reported missing on 4 October 1977 and found dead two days later, having been raped and strangled. Moen was indicted by a [[Frostating]] court for the crime on 11 April 1978. He was convicted and sentenced to 20 years' imprisonment on 29 May the same year. This sentence was reduced to 16 years on appeal. * Sigrid Heggheim, who was found dead in September 1976. She had been strangled and an attempt had been made to rape her. The same court indicted Moen for murder and attempted rape on 15 September 1981, and on 19 December he was convicted and sentenced to an additional 5 years. An appeal was rejected.
The prosecuting authorities relied on Moen's confession to the murders, which appears to have been coerced by way of intimidation.
Biological samples were collected at both crime scenes and tested with technology available at the time, but the samples were then lost and destroyed for reasons that remain unclear.
When Moen was convicted, his defence lawyer, Olav Hestenes, announced: "For the first time at this desk, I allow myself to say that a travesty of justice has been committed."
The judge, Karl Solberg, reacted furiously and later applauded the court's verdict. Solberg has become notorious for miscarriages of justice, having also been instrumental in the wrongful conviction of Atle Hage, a father who was convicted of incest, took his own life after his release from prison, and was cleared ten years later when his children testified on his behalf.<ref>http://www.forejustice.org/db/Hage--Atle.html</ref>
== Convictions quashed ==
Moen's lawyer requested a new trial for both cases on 2 January 2000. The court accepted the request for the Sigrid Heggheim case, and on 7 October 2004 judge [[Wenche Skjæggestad]] announced that the court had quashed the conviction and acquitted Moen for the rape and attempted murder of Sigrid Heggheim. The court found that the forensic evidence exonerated Moen, and that in any case reasonable doubt should have acquitted him in the first place. Among other things, he had an alibi for the most likely time of the crime. Also, the forensic evidence indicated that the perpetrator had pursued the victim across a field, knocked her down, and then tied her with her own clothes — Moen was partly paralysed and physically incapable of these actions.
The court rejected the appeal against Moen's conviction in the Torunn Finstad case, and on 13 October 2005, the Norwegian Criminal Cases Review Commission received a preliminary application to review the case. When Moen died on 28 March 2005 of natural causes, it became known that he wanted the case on his behalf to continue.
In December 2005, it became known that Tor Hepsø, a convicted criminal with a long history of violence, had made a [[deathbed confession]] to killing both Sigrid Heggheim and Torunn Finstad. On 15 June 2006, the Criminal Cases Review Commission formally accepted the application, and on 24 August 2006, the Frostating court posthumously acquitted Fritz Moen for the rape and murder of Sigrid Heggheim. It found that the preponderance of evidence made Hepsø a more likely suspect, and that Moen's confession was likely coerced and only included information that had been made public. These two acquittals are widely attributed to the work of Moen's defence lawyer [[John Christian Elden]] and private investigator [[Tore Sandberg]].
In the aftermath of the acquittals, Fritz Moen's lawyers filed a civil suit against the Norwegian government seeking 28 million NOK (€3 million). The case was settled in April 2008 when the presiding judge awarded 20 million NOK.<ref>{{cite web|title=Forlik om Fritz Moen-erstatning|url=http://www.adressa.no/nyheter/trondheim/article1066854.ece|accessdate=3 May 2017}}</ref>
The case caused widespread public debate in Norway. There were calls for a formal inquiry into the conduct of the prosecutors and police, and in 2008 the newspaper [[Aftenposten]] proposed erecting a bust or statue of Moen in front of the [[Norwegian Ministry of Justice and the Police|Norwegian Ministry of Justice]] as a symbol of the responsibilities of the criminal justice system, although there so far has been no sign of this being taken seriously.<ref>{{cite news|title=Moen-byste foran Justisdepartementet|url=https://www.nrk.no/arkiv/artikkel/humor/moen-byste-foran-justisdepartementet-1.3186958|accessdate=3 May 2017}}</ref>
== Inquiry ==
On 25 June 2007 a commission headed by Henry John Mæland, professor of law at the [[University of Bergen]], delivered its findings to the Norwegian Minister of Justice [[Knut Storberget]]. The commission stated that the [[Right to a fair trial|principle of objectivity]] was violated repeatedly by both the [[Norwegian Police Service|police]] and the [[Courts of Justice of Norway|courts]]. It also found that the most important lesson that could be learned from this case was that the [[presumption of innocence]] must be upheld by both the public prosecutors and the courts.<ref>{{cite news |authorlink=Norwegian News Agency |author=Norwegian News Agency |title= Krass kritikk i Fritz Moen-saken |url=http://news.no.msn.com/domestic/Article.aspx?cp-documentid=5345945 |date=25 June 2007 |accessdate=25 June 2007 |language= Norwegian }}</ref> Mæland stated that witnesses had been coaxed by the Trondheim police force, while at the same time significant evidence proving Moen's innocence had been withheld from the defence and the courts. "Some of the evidence has basically been hidden within the police reports," Mæland concluded. The justice minister commented during the press conference that "the commission's report shows that grave errors have been committed leading to grave results."<ref>{{cite news |first=Børre O. |last=Haugli |author2=Ida Johansson |title=Politiet slaktes |url=http://www.nettavisen.no/innenriks/article1150816.ece |work=[[Nettavisen]] |publisher=[[TV 2 (Norway)|TV 2]] |date=25 June 2007 |accessdate=25 June 2007 |language= Norwegian }}</ref>
The commission was appointed on 8 September 2006 by the [[Council of State (Norway)|Norwegian cabinet]]. Besides Professor Mæland, it consisted of judge Inger Marie Dons Jensen and psychiatrist Ingrid Lycke Ellingsen. Its mandate was to "find out why Moen was wrongfully convicted and evaluate whether changes are needed in the criminal justice system to avoid wrongful convictions in the future".
A book called ''Overgrepet'' (Infringement)'','' by Tore Sandberg, the private investigator involved in Moen's case, was published in October 2007. The book names police officers and other public servants instrumental in Moen's prosecution.
On 5 February 2008, the [[Storting|Norwegian Parliament's]] Standing Committee on Scrutiny and Constitutional Affairs recommended that a commission be appointed to investigate and, if warranted, prosecute for the [[Impeachment (Norway)|impeachment]] of three of the [[Supreme Court of Norway|Norwegian Supreme Court]] justices who presided over the Moen cases. The three were [[Magnus Matningsdal]], [[Karin Maria Bruzelius]] and [[Eilert Stang Lund]].<ref>{{cite news|first=Robert |last=Gjerde |title=Stortinget må vurdere riksrett |url=http://www.aftenposten.no/nyheter/iriks/article2238528.ece |work=[[Aftenposten]] |date=5 February 2008 |accessdate=5 February 2008 |language=Norwegian |deadurl=yes |archiveurl=https://web.archive.org/web/20080208113153/http://www.aftenposten.no/nyheter/iriks/article2238528.ece |archivedate=8 February 2008 |df= }}</ref> However, when the case went to the Standing Committee on Justice, it was closed.<ref>{{cite news |first=Else Gro |last=Ommundsen |title=Høyesterettsdommere stilles ikke for riksrett |url=http://www.dagsavisen.no/innenriks/article348162.ece |work=[[Dagsavisen]] |date=8 May 2008 |accessdate=12 October 2008 |language=Norwegian |deadurl=yes |archiveurl=https://web.archive.org/web/20080822053950/http://www.dagsavisen.no/innenriks/article348162.ece |archivedate=22 August 2008 |df= }}</ref>
''[[Justice Denied|Justice:Denied]]'', the only wrongful conviction magazine in the United States, published an article about Fritz Moen's case in its Spring 2008 issue: [http://justicedenied.org/issue/issue_40/moen_i-40.pdf "Exonerated Of Two Murders, Fritz Moen Posthumously Awarded $4 Million"].
The conclusion of the inquiry recommended there be no investigation to label responsibility to individual police or judicial officers since "such action would probably lead to the pulverisation of responsibility".
== Footnotes == <references />
== External links == * [http://www.gjenopptakelse.no/index.php?id=48 Norwegian Criminal Cases Review Board decision about Moen's case (Norwegian)] * [http://justicedenied.org/cases/moen_v_public,nccrc_decision_06-15-2006.pdf Norwegian Criminal Cases Review Board decision about Moen's case (English)] * [http://justicedenied.org/issue/issue_40/moen_i-40.pdf Exonerated Of Two Murders, Fritz Moen Posthumously Awarded $4 Million, ''Justice:Denied - the magazine for the wrongly convicted'', Issue 40 (Spring 2008)]
{{Authority control}}
{{DEFAULTSORT:Moen, Fritz}} [[Category:Overturned convictions]] [[Category:Norwegian prisoners and detainees]] [[Category:1941 births]] [[Category:2005 deaths]] [[Category:Norwegian victims of human rights abuses]] [[Category:Norwegian people convicted of murder]] [[Category:People convicted of murder by Norway]] [[Category:People wrongfully convicted of murder]]

{{Infobox person | honorific_prefix = | name = Gaston Glock | honorific_suffix = | image = | image_size = | alt = | caption = | birth_name = | birth_date = {{Birth date and age|1929|7|19|df=y}} | birth_place = [[Vienna, Austria]] | death_date = | death_place = | residence = | nationality = [[Austria]]n | other_names = | ethnicity = | citizenship = | education = | alma_mater = | occupation = {{Hlist|[[Engineer]]|[[Business executive]]}} | known_for = Founder of [[Glock Ges.m.b.H.]] | title = [[Managing director]] of Glock | notable_works = | influences = | influenced = | religion = | spouse = {{marriage|Helga Glock|1958|2011|reason=divorced}}
{{marriage|Kathrin Glock|2011}} | partner = | children = Brigitte Glock
Gaston Glock, Jr
Robert Glock | parents = | relatives = }} '''Gaston Glock''' (born 19 July 1929) is an [[Austria]]n [[engineer]], and founder of the firearms company [[Glock Ges.m.b.H.|Glock]]. A book about Gaston Glock's life and his company, titled ''[[Glock: The Rise of America's Gun]]'', was published in 2012. ==Manufacturing== Glock began as a manufacturer of curtain rods and knives for the Austrian military. He had not designed or manufactured a firearm until he was 52 years old. He was already an expert in polymers as a result of his previous business ventures. In 1980 he bought an injection-moulding machine to manufacture handles and sheaths for the [[Glock knife|field knives]] he was making for the Austrian army in his garage workshop. His earliest employees were from the camera industry and were experts in producing polymer components. His first pistol took one year to produce from the design and concept stage to production, and he applied for an Austrian patent in April 1981 for the pistol known as the [[Glock|Glock 17]].{{cite book|last=Barrett|first=Paul M.|title=Glock: The Rise of America's Gun|url=https://books.google.com/books?id=sPNAkiAnm7cC|year=2013|publisher=Broadway Books|isbn=978-0-307-71995-9}} ==Personal life== Glock married Helga Glock in 1958, and they co-founded the family business in 1963.{{cite web|url=https://www.theguardian.com/world/shortcuts/2014/oct/13/guns-money-misery-gaston-glock-lawsuit|title=Guns, money and misery: billionaire Gaston Glock’s ex-wife sues for $500m|first=Mark|last=Hooper|date=13 October 2014|publisher=|via=The Guardian}} They divorced in 2011 and have been in litigation since.{{cite web|url=https://www.bloomberg.com/news/articles/2017-03-30/glock-defeats-ex-wife-s-500-million-shotgun-racketeering-suit|title=Glock Defeats Ex-Wife’s $500 Million ‘Shotgun’ Racketeering Suit|date=30 March 2017|publisher=|via=www.bloomberg.com}} Glock supports different charities in Austria, having donated over one million euros.{{cite web|url=http://www.ghpc.at/de/charity|title=Charity donations as documented by the Glock-organization GHPC|publisher=|deadurl=yes|archiveurl=https://web.archive.org/web/20121018101929/http://www.ghpc.at/de/charity|archivedate=2012-10-18|df=}}{{Cite news | title = Glück für Glock | newspaper = [[Kleine Zeitung]] | date = 29 July 2011 | url = http://www.kleinezeitung.at/kaernten/villachland/velden_am_woerther_see/2796737/glueck-fuer-glock.story | accessdate = 19 September 2011 | deadurl = yes | archiveurl = https://web.archive.org/web/20110925113658/http://www.kleinezeitung.at/kaernten/villachland/velden_am_woerther_see/2796737/glueck-fuer-glock.story | archivedate = 25 September 2011 | df = }}{{Cite news| title=Doppelte Hilfe für die Flutopfer| url=http://www.kleinezeitung.at/kaernten/wolfsberg/3160366/doppelte-hilfe-fuer-flutopfer.story| accessdate=7 January 2013| newspaper=[[Kleine Zeitung]]| date=7 November 2011| deadurl=yes| archiveurl=https://web.archive.org/web/20130203212549/http://www.kleinezeitung.at/kaernten/wolfsberg/3160366/doppelte-hilfe-fuer-flutopfer.story| archivedate=3 February 2013| df=}} ==Murder attempt== In July 1999, Glock's tax advisor Charles Ewert hired a French mercenary to murder Glock with a hammer in a car park in an apparent attempt to cover up embezzlement of millions from the Glock company.{{cite web|url=https://www.independent.co.uk/news/business/comment/jim-armitage-dont-mess-with-gaston-hes-still-got-his-hand-on-the-glock-8706719.html|title=Jim Armitage: Don't mess with Gaston – he's still got his hand on|date=13 July 2013|publisher=''The Independent''}} Although Glock's injuries included seven head wounds and the loss of about a litre of blood, Glock was able to fend off the attack by striking the hitman twice. The hired killer, 67-year-old Jacques Pêcheur, was sentenced to 17 years in prison for the attack. Charles Ewert was sentenced to 20 years as a result of Pêcheur's testimony.{{Cite news | last = Machan | first = Dyan | title = Top Gun | newspaper = [[Forbes]] | date = 31 March 2003 | url = https://www.forbes.com/global/2003/0331/020.html | accessdate = 19 September 2011}} == References == {{reflist}} {{DEFAULTSORT:Glock, Gaston}} [[Category:Firearm designers]] [[Category:People from Gänserndorf District]] [[Category:1929 births]] [[Category:Living people]]

page.title: George W. Bush military service controversy

revision.comment: branch of service has a specfic meaning. it can only be army, navy, air force, marines, or coast guard. air national guard falls under the us air force
revision.text:
{{Infobox military person |name = George Walker Bush |image = GW-Bush-in-uniform.jpg |caption = 1st Lt. George W. Bush in uniform |branch = [[United States Air Force]] (Air National Guard) |serviceyears = 1968–1974 |rank = [[File:US-O2 insignia.svg|8px]] [[First Lieutenant]] |unit = [[147th Reconnaissance Wing]]
[[187th Fighter Wing]] }} '''Controversy over [[George W. Bush]]'s military service''' in the [[Air National Guard of the United States|Air National Guard]] was an issue that first gained widespread public attention during the [[2004 U.S. presidential campaign|2004 presidential campaign]]. The controversy centered on [[Texas Air National Guard]], why he lost his flight status, and whether he fulfilled the requirements of his military service contract. ==Timeline== George W. Bush joined the [[147th Fighter Interceptor Group]] of the [[Texas Air National Guard]] on May 27, 1968, during the [[Vietnam War]]. He committed to serve until May 26, 1974, with two years on active duty while training to fly and four years on part-time duty.Lardner, George Jr. and Lois Romano. "[https://www.washingtonpost.com/wp-srv/politics/campaigns/wh2000/stories/bush072899.htm At Height of Vietnam, Bush Picks Guard]" ''[[Washington Post]]'', July 28, 1999. In his 1968 Statement of Intent (undated), he wrote, "I have applied for pilot training with the goal of making flying a lifetime pursuit and I believe I can best accomplish this to my own satisfaction by serving as a member of the Air National Guard as long as possible." Following his six weeks of basic training, Bush began 54 weeks of flight training at [[Moody Air Force Base]], [[Georgia (U.S. state)|Georgia]].{{cite web |url=http://www.nationalreview.com/york/york200402180840.asp |title=Bush and the National Guard: Case Closed |author=Byron York |publisher=''[[National Review]]'' |date=February 18, 2004 |accessdate=2012-10-25}} In December 1969, Bush began 21 weeks of fighter interceptor training on the [[F-102]] in Houston at the 147th's Combat Crew Training School, soloing in March 1970 and graduating in June 1970. When he graduated, he had fulfilled his two-year active-duty commitment. In November 1970, [[Lieutenant colonel|Lt. Col.]] [[Jerry B. Killian]], commander of the [[111th Fighter Squadron]], recommended that Bush be promoted to [[First Lieutenant]], calling him "a dynamic outstanding young officer" who stood out as "a top notch fighter interceptor pilot." He said that "Lt. Bush's skills far exceed his contemporaries," and that "he is a natural leader whom his contemporaries look to for leadership. Lt. Bush is also a good follower with outstanding disciplinary traits and an impeccable military bearing." Bush was promoted.{{cite news| url=https://query.nytimes.com/gst/fullpage.html?res=940DE1DB1F3AF937A25751C0A9629C8B63 | work=The New York Times | title=Files Offer Glimpse of Bush After College | first=Richard W. | last=Stevenson | date=February 14, 2004 | accessdate=May 3, 2010}} [[Air National Guard]] members could volunteer for active duty service with the Air Force in a program called Palace Alert, which deployed F-102 pilots to Europe and Southeast Asia, including Vietnam and Thailand. According to three pilots from Bush's squadron, Bush inquired about this program but was advised by the base commander that he did not have the necessary flying experience (500 hours) at the time and that the F-102 would soon be retired.{{cite web|last=Stone |first=Isaac |url=http://www.msnbc.msn.com/id/4271922/ |title=War Stories - Newsweek Campaign 2004 |publisher=MSNBC |accessdate=May 24, 2010 |deadurl=yes |archiveurl=https://web.archive.org/web/20061216040554/http://www.msnbc.msn.com/id/4271922/ |archivedate=December 16, 2006 }} Bush's four-year part-time obligation to serve required him to maintain his immediate readiness to be recalled to active duty in the event of a national emergency. Bush performed part-time Guard duty as an F-102 pilot through April 1972, logging a total of 336 flight hours.{{cite web|author=|url=http://washingtontimes.com/national/20040907-113844-8255r.htm |title=Inside Politics |work=Washington Times |date=September 7, 2004 |accessdate=May 24, 2010}} Prior to April 1972, Bush had fulfilled more than the required hours of service, but with more than two years remaining before his discharge. He volunteered his services on several projects, including a political campaign. After April 1972, Bush may have failed to meet the attendance requirements established for members of the Air National Guard. In mid-1972, he failed to meet the Air Force requirement for an annual physical examination for pilots, and lost his authorization to be a pilot.{{cite web |url=http://www.factcheck.org/democratic_groups_ad_revives_awol_allegation_against.html |title=Democratic Group's Ad Revives "AWOL" Allegation Against Bush |archiveurl=https://web.archive.org/web/20121120133253/http://www.factcheck.org/democratic_groups_ad_revives_awol_allegation_against.html |archivedate=November 20, 2012 |publisher=FactCheck.org |accessdate=May 4, 2014 }} According to Bush's pay records, he did not attend any drills between mid-April and the end of October 1972. He drilled in Alabama in October and November 1972, and again in January 1973; what duties he performed are unknown. Bush returned to his home unit in Houston and was paid for his service in April 1973 through July 1973; again, what duties he performed are not documented in any way. On October 1, 1973, Bush was [[honorable discharge|honorably discharged]] from the Texas Air National Guard and transferred to the Air Force Reserve's inactive reserves in [[Denver]], Colorado.{{cite web|url=https://www.usatoday.com/news/bushdocs/2-Discharge.pdf |title=Latest World & National News & Headlines |website=Usatoday.Com |date= |accessdate=2016-09-18}} He was discharged from the Air Force Reserve on November 21, 1974, ending his military service. ==Acceptance into the Air National Guard== During the 1968–1974 period, Presidents [[Lyndon Johnson|Johnson]] and [[Richard Nixon|Nixon]] decided against calling up National Guard units for service in Vietnam. However, military documents show during the Vietnam War, almost 23,000 Army and Air Guardsmen were called up for a year of active duty; some 8,700 were deployed to Vietnam.{{cite web|url=http://www.ng.mil/About/default.aspx |title=Archived copy |accessdate=2011-12-13 |deadurl=yes |archiveurl=https://web.archive.org/web/20130117043307/http://www.ng.mil/About/default.aspx |archivedate=January 17, 2013 |df=mdy }} In 1999, [[Ben Barnes (politician)|Ben Barnes]], former Democratic Speaker of the [[Texas House of Representatives]] and [[Lieutenant Governor of Texas]], gave testimony in a deposition for a lawsuit related to the Texas lottery; and following the deposition, his lawyer issued a statement to the press. According to the statement, Barnes had called the head of the Texas Air National Guard, [[Brigadier general (United States)|Brigadier General]] James Rose, to recommend Bush for a pilot spot at the request of Bush family friend Sidney Adger. The statement also said, "Neither Congressman Bush nor any other member of the Bush family asked Barnes' help. Barnes has no knowledge that Governor Bush or President Bush knew of Barnes' recommendation."{{cite news|last=Holmes|first=Michael|title=Man Says He OK'd Bush for Guard | url=https://www.washingtonpost.com/wp-srv/aponline/19990927/aponline190140_000.htm | work=The Washington Post | date=September 27, 1999 | accessdate=May 3, 2010}} While working as an active fundraiser for [[John Kerry]], Bush's opponent during the 2004 U.S. Presidential campaign,{{cite web|last=Roberts |first=Joel |url=http://www.cbsnews.com/stories/2004/06/18/politics/main624711.shtml |title=Kerry Keeping Eye On Big Donors |publisher=[[CBS News]] |date=2004-06-18 |accessdate=2016-09-18}} Barnes repeated that he used his political influence to preferentially refer people to the National Guard, including Bush.{{cite news | title= New Questions On Bush Guard Duty | url=http://www.cbsnews.com/stories/2004/09/08/60II/main641984.shtml | accessdate=November 19, 2009 |date=September 8, 2004 | work=CBS News}} Both George W. Bush and his father have stated that they did not ask Adger to intercede and were unaware of any action he may have taken. Walter Staudt, the [[colonel]] in command of Bush's squadron, has stated that he accepted Bush's application without receiving any outside pressure to do so.{{cite web | title = Guard Officer Denies Seeking Help for Bush | publisher = ABC News | date = September 17, 2004 | url = http://abcnews.go.com/Politics/Vote2004/story?id=123458 | accessdate =March 27, 2011}} In applying for pilot training, Bush took a standardized test on which he had a low score, in the 25th percentile. In addition, Bush had two arrests for college pranks and four traffic offenses before applying for pilot training. In 2004, former and current military pilots said it was uncommon for an applicant to be accepted into pilot school with such a record, though there was no specific score that disqualified a candidate.{{cite web|title = Why Bush stopped flying remains a mystery|url = http://usatoday30.usatoday.com/news/politicselections/nation/president/2004-02-15-bush-record_x.htm|website = USATODAY.com|accessdate = 2015-10-22|date = February 15, 2004|last = Moniz|first = Dave|last2 = Drinkard|first2 = Jim}} ==Flight performance and flight status in 1972 and 1973== ===Final flights=== Flight logs released in September 2004 in response to a lawsuit (see [[#Release of military records|below]]) showed that Bush, who had been flying in the [[F-102 Delta Dagger|F-102A Delta Dagger]], a single-seater [[interceptor aircraft|interceptor]], for most of his career, flew nine times in [[Lockheed T-33|T-33]] [[trainer (aircraft)|trainers]] in February and March 1972 – nearly twice as many times as he had flown in T-33s in the prior 18 months.[http://www.billingsgazette.com/newdex.php?display=rednews/2004/09/11/build/nation/60-bush-pilot.inc "Bush flew in training planes before losing pilot privileges"] {{webarchive|url=https://web.archive.org/web/20071021131053/http://www.billingsgazette.com/newdex.php?display=rednews%2F2004%2F09%2F11%2Fbuild%2Fnation%2F60-bush-pilot.inc |date=October 21, 2007 }}, ''[[Associated Press]]'', September 11, 2004. The logs also show that on March 12 and April 10 of 1972, Bush took two passes to land his F-102 fighter.{{cite web|last=Eastman|first=Susan Cooper|title=Fear of Flying|url=http://wjwb.com/servlet/Satellite?pagename=WJWB/MGArticle/JWB_BasicArticle&c=MGArticle&cid=1031778123118&path=!frontpage|date=September 23, 2004|publisher=WJWB|archiveurl=https://web.archive.org/web/20050825152157/http://wjwb.com/servlet/Satellite?pagename=WJWB%2FMGArticle%2FJWB_BasicArticle&c=MGArticle&cid=1031778123118&path=%21frontpage|archivedate=August 25, 2005|deadurl=yes|df=mdy-all}} Although White House officials could not explain the changes in the flight logs in these final flights, Air Force experts said there could be any of a number of reasons for the change in Bush's flight pattern. Retired Major General Paul A. Weaver, a former head of the Air National Guard, said Bush could have just been practicing landing skills. "It doesn't mean anything to have multiple approaches," Weaver said.{{cite news |url=http://www.foxnews.com/story/0,2933,131961,00.html |title=Experts Examine Bush Pilot Logs |publisher=Associated Press'' |date=September 10, 2004 |accessdate=2012-10-25}} The final two entries of Bush's official flight logs show him being assigned to work as an instructional pilot in late May 1972 at a Texas Air National Guard base, although he had left for Alabama in mid-May (see [[#Equivalent duty in Alabama|below]]) and his pay records show he was not paid for any work on the two dates of the instructional pilot assignment. Coding on the logs showed these assignments were subsequently deleted from the official record. ===Flight physical=== By regulation, all Air Force pilots were required to take and pass an annual physical in order to remain in flight status, in the three months prior to a pilot's birthday (in Bush's case, July 6). Bush did not take this mandatory physical examination in mid-1972. As a result of his failure to take his physical, his flight status was suspended by his commander on August 1, 1972,{{cite web|url=http://news.findlaw.com/hdocs/docs/gwbush/gwb72-73milpay-p1.html |title=FindLaw - Military Records of President George W. Bush |website=News.findlaw.com |date=2004-02-10 |accessdate=2016-09-18}} confirmed by Col Bobby Hodges on September 5, 1972, and confirmed again by a National Guard Bureau order on September 29, 1972, which meant he no longer was authorized to fly as a pilot.{{cite news|last=Yost|first=Pete|title=Bush's Guard record clean, White House says|url=http://www.deseretnews.com/article/print/595094895/Bushs-Guard-record-clean-White-House-says.html|newspaper=Deseret News|date=September 30, 2004|agency=Associated Press|accessdate=September 20, 2014}}{{cite news| work=Arizona Daily Star| date=February 12, 2004| url=http://www.azstarnet.com/dailystar/relatedarticles/9588.php| title= White House defends Bush service in Guard| archiveurl=https://web.archive.org/web/20051207122426/http://www.azstarnet.com/dailystar/relatedarticles/9588.php|archivedate=December 7, 2005}}{{cite news|last=Riechmann|first=Deb|title=White House Releases '73 Bush Dental Exam|url=https://www.washingtonpost.com/wp-dyn/articles/A34628-2004Feb11.html|work=The Washington Post|agency=Associated Press|accessdate=March 27, 2011|date=February 11, 2004}} Air National Guard regulations require that "the local commander who has authority to convene a Flying Evaluation Board will direct an investigation as to why the individual failed to accomplish the medical examination." But there are no records of an investigation or of any requests to complete one.{{cite web|title = Gaps Remain In Bush Guard Service|url = http://www.cbsnews.com/stories/2004/05/03/politics/main615317.shtml|website = |accessdate = 2015-10-17|date = May 3, 2004|last = Lester|first = Beth|publisher = CBS News}} Although the previous two physicals that Bush had taken were done by flight surgeons, Bush said in 2000 that he wanted to wait to take the physical until it could be done by his own private doctor. But regulations require that the physical be performed by an Air Force doctor. Air Force flight surgeons were assigned to [[Maxwell Air Force Base]] in [[Montgomery, Alabama]], located across town from Maxwell AFB at the [[Montgomery Air National Guard Base|Dannelly Field Air National Guard Base]] at [[Montgomery Regional Airport|Dannelly Field]] airport, where Bush was paid for drilling in October and November 1972 and in January 1973, his only drilling dates between April 1972 and April 1973. According to his released military records, after April 1972 Bush never flew again as an Air National Guard pilot. ==Drill attendance in 1972 and 1973== During 2004, [[Democratic National Committee]] chairman [[Terry McAuliffe]] and others accused Bush of being absent without leave ([[AWOL]]) from the Air National Guard in 1972–73.[http://www.salon.com/news/feature/2004/09/20/bush_guard_records/index.html "Bush in the National Guard: A Primer"] {{webarchive|url=https://web.archive.org/web/20080830011231/http://www.salon.com/news/feature/2004/09/20/bush_guard_records/index.html |date=August 30, 2008 }} Salon.com – September 20, 2004 [[White House]] communications director [[Dan Bartlett]] and others, who called the charge election-year propaganda, noted that Bush was honorably discharged and that no AWOL charge had ever been made against Bush by the National Guard. Released military records show that Bush's documented service record through mid-April 1972 (Bush drilled on the 15th and 16th of that month) was without gaps; the period in question is from May 1972 forward. ===Transfer request=== On May 24, 1972, Bush submitted a form requesting a transfer to the [[9921st Air Reserve Squadron]] in [[Montgomery, Alabama]], under the command of [[Lieutenant Colonel]] Reese R. Bricken. According to the request form, Bush was already in Alabama at work on the Senate campaign of [[Winton M. Blount]], who was a friend of his father. Jimmy Allison, a longtime family friend, helped Bush get the campaign work.{{cite web|last=Elizabeth |first=Mary |url=http://www.salon.com/news/feature/2004/09/02/allison/index.html |title=George W. Bush's missing year |publisher=Salon.com |date=September 2, 2004 |accessdate=May 24, 2010}} On May 26, Bricken approved Bush’s application for transfer. Bricken wrote: "You already understand that this is a Training Category G, Pay Group None, Reserve Section MM proposition." As an obligated Reservist, Bush was in Training Category "fA", which required a minimum of 48 periods of inactive duty training, and 15 days of active duty training, and was required to remain in that Training Category. Training Category "G" offered no training at all. According to Air Force regulations (AFM 35-3, paragraph 14-6), being in "Training Category A" meant that "If a member...will be unable to further train with his unit because of an impending change of residence,...he is required to sign a statement that he has been counseled." That counseling included notifying Bush of his obligation to find a new unit with which he could fulfill his training obligations.{{cite web|url=https://www.nytimes.com/packages/pdf/opinion/lechliter.pdf |format=PDF |title=President George W. Bush’s Military Service: A Critical Analysis |author=Gerald A. Lechliter |date=2004 |website=Nytimes.com |accessdate=2016-09-18}} On July 31, the Air Reserve Personnel Center (ARPC) rejected Bush's transfer request, saying that he could not be reassigned to an Air Reserve Squadron because of his obligated service.{{cite web |url=http://www.glcq.com/docs/transfer_rejection.jpg |title=Memo, Subject: Application for Reserve Assignment, Bush, George W., 1st Lt |publisher=Air Reserve Personnel Center |accessdate=2012-10-22}} Bricken, asked about the matter in 2000, said that Bush made no effort to participate as a Guardsman with the 9921st.{{cite news|last=Robinson |first=Walter V. |title=1-year gap in Bush's Guard duty |url=http://www.boston.com/news/politics/president/bush/articles/2000/05/23/1_year_gap_in_bushs_guard_duty?pg=full |newspaper=The Boston Globe |date=May 23, 2000 |archiveurl=https://web.archive.org/web/20051104012330/http://www.boston.com/news/politics/president/bush/articles/2000/05/23/1_year_gap_in_bushs_guard_duty?pg=full |archivedate=November 4, 2005 |deadurl=unfit }} ===Equivalent duty in Alabama === Bush remained obligated to train with his Texas unit, or to perform substitute training elsewhere each month.{{cite news|url=http://www.boston.com/news/nation/articles/2004/02/10/bush_credited_for_guard_drills/ |title=Bush credited for Guard drills|work=The Boston Globe |date= February 10, 2004| first=Walter V. | last=Robinson|archiveurl=https://web.archive.org/web/20061206113258/http://www.boston.com/news/nation/articles/2004/02/10/bush_credited_for_guard_drills/|archivedate=December 6, 2006}} On September 5, 1972, he requested permission to "perform equivalent duty" at the [[187th Fighter Wing|187th Tactical Reconnaissance Group]] in Alabama "for the months of September, October, and November." He did not receive approval to do so, though his commanding officer recommended he be granted permission. He would have reported to [[Lieutenant Colonel]] William Turnipseed, the base commander, for drills on October 7 and 8, and November 4 and 5 (the September drill dates of the unit had already passed). Bush's grandfather, former U.S. Senator [[Prescott Bush]], died of cancer on October 8, and Bush served as a pallbearer at the funeral in [[Greenwich, Connecticut]]. Turnipseed has said that he could not recall whether Bush reported on those occasions.{{cite news| url=https://www.washingtonpost.com/wp-dyn/articles/A7372-2004Feb2.html | work=The Washington Post | title=Bush's Guard Service In Question | first=Lois | last=Romano | date=February 3, 2004 | accessdate=May 3, 2010}} In 2004, John "Bill" Calhoun, a former [[Alabama Air National Guard]] officer who had served at the [[Montgomery Air National Guard Base|Dannelly Field Air National Guard Base]] in Montgomery, home of the 187th, said he had seen Bush report for duty "at least six times" in the spring and summer of 1972, a period he had not even applied for, and that Bush had in fact spent time in his office.{{cite news| url=https://www.usatoday.com/news/washington/2004-02-13-bush-military_x.htm | work=USA Today | title=Former Guardsman: Bush served with me in Alabama | date=February 13, 2004 | accessdate=May 3, 2010}} However, the payment and retirement records the White House handed out three days prior to Calhoun's claims show that Bush received no pay or attendance credits during that May to October period.{{cite web|url=http://www.thenation.com/blogs/capitalgames?pid=1257 |title=W's AWOL Spin Update! |publisher=Thenation.com |accessdate=May 24, 2010}} The U.S. Senate campaign in Alabama, on which Bush worked, ended on November 7, 1972, when Blount lost overwhelmingly.{{cite news |url=https://news.google.com/newspapers?id=m7JPAAAAIBAJ&sjid=clIDAAAAIBAJ&pg=1372,2968177&dq=winton+blount+1972+senate&hl=en |title=Nixon Went It Alone for Sweeping Victory |work=The Bryan Times |date=November 9, 1972 |author=Mike Feinsilber |publisher=UPI}} Released military records show that Bush was paid for service for the days of October 28–29 and November 11–14, 1973, and for January 4–6 and 8–10, 1973, and that he received a dental examination at Dannelly on January 6.{{cite news| publisher=[[The Nation]]| date=February 19, 2004| url=http://www.thenation.com/blogs/capitalgames?pid=1264| title= What Bush's Guard File Reveals| accessdate=July 10, 2006}}{{cite web|author=|url=http://www.msnbc.msn.com/id/6257505/ |title=More Bush service documents found - Politics |publisher=MSNBC |date=October 15, 2004 |accessdate=May 24, 2010}} All of those dates are outside of the period that was claimed for Bush's service in Alabama. A 2006 column in the ''[[Birmingham News]]'' (Alabama) reported about people who remembered Bush when he was in Alabama, working for the Blount campaign: "None have specific recollections about Bush and the National Guard. Some heard he was serving but never saw for themselves." Opinions of him during his time working on the campaign ranged from good (amiable, well liked, and fond of sports) to bad (bragging about drinking and allegations he trashed a cottage where he was living).{{cite web|last=Blackledge|first=Brett J.|title=Bush Remembered From Social Contacts|url=http://www.al.com/news/birminghamnews/index.ssf?/base/news/1077963426278660.xml|work=The Birmingham News|archiveurl=https://web.archive.org/web/20070607150053/http://www.al.com/news/birminghamnews/index.ssf?%2Fbase%2Fnews%2F1077963426278660.xml|archivedate=June 7, 2007|deadurl=yes|df=mdy-all}} Winton Blount's son Tom said "He was an attractive person, kind of a 'frat boy.' I didn't like him."{{cite news|work=[[Village Voice]]|date=February 11, 2004|url= http://www.villagevoice.com/news/0406,mondo1,50942,6.html |title= Dubya in 'Bama: 'God's Gift to Women' | accessdate=July 10, 2007}} In 1972 and 1973, Bush dated Mavanee Bear, another member of Blount's campaign staff. Bear said in 2009 that "I know [Bush] served" while in Alabama because he had to regularly reschedule meetings, but also said "I didn't see him in uniform." When later back in Texas, she said she frequently saw him in uniform, stating "I think he was mostly just flying in circles over Houston."{{cite web |last=Mayer |first=Jane |url=http://newyorker.com/printable/?talk/040301ta_talk_mayer |title=Old Flames: The Guard Years |work=The New Yorker |date=January 7, 2009 |accessdate=May 24, 2010 |deadurl=yes |archiveurl=https://web.archive.org/web/20120728095327/http://www.newyorker.com/printable/?talk%2F040301ta_talk_mayer |archivedate=July 28, 2012 |df=mdy-all }} In a document dated May 2, 1973, Bush's immediate superiors gave him his [[performance appraisal|annual performance review]] for the period from May 1, 1972, to April 30, 1973. The review stated that "Lt. Bush has not been observed at this unit during the period of the report." {{cite news | author=Beth Lester |title=Gaps Remain In Bush Guard Service |date=May 3, 2004 |accessdate=2012-10-22 |url=http://www.cbsnews.com/stories/2004/05/03/politics/main615317.shtml |work=CBS News}} Lt. Col. William D. Harris Jr. and Lt. Col. [[Jerry B. Killian]] also wrote, "A civilian occupation made it necessary for him to move to Montgomery, Ala. He cleared this base on May 15, 1972 and has been performing equivalent training in a non-flying status with the 187 Tac Recon Gp. Dannelly ANG Base, Alabama." === Return to Houston === Back in Houston, in late 1972 or early 1973, Bush did unpaid volunteer work for a number of months with an inner-city poverty program, Project P.U.L.L. (Professional United Leadership League), the brainchild of John White, a former professional football player and civic leader.{{cite news |date=October 23, 2004 |publisher=Knight-Ridder |title=Former Workers Dispute Bush's Pull in Project P.U.L.L. |author=Meg Laughlin |url=http://www.commondreams.org/headlines04/1023-03.htm |deadurl=yes |archiveurl=https://web.archive.org/web/20130527011318/http://www.commondreams.org/headlines04/1023-03.htm |archivedate=May 27, 2013 |df=mdy-all }} Bush was paid for drilling on April 7–8, 1973. That service presumably occurred at his home base, [[Ellington Air Force Base]], in Houston, in contradiction to the information in his performance review. For May 1973, Bush was paid for service on fifteen days: 1–3, 8–11, 19–20, 22–24, and 29-31. For June, he was paid for five days; for July (his last month of drilling) for 19 days. However there is nothing in the released military documents that shows that he actually reported for duty on those days, or exactly where, or what duties he performed. As of the end of July 1973, Bush had been in the Air National Guard for a little over five years. ==Six-year service obligation== On May 27, 1968, Bush signed a six-year obligation. That required him to complete "48 scheduled inactive-duty training periods" each fiscal year (typically consisting of four four-hour periods during one weekend each month), plus a minimum of 15 days of Annual Active Duty Training. For Bush, as a pilot, this was typically split into periods of duty of a few days each during the year. The ''Boston Globe'' reported in September 2004 that "Bush fell well short of meeting his military obligation", citing examples of Bush failing to meet Air National Guard commitments in 1972 and 1973. Bush's military records show that he was credited for attending Air National Guard drills during 1972 and 1973, but the time frame of these drills (see above) still left questions.{{cite web|last=Robinson |first=Walter V. |title=Bush credited for Guard drills: But time frame leaves questions |url=http://liveweb.web.archive.org/http://www.boston.com/news/nation/articles/2004/02/10/bush_credited_for_guard_drills/?page=2 |archive-url=https://archive.is/20130414074902/http://liveweb.web.archive.org/http://www.boston.com/news/nation/articles/2004/02/10/bush_credited_for_guard_drills/?page=2 |dead-url=yes |archive-date=April 14, 2013 |work=The Boston Globe |date=February 10, 2004 }} On July 30, 1973, his last day of paid service in the Texas Air National Guard, Bush signed a statement that "I have been counseled this date regarding my plans to leave my present Reserve of [sic] assignment due to moving from this area. I understand that: a. If I disassociate from my current Ready Reserve Assignment, it is my responsibility to locate and be assigned to another Reserve Forces unit or mobilization augmentation position. If I fail to do so, I am subject to involuntary order to active duty for up to 24 months under the provisions of AFM 35-3, chapter 14."{{cite news|url=http://www.boston.com/news/nation/articles/2004/09/08/bush_fell_short_on_duty_at_guard/ |title=Bush fell short on duty at Guard |work=Boston Globe |date=September 8, 2004 |accessdate=2010-05-24 |author=Walter V. Robinson}} On September 5, 1973, Bush requested discharge from Texas Air National Guard service, to be effective on October 1. He wrote, "I am moving to Boston, Massachusetts to attend [[Harvard Business School]] as a full time student."{{cite web|title=George W. Bush's letter of request for discharge for the Texas Air National Guard |date=September 5, 1973 |url=http://users.cis.net/coldfeet/doc27.gif |accessdate=June 15, 2006 |deadurl=yes |archiveurl=https://web.archive.org/web/20060530012148/http://users.cis.net/coldfeet/doc27.gif |archivedate=May 30, 2006 }} Jerry Killian recommended approval of the discharge the following day. Bush had completed five years, four months, and five days toward his six-year service obligation. On October 1, 1973, Bush was [[honorable discharge|honorably discharged]] from the Texas Air National Guard and transferred to the Air Force Reserve's inactive reserves in [[Denver]], Colorado. On November 21, 1974, he was discharged from the Air Force Reserve, ending his military service. In September 2004, [[Lawrence Korb]], an Assistant Secretary of Defense under President Ronald Reagan, after reviewing the payroll records for Bush's last two years of service, concluded that they indicated that Bush did not fulfill his obligations and could have been ordered to active duty as a result.{{cite web|last=Roane |first=Kit R. |url=https://www.usnews.com/usnews/news/articles/roane040908.htm |title=Bush's military service in question – again (9/8/04) |publisher=USNews.com |accessdate=May 24, 2010}} ==Release of military records== During the 2000 presidential campaign, various military records of Bush were made public by the Bush campaign. On February 13, 2004, during Bush's re-election campaign, more than 700 additional pages of documents on Bush's service were released, including those from the [[National Personnel Records Center]], under the provisions of the [[United States FOIA|Freedom of Information Act]].{{Cite news|title = Bush's National Guard Pay Records Are Released|url = https://www.nytimes.com/2004/02/11/us/bush-s-national-guard-pay-records-are-released.html|newspaper = The New York Times|date = 2004-02-11|access-date = 2015-10-17|issn = 0362-4331|first = Elisabeth|last = Bumiller}} This release was claimed by some to contradict the statement that Bush made on February 8, 2004 to ''Meet the Press'' interviewer [[Tim Russert]], that "We did [authorize the release of everything] in 2000, by the way." In response, Bush contended that he was referring only to documents already in his possession, as opposed to the newly released documents from military sources. On June 22, 2004, The [[Associated Press]] sued the [[United States Department of Defense|U.S. Department of Defense]] and the [[United States Air Force|U.S. Air Force]], seeking access to all of Bush's records during his military service.{{Cite news|title = Pentagon Says Bush Records of Service Were Destroyed|url = https://www.nytimes.com/2004/07/09/politics/campaign/09records.html|newspaper = The New York Times|date = 2004-07-09|access-date = 2015-10-17|issn = 0362-4331|first = Ralph|last = Blumenthal}} On July 8, 2004, [[the Pentagon]] reported that the [[microfilm]]ed payroll records of Bush and numerous other service members had been inadvertently ruined in 1996 and 1997 by the [[Defense Finance and Accounting Service]] during a project to salvage deteriorating microfilm. The records lost included those covering July through September 1972, when Bush's claims of service in Alabama were in question, and the Pentagon reported that no paper backups could be found.{{cite web|last=Roberts |first=Joel |url=http://www.cbsnews.com/stories/2004/05/03/politics/main615317.shtml |title=Gaps Remain In Bush Guard Service |publisher=[[CBS News]] |date=2004-05-03 |accessdate=2016-09-18}} On July 23, 2004, the Pentagon reported that the records it had previously reported destroyed had been found. A Pentagon official said the earlier statement that the records were destroyed was an "inadvertent oversight." The Pentagon released computerized payroll records covering Bush's 1972 service. Like the records released earlier by the White House, the newly released documents did not indicate that Bush performed any drills, in Alabama or elsewhere, during May through September 1972.{{Cite news|title = Bush Service Records From '72, Thought Lost, Are Discovered|url = https://www.nytimes.com/2004/07/24/politics/campaign/24records.html|newspaper = The New York Times|date = 2004-07-24|access-date = 2015-10-17|issn = 0362-4331|first = Ralph|last = Blumenthal}} On September 7, 2004, the White House released the flight logs recording the flights done by Bush as a pilot. A Pentagon spokeswoman said the logs were found at the National Personnel Records Center in St. Louis, which is the central repository for veterans' records. She said the logs were found among a batch of records sent to St. Louis from [[Norton Air Force Base]] in 1993, which were originally thought to contain records of active-duty officers rather than of National Guardsmen such as Bush.{{Cite news|title = Pentagon Releases Bush's Long-Sought Military Records|url = https://www.nytimes.com/2004/09/08/politics/campaign/pentagon-releases-bushs-longsought-military-records.html|newspaper = The New York Times|date = 2004-09-08|access-date = 2015-10-17|issn = 0362-4331|first = Elisabeth|last = Bumiller}} On September 24, 2004, under court order resulting from an earlier FOIA lawsuit filed by the Associated Press, the Pentagon released more documents.{{cite web | title= Judge orders all Bush records released | url=http://www.msnbc.msn.com/id/6022115|website=Msnbc.msn.com | accessdate=October 4, 2007 }} On September 29, 2004, the White House released a November 1974 document, saying it had been in Bush's personnel file and that it had been found by the Pentagon. On October 5, 2004, more than a week after a court-imposed deadline to turn over all records of Bush's military service, the Texas Air National Guard produced two previously unreleased documents (four pages of records) that included Bush's orders for his last day of active duty in 1973.{{Cite news|title = THE 2004 CAMPAIGN: THE MILITARY RECORDS; Texas Unit Releases More on Bush|url = https://query.nytimes.com/gst/fullpage.html|newspaper = The New York Times|date = 2004-10-06|access-date = 2015-10-17|issn = 0362-4331}} On October 14, 2004, two weeks after Texas National Guard officials signed an oath swearing they had turned over all records, the Texas National Guard released 31 additional pages of documents found by two retired Army lawyers who went through Guard files under an agreement between the Texas National Guard and The Associated Press, which sued to gain access to the files. A Guard spokesman defended the continuing discoveries, saying Guard officials did not find all of Bush’s records because they were disorganized and in poor shape. "These boxes are full of dirt and rat [excrement] and dead bugs. They have never {{sic}} been sitting in an uncontrolled climate," said Lt. Col. John Stanford. "It’s a tough task to go through archives that were not set up in a way that you could easily go through them." ==Memos allegedly from Jerry Killian== {{Main|Killian documents}} {{See also|Killian documents authenticity issues}} The "Killian documents" were initially claimed by CBS to have come from the "personal files" of the late Lt. Col. Jerry B. Killian, Bush's squadron commander during Bush's Air National Guard service.{{cite news | title= New Questions On Bush Guard Duty | url=http://www.cbsnews.com/stories/2004/09/08/60II/main641984.shtml | accessdate=October 3, 2007 |date=September 8, 2004 | work=CBS News}} They describe preferential treatment during Bush's service, including pressure on Killian to "sugar coat" an annual officer rating report for the then 1st Lt. Bush. CBS aired the story on September 8, 2004, amid more releases of Bush's official records by the [[United States Department of Defense|Department of Defense]], including one just the day before as the result of a [[Freedom of Information Act (United States)|FOIA]] lawsuit by the [[Associated Press]].{{cite web | title=AP Sues for Bush Guard Records | website=Editorandpublisher.com | url=http://www.editorandpublisher.com/eandp/departments/newsroom/article_display.jsp?vnu_content_id=1000543184 | accessdate=October 3, 2007 | deadurl=yes | archiveurl=https://web.archive.org/web/20081210121925/http://www.editorandpublisher.com/eandp/departments/newsroom/article_display.jsp?vnu_content_id=1000543184 | archivedate=December 10, 2008 | df=mdy-all }} The Killian documents are widely considered to be fake. Starting with a [[Free Republic]] web posting by Harry MacDougald, a conservative Republican lawyer posting under the blogger name, "Buckhead." MacDougald and multiple fellow bloggers claimed that the formatting shown in the documents used proportional fonts that did not come into common use until the mid-to-late 1990s and alleged that the documents were therefore likely forgeries. {{cite news |title="Buckhead," who said CBS memos were forged, is a GOP-linked attorney |url=http://seattletimes.nwsource.com/html/nationworld/2002039080_buckhead18.html |accessdate=October 3, 2007 |date=March 18, 2002 |work=The Seattle Times |deadurl=yes |archiveurl=https://web.archive.org/web/20070809230831/http://seattletimes.nwsource.com/html/nationworld/2002039080_buckhead18.html |archivedate=August 9, 2007 |df=mdy }}{{cite news | title= After Blogs Got Hits, CBS Got a Black Eye | url=https://www.washingtonpost.com/wp-dyn/articles/A34153-2004Sep19.html | accessdate=October 3, 2007 |date=September 19, 2004 | work=The Washington Post | first=Howard | last=Kurtz}} While the widely publicized rationale of "Buckhead" was technically inaccurate, both related and unrelated serious challenges to the authenticity of the documents nonetheless exist. For instance, it is unlikely that the typewriters available to Killian's secretary could have produced such a document, and the documents contained U.S. Army, rather than U.S. Air Force, jargon.{{cite web|author=Kevin Drum |url=https://www.motherjones.com/kevin-drum/2012/04/bush-national-guard-story-lives |title=The Bush National Guard Story Lives! |publisher=Mother Jones |date=2012-04-16 |accessdate=2016-09-18}}{{cite web|url=http://site.xavier.edu/polt/typewriters/bush.html |title=Are the Bush Documents Fakes? |website=Site.xavier.edu |date= |accessdate=2016-09-18}}{{cite web|url=http://www.bloombergview.com/articles/2014-07-24/ex-60-minutes-producer-is-no-hollywood-hero |title=Ex-'60 Minutes' Producer Is No Hollywood Hero |publisher=Bloomberg View |date= |accessdate=2016-09-18}}{{cite web|url=http://www.washingtonmonthly.com/archives/individual/2004_09/004692.php |title=Killian Finale? |publisher=[[Washington Monthly]] |date= |accessdate=2016-09-18}}{{cite web|url=http://www.texasmonthly.com/politics/truth-or-consequences/ |title=Truth or Consequences |website=Texasmonthly.com |date= |accessdate=2016-09-18}} The forgery allegations subsequently came to the attention of the mainstream media, especially after experts also questioned the documents' authenticity and lack of a chain of custody.[https://www.washingtonpost.com/wp-srv/politics/daily/graphics/cbsdocs_091804.html The Paper Trail: A Comparison of Documents] [[Washington Post]], September 18, 2004Kurtz, Howard [https://www.washingtonpost.com/wp-dyn/articles/A21675-2004Sep14.html?nav=hcmodule Document Experts Say CBS Ignored Memo 'Red Flags'] ''[[Washington Post]]'', (September 14, 2004) Accessed April 30, 2006.{{cite web|url=http://www.creativepro.com/story/feature/21939.html?cprose%3D5-39 |title=Archived copy |accessdate=2007-10-03 |deadurl=yes |archiveurl=https://web.archive.org/web/20070927230255/http://www.creativepro.com/story/feature/21939.html?cprose=5-39 |archivedate=September 27, 2007 |df=mdy }} The original documents have never been submitted for authentication. The man who delivered the copies, Lt. Col. [[Bill Burkett]], a former officer in the Texas Army National Guard and outspoken Bush critic, claimed that he burned the originals. Burkett admitted lying to CBS and ''USA Today'' about where he had obtained the papers and eventually expressed doubts of his own about their authenticity.{{cite web|last=Moniz |first=Dave |url=https://www.usatoday.com/news/politicselections/nation/president/2004-09-21-cover-guard_x.htm |title=CBS backs off Guard story |website=Usatoday.Com |date=2004-09-21 |accessdate=2016-09-18}} CBS and [[Dan Rather]] initially defended the documents and the report,{{cite news | title= CBS Stands By Bush-Guard Memos | url=http://www.cbsnews.com/stories/2004/09/11/politics/main642787.shtml | accessdate=October 3, 2007 |date=September 11, 2004 | work=CBS News}} but on September 20, 2004 – less than two months before Election Day, CBS News stated that it had been "misled" and that it could not authenticate the documents and should not have used them.{{cite news | title= CBS: Bush Memo Story A 'Mistake' | url=http://www.cbsnews.com/stories/2004/09/21/politics/main644719.shtml | accessdate=October 3, 2007 |date=September 21, 2004 | work=CBS News}} A later ''60 Minutes'' broadcast an interview with Marian Carr Knox, secretary to Killian at the time, who stated that she "didn't type these memos", although she stated she had typed memos of similar content.Rebecca Leung, [http://www.cbsnews.com/news/for-the-record-bush-documents-15-09-2004/ For the Record: Bush Documents], Sep 15 2004 (retrieved May 3, 2014) CBS then formed an independent panel headed by former U.S. Attorney General Dick Thornburgh and retired [[Associated Press]] president Louis D. Boccardi to investigate the story and the handling of the Killian memos.{{cite news | title= CBS Names Memo Probe Panel | url=http://www.cbsnews.com/stories/2004/09/06/politics/main641481.shtml | accessdate=October 3, 2007 |date=September 6, 2004 | work=CBS News}} The final report of the panel, while not addressing the authenticity of the documents, faulted many of the decisions made in developing the story, and producer [[Mary Mapes]] along with three others were forced to resign from CBS News.{{cite news | title= CBS Ousts 4 For Bush Guard Story | url=http://www.cbsnews.com/stories/2005/01/10/national/main665727.shtml | accessdate=October 4, 2007 |date=October 4, 2007 | work=CBS News}} Prior to the panel report being completed, Rather announced the date of his retirement,{{cite news | title= Dan Rather to Step Down at CBS | url=https://www.washingtonpost.com/wp-dyn/articles/A7313-2004Nov23.html | accessdate=October 4, 2007 |date=November 23, 2004 | work=The Washington Post | first=Howard | last=Kurtz}} left ''60 Minutes Wednesday'', stepped down as anchor on March 9, 2006, and then left CBS altogether on June 20, 2006.{{cite news | title= Dan Rather Signs Off | url=http://www.cbsnews.com/stories/2006/06/19/national/main1727285.shtml | accessdate=October 4, 2007 | date=June 19, 2006 | work=CBS News}} The CBS news show that had aired the memos, ''60 Minutes Wednesday'', was canceled on May 18, 2005, allegedly due to poor ratings and not because of the memos broadcast.{{cite news | title= '60 Minutes' Wednesday Canceled | url=http://www.cbsnews.com/stories/2005/05/18/60II/main696185.shtml | accessdate=October 4, 2007|date=May 18, 2005 | work=CBS News}} In September 2007, Rather sued CBS and its former parent company, Viacom, for US$70 million, claiming that he had been made a "[[scapegoat]]" over the memos story.{{cite news | title= Rather sues CBS for $70 million, saying he was made a scapegoat | url=http://www.boston.com/news/nation/articles/2007/09/20/rather_sues_cbs_for_70_million_saying_he_was_made_a_scapegoat/ | date=September 20, 2007|accessdate=October 4, 2007 | work=The Boston Globe | first1=Samuel | last1=Maull}} His legal fight with CBS ended in January 2010 when the New York State Supreme Court declined to hear his motion to reinstate his lawsuit.{{cite news |title=Dan Rather loses bid in CBS lawsuit |date=January 13, 2010|author= [[Matea Gold]] |work=Los Angeles Times |url=http://articles.latimes.com/2010/jan/13/entertainment/la-et-rather13-2010jan13 }} ==References== {{Reflist|30em}} ==External links== *[https://web.archive.org/web/20130712233004/http://www.dod.mil/pubs/foi/Personnel_and_Personnel_Readiness/GWBush/ Official Department of Defense website with released documents] *[https://www.usatoday.com/news/2004-02-14-bush-docs.htm USA Today posting of released military records] — A number of links to various documents in .PDF format. *[http://www.cnn.com/2004/ALLPOLITICS/09/14/bush.texans/index.html "Group offers $50,000 for proof of Bush service"] CNN.com – September 14, 2004 *[https://www.youtube.com/watch?v=vqVaNSzEgEw "Dan Rather interviews Marion Carr Knox - September 15, 2004"] Youtube {{George W. Bush}} {{2004 U.S. presidential election}} {{Use mdy dates|date=April 2012}} {{DEFAULTSORT:Military Service Controversy, George W. Bush}} [[Category:George W. Bush presidential campaign, 2004]] [[Category:George W. Bush administration controversies]] [[Category:Killian documents controversy]] [[Category:Military careers|Bush, George W.]] [[Category:George W. Bush]]

{{Philippine name|Juco|Puyat}} {{for|the street|Gil Puyat Avenue}} {{Infobox Officeholder | honorific-prefix = [[The Honourable]] | honorific_suffix = | name = Gil J. Puyat | image = Gil Puyat photo.jpg | imagesize = 210px | smallimage = | caption = | order = [[President_of_the_Senate_of_the_Philippines#List_of_Senate_Presidents|13th]] | office = President of the Senate of the Philippines | president = [[Ferdinand Marcos]] | term_start = January 26, 1967 | term_end = September 23, 1972 | predecessor = [[Arturo Tolentino]] | successor = ''Abolished'', next held by [[Jovito Salonga]] | order2 = | office2 = [[Senate of the Philippines|Senator of the Philippines]] | term_start2 = December 30, 1951 | term_end2 = September 23, 1972 | birth_name = Gil Juco Puyat | birth_date = {{Birth date|1907|9|1}} | birth_place = [[Manila]], [[Insular Government of the Philippine Islands|Philippine Islands]] | death_date = {{Death date and age|1981|3|22|1907|11|1}} | death_place = [[Makati]], [[Philippines]][https://familysearch.org/pal:/MM9.3.1/TH-1-17789-106817-0?cc=1852584&wc=SW5X-82S:167168101,167167602,167230101,215915701 Gil Puyat's Death Certificate] | nationality = [[Filipino people|Filipino]] | party = [[Nacionalista Party]] | spouse = Eugenia Guidote | children = 7 | alma_mater = [[University of the Philippines]] | occupation = | profession = | religion = [[Roman Catholic]] }} '''Gil Juco Puyat Sr.''' (September 1, 1907 – March 22, 1981) was a [[Philippines|Filipino]] statesman and businessman who served as a [[Senate of the Philippines|Senator]] of the [[Philippines]] from 1951, and as [[President of the Senate of the Philippines|Senate President]] from 1967 to 1972. ==Education== Having been exposed to the world of business, Puyat was inevitably drawn to a course in commerce for his higher education. This he pursued at the [[University of the Philippines]] where he topped his class. Even as a student, he was already immersed in intricate operations of finance and expense, of capital and production, and of management labor handling. He became an active member of the business-oriented [http://iskwiki.upd.edu.ph/index.php/Pan_Xenia_Fraternity#.WCIBMfl95PY Pan Xenia Fraternity]. He was also later inducted into [[Upsilon Sigma Phi]] as an honorary member. ==Early career== He became a member of the [[Rotary Club]] of Manila at about the same time that he was also a young professor of economics at the University of the Philippines. Puyat's skill in managing the family business caught the eye of the late President [[Manuel L. Quezon]]. At the time, the country was predominantly agricultural in activity and the President was advocating industrialization. Quezon named the young Puyat as dean of the College of Business Administration at the [[University of the Philippines]] when he was 33, becoming the youngest dean the UP ever had. An active member of international trades bodies, he acquired international stature in business. The Business Writers’ Association of the Philippines voted him "Business Leader of the Year" in 1948 and the Association of Red Feather Agencies voted him "Civic Leader of the Year" in 1949. {{Citation needed|date=July 2011}} In 1953, he received a plaque from the Community Chest of Greater Manila for “ outstanding services as one of the founders, first president and first campaign fund chairman “ of the body. The Philippine Institute of Public Opinion (PIPO) awarded him a certificate of honor for demonstrating national leadership in business, economics, the civic and political fields and for his distinguished service to the youth. {{Citation needed|date=July 2011}} ==Political career== In the [[Philippine general election, 1951|Philippine midterm elections of 1951]], he was elected Senator and he served in the [[Philippine Senate]] until its closure by Martial Law in 1972. From 1967 he was the Senate President. As a legislator, Puyat created a sensation unmarked in political history by his reforms and innovations involving the dispensation of the controversial public works funds. ==Business activities== He is founder of Manila Banking Corporation (now Chinabank Savings Bank), Manila Bankers Life Insurance Corporation and the Loyola Group of Companies. The Loyola Group of Companies is composed of Loyola Plans Consolidated Inc., Group Developers Inc. and Loyola Memorial Chapels and Crematorium Inc. He founded Loyola Plans Consolidated Inc. in 1968 and today it is the oldest Pre-need Company in continuous operation. Group Developers pioneered the concept of memorial parks in the Philippines with its two signature memorial parks in Marikina and Sucat. Loyola Memorial Chapels was the first to use modern cremation technology in the Philippines. Loyola Memorial Chapels has six branches: Commonwealth Avenue Quezon City, 20th Avenue Cubao Quezon City, Marikina, Guadalupe Makati City, Sucat Rd Paranaque City and Los Banos Laguna. ==Family background== Puyat is the third child of Philippine Pioneer Industrialist Gonzalo Puyat and Nicasia Juco. He was trained early in life by his father, Don Gonzalo, in the trade of manufacturing billiard tables and bowling alleys. Eventually, he assisted in managing the family business of Gonzalo Puyat & Sons, the brand holder of AMF-Puyat, Puyat Steel, and Puyat Vinyl. Puyat was married to Eugenia Guidote, an accountant and pioneer member of the [[Philippine Institute of Certified Public Accountants]] (PICPA), and a trained opera singer (soprano). They had seven children – Gil, Jr. (deceased), Vicente (deceased), Antonio, Victor, Jesusa, Alfonso and Eugenia ==Death== In 1978, he was invested as a member of the [[Order of St. Gregory the Great]]. He died, 3 years later, on March 22, 1981 due to [[cardiac arrest]], one of the complications of an asthma attack. He was buried on March 28, 1981 at [[Loyola Memorial Park]] in [[Marikina]]. [[Gil Puyat Avenue|Buendia Avenue]], which was formerly named after the [[Commonwealth of the Philippines|Commonwealth Era]] senator and [[Philippine Independent Church|Aglipayano]] Nicolas Buendia, is now named after him, but most people tend to use the original name of the road. ==References== {{reflist}} ==External links and sources== *[http://www.senate.gov.ph/senators/former_senators/gil_puyat.htm Official Website of the Philippine Senate – Sen. Gil J. Puyat] {{S-start}} {{succession box | before= [[Arturo Tolentino|Arturo M. Tolentino]] | title= [[President of the Senate of the Philippines]] | years= 1967–1972 | after= Abolished
Title next held by [[Jovito Salonga]] }} {{S-end}} {{Philippine Senate Presidents}} {{Candidates in the Philippine presidential election, 1961}} {{DEFAULTSORT:Puyat, Gil}} [[Category:1907 births]] [[Category:1981 deaths]] [[Category:Presidents of the Senate of the Philippines]] [[Category:Senators of the 7th Congress of the Philippines]] [[Category:Senators of the 6th Congress of the Philippines]] [[Category:Senators of the 5th Congress of the Philippines]] [[Category:Senators of the 4th Congress of the Philippines]] [[Category:Senators of the 3rd Congress of the Philippines]] [[Category:Senators of the 2nd Congress of the Philippines]] [[Category:Kapampangan people]] [[Category:People from Pampanga]] [[Category:People from Manila]] [[Category:University of the Philippines alumni]] [[Category:Nacionalista Party politicians]] [[Category:Knights of St. Gregory the Great]] [[Category:Burials at the Loyola Memorial Park]] [[Category:Philippine vice-presidential candidates, 1961]] [[Category:Presidents of the Nacionalista Party]]
