revision.text:
{{Infobox person |name = Kamal Abbas |image = Kamal Abbas (cropped).jpg |image_size = 250px |caption = Kamal Abbas |birth_name = كمال عباس |birth_date = <!-- {{birth date and age|1957|00|10}} --> age 55<ref name="wac-maanil">{{cite web|url=http://www.wac-maan.org.il/en/article__53 |title=Workers Advice Center (WAC/MAAN) | Egypt's Workers on the Move |publisher=Wac/Maan |date=1989-11-25 |accessdate=2011-07-16}}</ref> |birth_place = [[Egypt]] |death_date = <!-- {{Death date and age|YYYY|MM|DD|YYYY|MM|DD}} (death date then birth date) --> |death_place = |residence = Egypt |nationality = Egyptian |known_for = Co-founding CTUWS, activism in the [[2011 Egyptian revolution]], organizer of strikes, advocacy for workers' rights |alma_mater = |employer = |relations = |party = [[Workers Democratic Party]] }}
'''Kamal Abbas''' ({{lang-arz|'''كمال عباس'''}}) is General Coordinator of the [[Center for Trade Unions and Workers Services]] (CTUWS), an activist group for independent unions in [[Egypt]].<ref>{{cite news |last=Dine |first=Philip |url=http://www.washingtontimes.com/news/2011/feb/8/dine-egyptian-workers-key-element-in-uprising/ |title=DINE: Egyptian workers key element in uprising |work = [[The Washington Times]] |date=2011-02-08 |accessdate=2011-07-10}}</ref> Involved in activism for over 20 years,<ref name="towardfreedom1">{{cite web|url=http://www.towardfreedom.com/home/labor/2439-roots-of-egypts-revolution-labor-unions-and-the-uprising-in-tahrir-square |title=Roots of Egypt’s Revolution: Labor Unions and the Uprising in Tahrir Square |publisher=Towardfreedom.com |date=2011-06-22 |accessdate=2011-07-10}}</ref> Abbas has been active in mobilizing worker support during the [[Egyptian Revolution of 2011]] and its aftermath. His approach emphasizes peaceful strikes and rallies accompanied by demands for better wages and working conditions,<ref>{{cite news |url=http://english.aljazeera.net/news/middleeast/2011/02/2011216141815340645.html |title=Egyptians defy call to end strikes - Middle East |work = [[Al Jazeera English]] |date=2011-02-16 |accessdate=2011-07-10}}</ref> as well as more regular elections for union officials, and an independent union system.
He began his work by organizing a strike at a steel plant in [[Helwan]], Egypt in 1989, for which he was arrested, tortured, and fired. That incident led to his starting the CTUWS and advocating for workers' rights throughout Egypt. Abbas' relationship with [[Hosni Mubarak|Mubarak's regime]] was tense and marked by conflicts with the government and multiple arrests.<ref name="towardfreedom1"/> The ''[[Los Angeles Times]]'' called Abbas "a major annoyance" to President Hosni Mubarak's regime, and "passionate, methodical and accustomed to police surveillance."<ref name="latimes1">{{cite news |url=http://articles.latimes.com/2008/may/14/world/fg-activist14 |title=Problems In Egypt - Unions tap into public ire in Egypt |work = [[Los Angeles Times]] |date=2008-05-14 |accessdate=2011-07-16}}</ref>
In 2007, Abbas was charged with [[defamation]] and sentenced to one year of prison. There was international condemnation of the ruling, with major labor and human rights groups defending Abbas. In February 2012 he was once again sentenced to a prison term, this time six months for "insulting" a public official.
Abbas' work gained momentum and attention during the 2011 Egyptian revolution, where he helped mobilize workers in the nationwide movement for civil rights and the overthrow of Hosni Mubarak's regime.
==1989-1990: Early work and founding of CTUWS== Abbas began working in a steel mill in 1975 at the age of 20.<ref name="wac-maanil"/><ref name="aflcio1">{{cite web|url=http://blog.aflcio.org/2007/06/26/labor-support-organization-banned-after-strike-actions/ |title=Egyptian Labor-Support Organization Banned After Strike Actions |publisher=Blog.aflcio.org |date=2007-06-26 |accessdate=2011-07-16}}</ref> While under the [[Hosni Mubarak|Mubarak regime]], Abbas began organizing workers, despite unions being dominated by the state-approved [[Egyptian Trade Union Federation]] (ETUF). In 1989 he participated in a strike at the Iron and Steel Company plant in [[Helwan]] where 19,000 workers sought wage increases and a meal during work. They were met by 10,000 riot police who fired rubber bullets and tear gas at the striking workers;<ref name="aflcio1"/> ultimately the strike was broken up when security forces stormed the plant, resulting on one death, one hundred injuries and hundreds of arrests.<ref name="towardfreedom1"/><ref name="latimes1"/><ref name="aflcio1"/><ref>{{cite web|url=http://www.michaelmoore.com/words/must-read/statement-kamal-abbas |title='We Stand With You as You Stood With Us': Statement to Workers of Wisconsin by Kamal Abbas of Egypt's Centre for Trade Unions and Workers Services |publisher=MichaelMoore.com |date= |accessdate=2011-07-15}}</ref>
Abbas was arrested four times in the subsequent months,<ref name="aflcio1"/> including 45 days of detention in which he was tortured.<ref name="latimes1"/><ref name=stanford/> Following, he was terminated for participating in an “illegal” strike not sanctioned by the official trade union.<ref name="merip1">{{cite web|url=http://www.merip.org/mero/mero050907 |title=Strikes in Egypt Spread from Center of Gravity | publisher = [[Middle East Research and Information Project]] |date= |accessdate=2011-07-11}}</ref>
Several months later in 1990, Abbas co-founded CTUWS in Helwan to support workers and address the lack of independent unions in the private sector.<ref name="towardfreedom1"/><ref name="aflcio1"/><ref name="stanford">{{cite book|url=https://books.google.com/books?id=vnivX-lt1o4C&dq=%22Kamal+Abbas%22&source=gbs_navlinks_s |title=Social Social Movements, Mobilization, and Contestation in the Middle East and North Africa | author=Joel Beinin, Frederic Vairel |publisher=Stanford University Press |year=2011 |accessdate=2011-07-11}}</ref>{{Clarify|what pages?|date=July 2011}} He was guided by the advice of [[Yusuf Darwish]], a long-time communist and labor lawyer, with whom Abbas had previously led the People’s Socialist Party. Abbas had studied world labor movements, looking up to the power of unions in Europe and the Solidarity movement in Poland in the 1980s.<ref name="latimes1"/> Abbas changed his ideological focus from his early ties to Marxist politics, instead focusing CTUWS on practical reform.<ref name="merip1"/>
==1990-2007: Work with CTUWS== Abbas' relationship with Mubarak's regime was tense and marked by conflicts with the government and multiple arrests.<ref name="towardfreedom1"/>
In 1998 Abbas commented on the July strikes at the Egypt-Helwan Textiles Factory and the Nasr Pharmaceutical plant. Abbas saw the incidents as a test of the future of privatisation. He said, "People can now see that there is a choice, that they can say no."<ref>{{cite news |last=Farag |first=Fatemah |url=http://weekly.ahram.org.eg/1998/390/eg2.htm |work = [[Al-Ahram Weekly]] | title = Privatisation faces a hot summer |date=1998-08-19 |accessdate=2011-07-16}}</ref>
In 1999 he spoke out on the need for education and training for workers. He said, "In Korea, development was based on a comprehensive educational policy. We still do not see this happening here. Even in the new factories, production lines are imported with a foreign expert to run them. They are assembly plants and the Egyptian worker does not have to be very skilled. The Egyptian worker does not gain the kind of knowledge that can make him an interactive part of the production process."<ref>{{cite news |url=http://weekly.ahram.org.eg/1999/427/eg6.htm |work =[[Al-Ahram Weekly]] | title = May Day dilemmas |date=1999-05-05 |accessdate=2011-07-16}}</ref>
In the 2000 Parliamentary elections, Abbas nominated himself as an independent labor representative for Helwan. Abbas said that his General Union for Mineral, Electrical, and Engineering Industries at first refused to grant him status as a labor representative. According to Abbas, he received it, "Following a long and exhausting struggle with the general union council."<ref name="almasryalyoum2">{{cite news |url=http://www.almasryalyoum.com/en/node/72833 |title=Labor representation in parliament: Between need and myth | work = [[Almasry Alyoum]] |date=2010-08-28 |accessdate=2011-07-15}}</ref> He also criticized the candidacy of Minister Sayed Mash'al and supported Safir Nigm for minister of military production in the Helwan area. Abbas argued, "After Mash'al took over, there was a massive explosion at one of the factories. Five workers died and compensation was inadequate. When workers complained, [Mash'al] had dozens of them sent to jail."<ref>{{cite news |url=http://weekly.ahram.org.eg/2000/507/eg21.htm |work =[[Al-Ahram Weekly]] | title = Tribal labour |date=1995-11-15 |accessdate=2011-07-17}}</ref>
In 2001 Abbas commented on the increasing privatisation of employment and the role of professional committees. He said, "Approximately 50 per cent of the number of trade union members who make up the current trade union structure belong to and vote for 'professional committees.'" Drivers in the Helwan district, Abbas said, are members of a professional committee, as are the construction workers in Shubra. "These are committees that have few functions. For example, a driver will only go to his union when getting his licence because he needs their signature. We cannot consider these committees or their members active components of the trade union structure or the working class." He noted the changing nature of political alliances regarding unions: "And this time around, the left has changed its election programme from calling for the protection of the public sector to focusing on the protection of workers' rights, irrespective of who the management is."<ref>{{cite news |author=Fatemah Farag |url=http://weekly.ahram.org.eg/2001/552/eg2.htm |work =[[Al-Ahram Weekly]] | title = What lies beneath |date=2001-09-26 |accessdate=2011-07-17}}</ref>
In 2002 a Unified Labour Law came up for parliamentary debate to replace labour law 137, passed in 1981. Abbas criticized exclusions in the bill which left out government administration, domestic work, workers' families, short-term workers (less than six months), principal management, and self-employed workers, and "pure" agricultural work when done by women and minors.<ref name="ahram2002">{{cite news |url=http://weekly.ahram.org.eg/2002/569/ec4.htm |work =[[Al-Ahram Weekly]] | title = Dirge for a dog? |date=2002-01-23 |accessdate=2011-07-16}}</ref>
In 2003 Abbas began seeking formal registration in line with Article 11 of Law 84/2002, which deals with NGO registration, security and public order. Abbas was critical of the registration procedures: "The law is bad and it is designed to co-opt you under government control. And there has been heavy government pressure. But we decided to try and open negotiations with them. After all, in Egypt you never know what is going to happen—things could get even worse tomorrow."<ref name="autogenerated1">''Margins of Repression'' by Human Rights Watch</ref> Abbas fought attempts to exclude the words "worker" and "trade union" from the organization name or scope. "They wanted us to change our name, but we won't, it's internationally recognized. They said the name breaches Article 11. We said no, Article 11 has to do with your goals...They said that our work could breach article 11. 'Your problem is that you speak for workers in disputes, and this we can not allow. There are government agencies and organizations that already do this, and you cannot have face to face meetings [on these issues].'"<ref name="autogenerated1"/>
In 2005 Abbas was critical of how workers' rights were being addressed in the political dialogue. He said, "Unfortunately, the labour movement's democratic demands are absent from the agenda of change called for by the opposition. Even the political parties that are close to workers' circles—such as the Tagammu and Nasserist parties—are only interested now in the laws that regulate political participation and professional syndicates." He told the Egyptian newspaper ''[[Al-Ahram]]'', "Political movements that once upheld the interests of the working class based themselves on public sector workers, most of whom have been liquidated through early retirement schemes...the current environment where workers see people taking on the state and putting up a fight has created a situation in which we can see renewed labour activism of the sort now taking place...I do not think that such a movement would have been possible if it were not for the current movement for political reform."<ref>{{cite news |url=http://weekly.ahram.org.eg/2005/740/eg10.htm |work =[[Al-Ahram Weekly]] | title = May Day and the absent actor |date=2005-05-04 |accessdate=2011-07-10}}</ref>
In 2005 Abbas criticized the negotiations in the Esco workers' protest. He noted that clause 69 of the labor contract, which stipulated workers could be fired if they fail to perform "essential duties", was broad enough to permit random firings.<ref>{{cite news|url=http://weekly.ahram.org.eg/2005/743/eg42.htm |work =[[Al-Ahram Weekly]] | title = A partial victory |date=2005-05-25 |accessdate=2011-07-10}}</ref> Abbas also criticized requirements that protests be approved by the General Federation of Trade Unions (GFTU). He said, "Workers go on strike to improve their material conditions. They are not staging a play. They are not rehearsing for some media circus. And they should not be forced to strike within the straitjacket of a preset timetable. This defeats the purpose of the strike because it limits the workers' bargaining power."<ref>{{cite news |url=http://weekly.ahram.org.eg/2005/734/eg9.htm |work =[[Al-Ahram Weekly]] | title =Nobody's listening |date=2005-03-23 |accessdate=2011-07-11}}</ref>
In June 2005 Abbas commented on legal issues dealing with the Al-Amrya Weaving and Textile Company. He said, "The distinction between public and private sector workers will in any case become irrelevant, sooner or later, given that the entire public sector is on the block. What is important in this case is that the Unified Labour Law (12) of 2003 doesn't differentiate between private and public sector workers. Misr Al-Amrya cannot legally argue on the basis of state workers' rights to base salary increments versus private sector workers' non-rights. Which is why, in the end, the company did eventually comply."<ref>{{cite news |url=http://weekly.ahram.org.eg/2005/749/eg9.htm |work= [[Al-Ahram Weekly]] | title = Political spin-off effects |date=2005-07-06 |accessdate=2011-07-10}}</ref>
In July 2005 Abbas was attacked by plain-clothes Egyptian security forces while demonstrating against human rights abuses by the Mubarak regime. He was badly wounded.<ref>{{cite web|last=Zunes |first=Stephen |url=http://www.fpif.org/articles/bombings_and_repression_in_egypt_underscore_failures_in_us_anti-terrorism_strategy |title=Bombings and Repression in Egypt Underscore Failures in U.S. Anti-Terrorism Strategy |publisher=FPIF |date=2005-08-11 |accessdate=2011-07-10}}</ref>
In 2005 Abbas also criticized the [[Muslim Brotherhood]] for being two-faced in their approach to civil rights. "Egypt has never had democracy. For now the Brotherhood stands for civil rights, but its basic stance is against them. It has one language for the media and another for its followers."<ref>{{cite news | author=Jonathan Steele |url=https://www.theguardian.com/world/2005/jul/29/comment.islam |title= Open debate can tackle the dangers of fundamentalism |work =[[The Guardian]] |date= 2005-07-29 |accessdate=2011-07-15}}</ref>
In November 2006 Abbas dismissed the significance of General Federation of Trade Unions (GFTU) elections, arguing that public sector industrial workers overseen by the GFTU were increasingly few. He recommended switching focus to uninionized private sector workers: "The minister of investment has openly stated that except for four companies the little that remains of the industrial public sector is for sale...the real battle is to fight for trade union pluralism, to build a new and independent trade union structure."<ref>{{cite news |url=http://weekly.ahram.org.eg/2006/818/eg4.htm |work=[[Al-Ahram Weekly]] | title = Battling over a dead horse | date=2006-11-07 |accessdate=2011-07-10}}</ref>
==2007-2010: CTUWS closure, lawsuit, and prison sentence== [[File:Kamal Abbas.jpg|thumb|Kamal Abbas during the 2010 National Minimum Wage protest]]
In November 2007 Abass criticized the government sale of companies to international investors, arguing the transactions led to workers losing their jobs.<ref>{{cite web|last=Kassem |first=Mahmoud |url=https://www.bloomberg.com/apps/news?pid=newsarchive&sid=ayJBbeRA0qLw&refer=home |title=Egypt's Bow to Unions Stalls State Asset Sales, Investing Boom |publisher= [[Bloomberg L.P.]] |date=2007-04-23 |accessdate=2011-07-11}}</ref>
In 2007 he criticized the state of politics, calling the regime illegitimate, and saying that Egypt is "a suffering society with no way to express itself."<ref name="latimes1"/> He speculated that poverty in Cairo could lead to a violent confrontation with the police.<ref name="latimes1"/> Abbas envisioned a charismatic opposition leader who could rise up amidst the tension, but he did not believe such an individual would be part of the labor movement. He said, "Those who think the labor movement will lead to political change in Egypt are foolish. The movement is still too young. We have to be concerned with the economic conditions of the workers. We can't rush things."<ref name="latimes1"/>
In April 2007 Abbas' CTUWS office was shut down and he was accused of working with "external forces" in order to disrupt the country's economy. The government closed CTUWS' Helwan headquarters and two other branches in Nag' Hamadi and Mehala Al-Kobra for "security reasons".<ref name="ahram2007">{{cite news |url=http://weekly.ahram.org.eg/2007/866/eg4.htm |work = [[Al-Ahram Weekly]] | title = Inconvenient truths | date=2007-10-17 |accessdate=2011-07-16}}</ref>
In September 2007 Abbas and another writer were convicted of defamation and public abuse after writer Mohamed Helmy published an article on corruption at the 15th of May Youth Center, where Abbas was a member of the board. The story was published in ''Kalam Sanay'iya'', a magazine published by the CTUWS. The lawsuit for alleged "slander and defamation of character" against Abbas—and his co-defendant lawyer Mohamed Helmi—was filed by Mohamed Mustafa Ibrahim, chairman of the board of directors at the youth center.<ref name="ahram2007"/> Ibrahim filed three petitions against Abbas and claimed that the magazine article "publicly defamed him as a state-appointed civil servant". He based his case on Article 188 of the Egyptian code of law,<ref name="ahram2007"/> which penalizes false reporting (anyone who "publishes false news, statements or rumours likely to disturb public order" may face a prison sentence).<ref name="ahram2007"/> Abbas was sentenced to one year in prison.<ref name="latimes1"/><ref name="autogenerated2">{{cite web|url=https://www.npr.org/templates/story/story.php?storyId=15218389 |title=Striking Textile Workers in Egypt Get Concessions |publisher=NPR |date=2007-10-12 |accessdate=2011-07-16}}</ref>
About the incident, Abbas commented to [[National Public Radio]], "The government is also very sensitive about any links between political powers in Egypt and the labor movement because this would mean that workers might enter with their weight into the democratic movement. They're very scared of this."<ref name="autogenerated2"/>
"It is clear the judge's decision to give me a one-year jail sentence is political...It is no coincidence that I was sentenced at about the same time as the journalists and editors," Abbas told Ahram Weekly. "The court had regularly adjourned the case since May, deciding to issue a ruling only on 21 September. Prosecuting and sentencing journalists for publishing offences is all part of the government's general crack-down on civil liberties. The government feels threatened by the strikes, especially actions taken by the militant Mehala Al-Kubra textile workers whose latest strike was settled last week. They need a scapegoat for their failed policies. This is why they closed down our offices, refuse to license us and continue to accuse the CTUWS of inciting the strikes. The allegations are flattering but untrue. How could we possibly have incited the tens of thousands of workers who have gone on strike since December?" he said.<ref name="ahram2007"/>
CTUWS criticized the conviction. "What does it mean when courts seek to imprison citizens, who publish the facts about corruption cases? The allegations against Ibrahim were found to be true and were the basis for the legal decision... Does it mean that the courts are offering immunity to corrupt officials, that they are offering protection against any criticism or disclosure?"<ref name="ahram2007"/>
International labor and human rights groups came out in support of Abbas and condemned the court decision.<ref name="thedailynewsegypt1">{{cite news |url=http://www.thedailynewsegypt.com/international-labor-groups-condemn-conviction-of-labor-leader-kamal-abbas.html |title=International labor groups condemn conviction of labor leader Kamal Abbas |work =Thedailynewsegypt.com |date= |accessdate=2011-07-16}}</ref> The [[International Confederation of Trade Unions (ITUC)]], accused the Mubarak regime of going after opposition groups and media. "We are very concerned about this latest attack on the CTUWS. We are particularly concerned that these prison sentences follow a long tradition of repression of the CTUWS, an independent civil society organization committed to defending trade union and workers rights in Egypt," said Guy Ryder, ITUC general secretary.<ref name="thedailynewsegypt1"/> A coalition of the Italian trade unions sent a letter to Mubarak asking him to "ensure that CTUWS is not persecuted and demanding that "this particular case could be reviewed. The Euro-Mediterranean Human Rights Network also issued a statement "expressing its deep concern over the case.<ref name="thedailynewsegypt1"/>
Egyptian labour historian Joel Beinin said, "The attack on CTUWS is part of the intensification of the assault of the Mubarak regime against its opponents".<ref name="ahram2007"/> Faiza Rady considered the prison sentence an attack on the defence of workers' rights.<ref name="ahram2007"/>
After Abbas' and Helmy's September conviction, an investigation by the Governor of Cairo found the charges of corruption at the youth center to be true. Cairo Governor Abdel Azim Wazir ordered the entire board of the center to be disbanded.<ref name="thedailynewsegypt1"/>
Abbas appealed his conviction at a Dec. 29 hearing. He and Helmy remained free between the case and the appeal.<ref name="thedailynewsegypt1"/>
In 2009 [[Human Rights Watch]] noted a significant increase "in the harassment of human rights activists at Cairo airport", which included the detainment of Abbas.<ref>{{cite web|author=Sarah Leah Whitson, Middle East director |url=https://www.hrw.org/en/news/2010/01/24/egypt-and-libya-year-serious-abuses |title=Egypt and Libya: A Year of Serious Abuses | publisher = [[Human Rights Watch]] |date=2010-01-24 |accessdate=2011-07-15}}</ref><ref>{{cite news |url=http://www.almasryalyoum.com/en/node/2128 |title=No fly zone: The perils of Cairo Airport | work = [[Almasry Alyoum]] | date=2009-10-21 |accessdate=2011-07-15}}</ref>
In 2010 the Egyptian Minister of Planning created a committee regarding [[minimum wage]], which Abbas criticized for not acting. Abbas supported working with the new committee's goals, which included a minimum annual salary increase of seven per cent. He also criticized the labour complaints committee for not meeting regularly.<ref>{{cite news |url=http://weekly.ahram.org.eg/2004/689/eg2.htm |work =[[Al-Ahram Weekly]]| title = Labour backlog | date=2004-05-12 |accessdate=2011-07-15}}</ref>{{Clarify | how can the article be dated when it discusses 2010?|date=July 2011}}
In 2010 Abbas criticized proposals to postpone trade union elections. Abbas criticized the role of the ETUF as "a governmental institution, not a federation of genuine trade unions. Nor does it represent Egypt's workers in any way."<ref name="almasryalyoum1">{{cite web|url=http://www.almasryalyoum.com/en/node/227915 |title=ETUF makes bid to rally workers behind president, regime | work = [[Almasry Alyoum]] |date=2009-12-16 |accessdate=2011-07-10}}</ref> Abbas also noted the practice of elected officials busing in members of their constituency to vote.<ref name="almasryalyoum1"/>
In May 2010 Abbas criticized the forced end of a protest in Cairo by workers from Amonsito, the Egyptian Telephone Company and el-Nubaria Agricultural Engineering, who had been protesting for several months. Abbas had said he would submit a complaint to the International Labour Organization about the incident.<ref>{{cite news|url=http://www.almasryalyoum.com/en/node/44045 |title=Streets cleaned and protesters cleared out for Kenyan PM's visit | work = [[Almasry Alyoum]] |date=2010-05-25 |accessdate=2011-07-11}}</ref>
In August 2010 Abbas criticized the constitutionality of military courts being used on civilians working in military production facilities.<ref>{{cite news |url=http://www.almasryalyoum.com/en/node/74146 |title=Military court acquits 3 workers, suspends sentences of others | work = [[Almasry Alyoum]] | date=2010-08-30 |accessdate=2011-07-15}}</ref>
Also in August Abbas criticized ETUF head Megawer of being an appointed labor representative in positions that are mandated to be elected. Abbas also criticized Megawer's affiliation with the [[National Democratic Party (Egypt)|National Democratic Party (NDP)]], suggesting that the ETUF should not be determining eligibility for parliamentary elections. Abbas argued, "The ETUF has actually granted a number of businessmen and retired officers, from the ruling party, the status of labor representatives when they are not laborers in any way shape or form."<ref name="almasryalyoum2"/>
==2011-present: Egyptian revolution== {{External media | video1 = {{YouTube|dHqWMxxBdMY|The role of Independent Unions in Egypt's Revolution}} | video2 = {{YouTube|5Y6uc8tV3G0|Egyptian Unions In Solidarity With Wisconsin Workers}} }} During the revolution, Abbas made an appeal for new trade unions at [[Tahrir Square]]. He said, “On January 30th we met with representative of other independent trade union organizations and we discussed forming a new federation. We then made an announcement in Tahrir square, calling for a new federation. But at the time we had no idea what would happen. Since then this call has been responded to by the workers. The challenge now that the revolution has succeeded is to be able to build a society of social justice.”<ref name="towardfreedom1"/>
In February 2011 Abbas criticized the elections in federation syndicates for being corrupt with fraud. He said, "There are 116 verdicts of administrative court annulling the last union elections and we believe members of the federation were involved in acts of violence against the protesters in Tahrir.” Abbas recommended creating independent syndicates, saying, "We will do as our grandfathers did before 1952 when the first unions were created in Egypt.”<ref>{{cite news |url=http://english.ahram.org.eg/NewsContentPrint/3/0/6383/Business/0/Revolution-fuels-Egypt-labour-movement-.aspx |work = [[Al-Ahram]] | title = Revolution fuels Egypt labour movement |date=2011-02-25 |accessdate=2011-07-10}}</ref>
Also in February, Abbas supported strikes motivated by "how many billions the Mubarak family was worth."<ref>{{cite news |url=http://seattletimes.nwsource.com/html/nationworld/2014178863_egypt10.html |title= Strikers in Egypt try to turn up heat on Mubarak | work = [[The Seattle Times]] |date=2011-02-09 |accessdate=2011-07-15}}</ref><ref>{{cite news |url=https://nationalpost.com/news/Strikes+sweep+Egyptian+workplaces/4257204/story.html |title=Strikes sweep Egyptian workplaces |work = [[National Post]] |date=2011-02-10 |accessdate=2011-07-15}}</ref>
In May 2011 Abbas celebrated [[International Workers' Day]] (also known as "May Day"), the international socialist commemoration of workers' rights reform begun in the United States. Abbas deemed that year's celebrations “historic” for marking a break from the ETUF. Abbas also praised the then newly formed Egyptian Federation of Independent Trade Unions (EITUF). May Day celebrations focused on the free will of Egyptian workers to form independent trade unions, free from state control, and the dismantling of the ETUF.<ref>{{cite news |url=http://english.ahram.org.eg/NewsContent/1/64/11128/Egypt/Politics-/Egyptians-celebrate-first-May-Day-since-popular-up.aspx |title=Egyptians celebrate first May Day since popular uprising | work = [[Al-Ahram]] |date= |accessdate=2011-07-10}}</ref>
In June 2011, Abbas was co-filer of a lawsuit calling for the dissolution of the state-controlled ETUF. The suit called for "sequestration of the ETUF headquarters, buildings, its Workers' University, cultural institute, hospitals and clinics" as well as "barring the ETUF from representing Egypt's workers or unions at international conferences".<ref>{{cite news |url=http://www.almasryalyoum.com/en/node/468158 |title=Legal battle against Mubarak's trade union federation begins | work =[[Almasry Alyoum]] |date=2011-06-14 |accessdate=2011-07-10}}</ref>
Abbas interrupted the ETUF's Ismail Fahmy during his speech at the [[International Labour Organization|International Labour Organization (ILO)]] June 2011 conference. Abbas criticized the ETUF saying, "Enough ... all these years ... and crimes enough! ... Enough you killers! ... You participated in the passage of the privatization deals, and facilitated and justified the blatant attacks on the rights of workers ... You defended with impunity Mubarak's regime with its corruption, repression and tyranny, and then you plotted against the killing of the revolutionaries in Tahrir Square!"<ref>{{cite web|url=http://www.workersliberty.org/story/2011/06/13/enough-you-killers-egypts-independent-unions-confront-state-labour-front |title="Enough you killers" - Egypt's independent unions confront state labour front | publisher=[[Alliance for Workers' Liberty]] |date= 2011-06-13 |accessdate=2011-07-10}}</ref>
During the 2011 revolution Abbas made a video from [[Tahrir Square]] telling American workers who were on [[2011 Wisconsin protests|strike]] in [[Wisconsin]]: <blockquote>"From this place, I want you to know that we stand with you as you stood with us. I want you to know that no power can challenge the will of the people when they believe in their rights. When they raise their voices loud and clear and struggle against exploitation. No one believed that our revolution could succeed against the strongest dictatorship in the region. But in 18 days the revolution achieved the victory of the people….We want you to know that we stand on your side. Stand firm and don’t waiver. Don’t give up on your rights. Victory always belongs to the people who stand firm and demand their just rights. We and all the people of the world stand on your side and give you our full support. As our just struggle for freedom, democracy and justice succeeded, your struggle will succeed. Victory belongs to you when you stand firm and remain steadfast in demanding your just rights."<ref>{{cite news |author=Mark Levine |url=http://english.aljazeera.net/indepth/opinion/2011/02/201122518445333563.html |title=History's shifting sands |publisher= [[Al Jazeera English]] |date=2011-02-26 |accessdate=2011-07-10}}</ref><ref>{{cite news | title = Eating Egyptian pizza in Wisconsin |author= Kroll A |url=http://www.atimes.com/atimes/Middle_East/MC04Ak01.html |work =[[Asia Times]] |date=2011-03-04 |accessdate=2011-07-15}}</ref></blockquote>
In March 2011, Abbas participated in a labour panel discussing the future of trade unions following the fall of Mubarak's regime. At the end of the panel, Abbas declared, “the regime has fallen...the Egyptian Federation of Trade Unions has fallen! What more do you want? Go create your own unions!”<ref>{{cite news |url=http://english.ahram.org.eg/NewsContent/1/64/7652/Egypt/Politics-/Egypt-Labor-minister-declares-the-end-of-governmen.aspx |title=Egypt Labor minister declares the end of government domination of trade unions | work = [[Al-Ahram]] |date=2011-03-14 |accessdate=2011-07-11}}</ref>
On 29 February 2012, the [[CTUWS]] reported that Abbas had been sentenced ''in absentia'' to six months in prison for "insulting" a public official.<ref>{{cite web |url=http://ctuws.com/view.aspx?id=1123&item=1123 |title=A judgment in absentia has been issued on Kamal Abbas, CTUWS general coordinator, of six months imprisonment |publisher=[[CTUWS]] |date=2012-02-29 |accessdate=2012-02-29 |deadurl=yes |archiveurl=https://web.archive.org/web/20130512011355/http://ctuws.com/view.aspx?id=1123&item=1123 |archivedate=12 May 2013 |df=dmy-all }}</ref>
== See also ==
* [[Sameh Naguib]] * [[Kamal Khalil]] * [[Kamal el-Fayoumi]]
== References ==
{{reflist|colwidth=30em}} {{Use dmy dates|date=July 2011}}
==External links== * [http://www.ctuws.com/Default.aspx CTUWS] * [[LA Times]] [http://articles.latimes.com/2008/may/14/world/fg-activist14 profile] * [https://www.npr.org/templates/story/story.php?storyId=15218389 2007 National Public Radio (NPR) interview]
{{DEFAULTSORT:Abbas, Kamal}} [[Category:Egyptian democracy activists]] [[Category:Egyptian human rights activists]] [[Category:Egyptian revolutionaries]] [[Category:Living people]] [[Category:People of the Egyptian revolution of 2011]] [[Category:Egyptian trade unionists]] [[Category:Year of birth missing (living people)]] [[Category:Egyptian nationalists]]

page.title: List of Britain & Ireland's Next Top Model contestants

revision.comment: Rescuing 76 sources and tagging 1 as dead. #IABot (v2.0beta9)
revision.text:
{{Use dmy dates|date=December 2012}} This is a list of contestants who have appeared on the British television show ''[[Britain & Ireland's Next Top Model]]''. Contestants compete against each other to become the next British and Irish top model. They are judged by model [[Abigail Clancy]] (previously [[Lisa Butcher]], [[Lisa Snowdon]], and [[Elle Macpherson]]) and her panel of judges to win a modeling contract with [[Models 1]], a cover and/or spread in a magazine, and a cosmetics campaign. The series first aired in 2005 and as of 2017, there have been twelve "cycles" that have aired. In its twelve years running, twelve models have been crowned ''Britain's Next Top Model'': [[Lucy Ratcliffe]], Lianna Fowler, Lauren McAvoy, [[Alex Evans (model)|Alex Evans]], [[Mecia Simson]], [[Tiffany Pisani]], Jade Thompson, Letitia Herod, [[Lauren Lambert]], Chloe Keenan, Olivia Wardell & Ivy Watson. ==Contestants== {{legend|#B2FFAB|The contestant won the competition}} {{legend|lightblue|The contestant participated a second time in the [[America's Next Top Model, Cycle 18|18th cycle of America's Next Top Model]], which featured contestants from the US vs the UK.<ref name=Blog>{{cite web| url=http://blog.cwtv.com/2012/02/09/16653/| title=The British are Coming! "America’s Next Top Model: British Invasion" Premieres Wednesday, February 29| publisher=The CW| date=9 February 2012| accessdate=9 February 2012}}{{dead link|date=December 2017 |bot=InternetArchiveBot |fix-attempted=yes }}</ref>|border=solid 1px #AAAAAA}} {{legend|thistle|The contestant competed in a previous cycle of the series}}

page.title: List of Pinoy Big Brother: 737 housemates

revision.text:
{{DISPLAYTITLE:List of ''Pinoy Big Brother: 737'' housemates}} This is a list of housemates that participated in ''[[Pinoy Big Brother: 737]]'', the second special season of ''[[Pinoy Big Brother]]'' that started airing in June 20, 2015.
The housemates are listed below in order of their entry into the House. Their '''ages at the time of their entry''' are also indicated. {{TOC right}} <!-- keep the table of contents on the right side, please. READ 'VIEW HISTORY' FOR NOTES -->
==[[Pinoy Big Brother: 737 – Part 1|Teen housemates]]== <!-- Users who will continually add unconfirmed information will be given a warning. Your IP address could be blocked from editing this soon if you start abusing it. Thanks --> The teen housemates are the first set of housemates to set foot inside the house. The first seven housemates entered on Day 1, while an additional four housemates entered on Day 2. They stayed for 50 days, until August 8, 2015.
===Ryan=== <!-- You can be given a warning for vandalism without notice. Once these accumulate, you cannot edit in Wikipedia. --> <!-- Pwede kang mabigyan ng babala ng hindi mo alam. Kapag ito ay naipon, hindi ka na pwedeng makapag-edit sa Wikipedia. --> '''Ryan James Bacalla''' (born April 9, 2001) is a 16-year-old student from [[Cebu City]]. He knew he was gay at a young age, and was bullied at school because of it. His family is yet to accept his sexuality. Ryan is an achiever, participating in both academics and extra co-curricular activities such as dancing, editorial writing, and acting. He was first nominated on Day 15, but survived the eviction. He was nominated again and was evicted on Day 28.<ref>{{cite web | url=http://entertainment.abs-cbn.com/tv/shows/pbb737/housemates/profile/ryan-james-bacalla | title=Ryan Bacalla profile | publisher=''[[ABS-CBN]]'' | date=June 20, 2015 | accessdate=June 22, 2015}}</ref>
===Kenzo=== <!-- You can be given a warning for vandalism without notice. Once these accumulate, you cannot edit in Wikipedia. --> <!-- Pwede kang mabigyan ng babala ng hindi mo alam. Kapag ito ay naipon, hindi ka na pwedeng makapag-edit sa Wikipedia. -->
'''Karlos Lorenzo "Kenzo" Lazcanotegui Gutierrez''' (born February 17, 1997) is an 18-year-old student-athlete from [[Quezon City]]. He is studying at [[Ateneo de Manila University]] and is a football player since prep school. He was nominated on week 4, but was saved after Kyle made a voluntary exit. He was nominated on week 6, but was saved after a ''Ligtask'' challenge. On Day 49, he was the last evictee of the batch, with -9.38% of the net votes.
===Jimboy=== <!-- You can be given a warning for vandalism without notice. Once these accumulate, you cannot edit in Wikipedia. --> <!-- Pwede kang mabigyan ng babala ng hindi mo alam. Kapag ito ay naipon, hindi ka na pwedeng makapag-edit sa Wikipedia. --> {{main article|Jimboy Martin}} '''Hendrix Jim "Jimboy" Balasoto Martin''' (born October 12, 1997) is a 20-year-old student from [[Nueva Vizcaya]]. He is fond of basketball and writing his own rap verses, usually about social issues. His college education is uncertain despite both of his parents working hard to make e8nds meet. He is also determined to help his family financially.<ref>{{cite web | url=http://entertainment.abs-cbn.com/tv/shows/pbb737/housemates/profile/hendrix-jimboy-martin | title=Jimboy Martin profile | publisher=''[[ABS-CBN]]'' | date=June 20, 2015 | accessdate=June 23, 2015}}</ref> He survived the first three nominations and secured immunity with Franco and Zonia on week 4. On week 5, he loses together with the Pinoy Big Brothers and Sisters in ''The Big-Ating Concert'' and was automatically nominated for the first time. On Day 49, he secured his place as a finalist with 10.9% of the net votes. He exited the House on Day 50. He exited on Day 142, emerging as the winner for the teen batch, garnering 56.76% of the votes, out of 4.
===Bailey=== <!-- You can be given a warning for vandalism without notice. Once these accumulate, you cannot edit in Wikipedia. --> <!-- Pwede kang mabigyan ng babala ng hindi mo alam. Kapag ito ay naipon, hindi ka na pwedeng makapag-edit sa Wikipedia. --> <!-- This will be my last edit of Bailey's age. Anyone who changes this further will be given a warning for vandalism. Thanks. --> {{Main|Bailey May}}
'''Bailey Thomas Cabello May''' (born August 6, 2002) is a 13-year-old social media personality from [[Norwich]], [[United Kingdom]]. He was born in [[Cebu City]] to a Filipino mother and a British father before moving to UK at age 4. Though he frequently visits his relatives in Cebu, he only knows little of the Filipino language. He is, by far, the youngest Big Brother housemate in the whole franchise.<ref>{{cite web | url=http://entertainment.abs-cbn.com/tv/shows/pbb737/housemates/profile/bailey-thomas-may | title=Bailey May profile | publisher=''[[ABS-CBN]]'' | date=June 20, 2015 | accessdate=June 23, 2015}}</ref> He was nominated for three consecutive weeks but he continues to evade eviction. On week 3, he won the Ligtask challenge, rendering him safe from nomination. On week 4, he was nominated after failing the immunity challenge, but got saved by the winning team. On Week 5, his group, the Dream Team, won the majority of votes for their performances in ''The Big-Ating Concert'' thus, being granted immunity along with Franco and Ylona. On week 6, he used the ''Ligtas'' app from the Big Tablet to save himself from nomination. On Day 49, he became a finalist with 1.99% of the net votes. He exited the House on Day 50. He returned to the House on Day 99. He was placed fourth during the finale night, and garnered 7.58% of the votes, out of 4. He exited on Day 141.
===Kamille=== <!-- You can be given a warning for vandalism without notice. Once these accumulate, you cannot edit in Wikipedia. --> <!-- Pwede kang mabigyan ng babala ng hindi mo alam. Kapag ito ay naipon, hindi ka na pwedeng makapag-edit sa Wikipedia. --> '''Ma. Anna Kristina Kamille Santos Filoteo''' (born December 7, 1996) is a 18-year-old from [[Manila]]. She is a teen mother and gave birth to her 2-year-old daughter when she was 16 years old. She was taking up a psychology degree.<ref>{{cite web | url=http://entertainment.abs-cbn.com/tv/shows/pbb737/housemates/profile/kamille-filoteo | title=Kamille Filoteo profile | publisher=''[[ABS-CBN]]'' | date=June 20, 2015 | accessdate=June 23, 2015}}</ref> She was originally nominated with Barbie and Bailey for the first nomination but she won the Ligtask challenge. She was nominated on week 4, but was saved after Kyle made a voluntary exit. She was evicted on Day 47. On Day 84, she, together with Mikee, re-entered the House. She became a cross-over housemate and fought for a chance to be an official housemate, with her fate to be decided through public voting.<ref>{{cite web|last1=Lastrilla|first1=Gary Ann|title=PBB 737 ex-housemates Mikee and Kamille re-enter Big Brother’s house as Big Yanig challengers|url=http://entertainment.abs-cbn.com/tv/shows/pbb737/show-updates/2015/09/11/9111583-pbb-737-ex-housemates-mikee-and-kamille-re-enter-big-brothers-house-as-big-yanig-challengers|publisher=ABS-CBN|accessdate=12 September 2015}}</ref> She was re-evicted on Day 86.
===Barbie=== <!-- You can be given a warning for vandalism without notice. Once these accumulate, you cannot edit in Wikipedia. --> <!-- Pwede kang mabigyan ng babala ng hindi mo alam. Kapag ito ay naipon, hindi ka na pwedeng makapag-edit sa Wikipedia. --> <!-- This will be my last edit of Barbie's age. Anyone who changes this further will be given a warning for vandalism. Thanks. --> '''Barbie Concina Imperial''' (born August 1, 1998) is a 20-year-old from [[Daraga, Albay]]. Her name suits her doll-like physical features. She grew up in a broken family and she only sees her father frequently. Barbie's family currently lives in a house beside the [[Philippine National Railways]] in Albay. She was nominated on Day 7, along with Bailey and Kamille but Kamille was saved through the ''Ligtask Challenge''. She and Bailey became nominees on week one. She was evicted on Day 14.
===Ailah=== <!-- You can be given a warning for vandalism without notice. Once these accumulate, you cannot edit in Wikipedia. --> <!-- Pwede kang mabigyan ng babala ng hindi mo alam. Kapag ito ay naipon, hindi ka na pwedeng makapag-edit sa Wikipedia. --> '''Ailah Montacar Antopina''' (born February 28, 2002) is a 13-year-old student from [[Bacolod]]. She belongs to a family that practices Islam. Her mother is a housewife and her father is an overseas worker in [[Saudi Arabia]].<ref>{{cite web | url=http://entertainment.abs-cbn.com/tv/shows/pbb737/housemates/profile/aila-antopina | title=Ailah Antopina profile | publisher=''[[ABS-CBN]]'' | date=June 20, 2015 | accessdate=June 23, 2015}}</ref> She is the first teen Muslim housemate of the franchise. The show has consulted different authorities, including the [[National Commission on Muslim Filipinos]], to prepare Ailah for her stay in the House. The housemates are being reminded to consider Ailah's restrictions when living inside the house, like not buying pork for their weekly shopping, among other things. She was given a buzzer by Big Brother to guide her when its time to do her daily prayers. She was nominated on week 2 and was evicted on Day 21.
===Kyle=== <!-- You can be given a warning for vandalism without notice. Once these accumulate, you cannot edit in Wikipedia. --> <!-- Pwede kang mabigyan ng babala ng hindi mo alam. Kapag ito ay naipon, hindi ka na pwedeng makapag-edit sa Wikipedia. --> '''Edward Kyle Parada Secades''' (born December 7, 1997) is a 18-year-old from [[San Juan, Metro Manila|San Juan]]. He is seen in several print and television ads. He grew up having a low self-esteem because of his weight. He decided to do something about his weight, and has regained his confidence. His grades improved and now has a girlfriend for ten months now.<ref>{{cite web | url=http://entertainment.abs-cbn.com/tv/shows/pbb737/housemates/profile/edward-kyle-secades | title=Kyle Secades profile | publisher=''[[ABS-CBN]]'' | date=June 20, 2015 | accessdate=June 23, 2015}}</ref> He avoided being nominated on the first 3 weeks, but on week 4, he was up for eviction, but won the ''Ligtask'' challenge. Due to personal reasons, he opted for a voluntary exit. He exited on Day 36.
===Zonia=== <!-- You can be given a warning for vandalism without notice. Once these accumulate, you cannot edit in Wikipedia. --> <!-- Pwede kang mabigyan ng babala ng hindi mo alam. Kapag ito ay naipon, hindi ka na pwedeng makapag-edit sa Wikipedia. --> '''Zonia Ysabel Baes Mejia''' (born August 26, 2001) is a 14-year-old from [[Quezon City]]. Her family owns a small bakery. Her parents are strict and impose a curfew on their children, making her quite sheltered, but she doesn't mind. She is a swimmer, like her other siblings, and was able to use it to get a scholarship at her school to help her parents.<ref>{{cite web | url=http://entertainment.abs-cbn.com/tv/shows/pbb737/housemates/profile/zonia | title=Zonia Mejia profile | publisher=''[[ABS-CBN]]'' | date=June 20, 2015 | accessdate=June 23, 2015}}</ref> Zonia was nominated for two consecutive times. She was granted immunity with Franco and Jimboy on week 4. She was evicted on Day 42.
===Franco=== <!-- You can be given a warning for vandalism without notice. Once these accumulate, you cannot edit in Wikipedia. --> <!-- Pwede kang mabigyan ng babala ng hindi mo alam. Kapag ito ay naipon, hindi ka na pwedeng makapag-edit sa Wikipedia. --> <!-- PLEASE SEE 'VIEW HISTORY' AT THE RIGHT SIDE OF THE SCREEN TO SEE COMMENTS ABOUT MY EDIT FOR THIS PART Just in case the note gets covered by other edits, I'll post it here anyways. This will be my last edit of Franco's age. Anyone who changes this further will be given a warning for vandalism. Thanks. --> '''Thomas Franco Rodriguez''' (born June 27, 1998) is a 16-year-old from [[Tabaco City]], [[Albay]]. He is popular at school because of his talent in singing and dancing. He is also a flutist for their school's brass band. His siblings are studying in Manila, while he stays in the province with his parents. His mother is a government employee and his father owns a piggery.<ref>{{cite web | url=http://entertainment.abs-cbn.com/tv/shows/pbb737/housemates/profile/franco-rodriguez | title=Franco Rodriguez profile | publisher=''[[ABS-CBN]]'' | date=June 20, 2015 | accessdate=June 23, 2015}}</ref> He was granted immunity with Zonia and Jimboy on week 4. Since his group, the Dream Team, won the majority of votes for ''The Big-Ating Concert.'' He, along with Bailey and Ylona, was granted immunity on week 5. He was nominated on week 6. On Day 49, he became a finalist with 3.78% of the net votes. He exited the House on Day 50. He returned to the House on Day 99. He was placed third during the finale night, and garnered 20.71% of the votes, out of 4. He exited on Day 141.
===Ylona=== <!-- You can be given a warning for vandalism without notice. Once these accumulate, you cannot edit in Wikipedia. --> <!-- Pwede kang mabigyan ng babala ng hindi mo alam. Kapag ito ay naipon, hindi ka na pwedeng makapag-edit sa Wikipedia. --> {{main article|Ylona Garcia}} '''Ylona Jade Navalle Garcia''' (born February 28, 2002) is a 13-year-old from [[Sydney]], [[Australia]]. Both of her parents are practitioners in the medical field, but she has more interest in the performing arts. She had previously performed with [[Martin Nievera]], [[Sarah Geronimo]], and [[Bamboo Mañalac]]. While she is becoming prominent within the Filipino community in Australia, she still has a lot to learn about Filipino culture, especially the Filipino language.<ref>{{cite web | url=http://entertainment.abs-cbn.com/tv/shows/pbb737/housemates/profile/ylona-jade-garcia | title=Ylona Garcia profile | publisher=''[[ABS-CBN]]'' | date=June 20, 2015 | accessdate=June 23, 2015}}</ref> Ylona was first nominated on week 2, and was nominated again for another week, but she survived the public vote. On week 4, she was nominated after failing to win the immunity challenge. She got a chance to be saved by the winning team, but the team chose Bailey. She was saved from eviction after Kyle made a voluntary exit. On Week 5, her group, the Dream Team, won the majority of votes for their performances in The Big-Ating Concert thus, being granted immunity along with Franco and Bailey. She was nominated on week 6. On Day 49, she was named a finalist with 19.84% of the net votes. She exited the House on Day 50. She returned to the House on Day 99. She exited on Day 142, emerging as the runner-up for the teen batch, garnering 43.24% of the votes, out of 2.
==[[Pinoy Big Brother: 737 – Part 2|Regular housemates]]== <!-- You can be given a warning for vandalism without notice. Once these accumulate, you cannot edit in Wikipedia. --> <!-- Pwede kang mabigyan ng babala ng hindi mo alam. Kapag ito ay naipon, hindi ka na pwedeng makapag-edit sa Wikipedia. --> The next set of housemates – regular housemates – were introduced from August 3 to 7.<ref>{{cite web | url=https://twitter.com/PBBabscbn/status/625644312135532544 | title=Regular housemates confirmed | publisher=''[[ABS-CBN]]'' | date=July 27, 2015 | accessdate=July 27, 2015}}</ref> The first six housemates entered the House on Day 50, August 8, 2015. After Jyo's voluntary exit, Philip's subsequent eviction and the eviction of their three housemates as a result of Roger saved from eviction in a two medallion with the latter's one vote (or medallion) after their failed in the ''Ligtask'' challenge, three replacement housemates entered as part of ''Big Yanig'' twist. On Day 77, Tommy entered as Jyo's replacement – while two new housemates entered on Days 80 and 81, respectively. On Day 84, two former housemates were re-entered, which is one of them is a housemate from a previous batch, known as a "cross-over housemate", while the other one is a recently evicted housemate, known as a "wildcard housemate"; however, only one of them returned as an official housemate by public voting.
===Jyo=== <!-- You can be given a warning for vandalism without notice. Once these accumulate, you cannot edit in Wikipedia. --> <!-- Pwede kang mabigyan ng babala ng hindi mo alam. Kapag ito ay naipon, hindi ka na pwedeng makapag-edit sa Wikipedia. --> '''Jyo Yokoyama''' (born November 7, 1993) is a 22-year-old wrecker operator from [[Japan]]. Born in Tokyo and raised in Pampanga, he went back to Japan together with his half-brother and half-sister when he was in high school to live with their mom who works as a factory worker. He was estranged from his father for 13 years until they were recently reunited. He was not able to obtain a college degree and is currently working in a construction company. During his first week of stay, he already mulled exiting the house because he felt he was restrained to do what he is used to do outside, but was advised by Big Brother to stay on. However, Through flipping a coin, Jyo opted for a voluntary exit on Day 75 and left the house on Day 76.<ref>{{cite web|title=Jyo Yokoyama's profile|url=http://entertainment.abs-cbn.com/tv/shows/pbb737/regular/profile/jyo-yokohama|publisher=ABS-CBN|accessdate=6 August 2015}}</ref>
===Roger=== <!-- You can be given a warning for vandalism without notice. Once these accumulate, you cannot edit in Wikipedia. --> <!-- Pwede kang mabigyan ng babala ng hindi mo alam. Kapag ito ay naipon, hindi ka na pwedeng makapag-edit sa Wikipedia. --> '''Roger Lucero''' (born September 26, 1986) is a 29-year-old tour guide from [[Bacolod]]. He lacks a college degree so he became a house helper, until his humor brought him to work for ''The Ruins'' in Talisay City, Negros Occidental, near the City of Bacolod. He is a father of a 3-year-old son.<ref>{{cite web | url=http://entertainment.abs-cbn.com/tv/shows/pbb737/regular/profile/roger-lutero | title=Roger Lucero profile | publisher=''[[ABS-CBN]]'' | date=August 3, 2015 | accessdate=August 4, 2015}}</ref> He was automatically nominated, with Charlhone, Group leader Krizia, and Mikee, due to losing the Food Fight weekly task against Dawn, Margo, Miho, and Then-rival group leader Richard. He, together with his team, went under a group ''Ligtask'' challenge, which they lost. This means only one of them can stay in the House. The safe housemates decided who will stay in the House. Roger was saved with two votes. He was placed third during the finale night, and garnered 9.99% of the votes, out of 4. He exited on Day 141.
===Dawn=== '''Dawn Chang (Erica Aparicio)'''(born January 29, 1989) is a 26-year-old baker from [[Parañaque City]] but is now currently based in Australia. She was born and raised by two mothers, one is her biological mom who is a lesbian while the other is her mother's ex-girlfriend. She recently met her biological father through social media. Currently, she is a part-time dancer and a full-time baker who is busy with her small cakes and cupcake business. She was a former member of the Hotlegs Dance Company.<ref>{{cite news|url=http://www.fhm.com.ph/news/dawn-chang-is-fhms-february-2016-cover-girl-a00028-20160129?ref=home_feed_4#|title=Dawn Chang Is FHM's February 2016 Cover Girl!|publisher=''FHM Philippines''|date=January 29, 2016|accessdate=February 9, 2016}}</ref> She and her Australian boyfriend of two years make their presence felt through their Facebook page ''English Tagalog 101''.<ref>{{cite web|title=Dawn Chang Profile|url=http://entertainment.abs-cbn.com/tv/shows/pbb737/regular/profile/dawn-chang|publisher=ABS-CBN|accessdate=6 August 2015}}</ref> She was placed fourth during the finale night, and garnered 7.79% of the votes, out of 4. She exited on Day 141.
===Charlhone=== <!-- You can be given a warning for vandalism without notice. Once these accumulate, you cannot edit in Wikipedia. --> <!-- Pwede kang mabigyan ng babala ng hindi mo alam. Kapag ito ay naipon, hindi ka na pwedeng makapag-edit sa Wikipedia. --> '''Charlhone Petro''' (born March 23, 1993) is a 22-year-old commercial model from [[Pampanga]]. Born to a Filipina mother and an American father, his parents left him to his mother's friend who maltreated him when he was young. Then he was adopted by a family full of military men who lives in Clark Freeport Zone in [[Angeles City]]. Though he attempted to follow the footsteps of his foster family, he decided to pursue a career in computer technology.<ref>{{cite web|title=Charlhone Petro Profile|url=http://entertainment.abs-cbn.com/tv/shows/pbb737/regular/profile/charlhone-petro|publisher=ABS-CBN|accessdate=8 August 2015}}</ref> He was automatically nominated, with Group leader Krizia, Mikee, and Roger, due to losing the Food Fight weekly task against Dawn, Margo, Miho, and Then-rival group leader Richard. He, together with his team, went under a group ''Ligtask'' challenge, which they lost. This means only one of them can stay in the House. The safe housemates decided who will stay in the House. Charlhone lost to Roger with one vote. He was evicted on Day 79.
===Mikee=== <!-- You can be given a warning for vandalism without notice. Once these accumulate, you cannot edit in Wikipedia. --> <!-- Pwede kang mabigyan ng babala ng hindi mo alam. Kapag ito ay naipon, hindi ka na pwedeng makapag-edit sa Wikipedia. --> '''Mikee Trixia Agustin''' (born August 23, 1993) is a 21-year-old online seller, model and YouTube sensation from [[Bulacan]]. She came from a broken family, witnessing the departure of her father for another woman at an early age. Together with her boyfriend [[Yexel Sebastian]], she releases short films and videos online which then became viral. Their videos have 6 million views now. She currently earns through modelling and her online business.<ref>{{cite web | url=http://entertainment.abs-cbn.com/tv/shows/pbb737/regular/profile/mikee-trixia-agustin | title=Mikee Agustin profile | publisher=''[[ABS-CBN]]'' | date=August 3, 2015 | accessdate=August 4, 2015}}</ref> She was automatically nominated, with Charlhone, Group leader Krizia, and Roger, due to losing the Food Fight weekly task against Dawn, Margo, Miho, and Then-rival group leader Richard. She, together with her team, went under a group ''Ligtask'' challenge, which they lost. This means only one of them can stay in the House. The safe housemates decided who will stay in the House. Mikee lost to Roger with one vote. She was evicted on Day 79, but re-entered the House on Day 84 as a wild card housemate. She, and cross-over challenger Kamille, fight for a chance to be an official housemate again, with her fate to be decided through public voting.<ref>{{cite web|last1=Lastrilla|first1=Gary Ann|title=PBB 737 ex-housemates Mikee and Kamille re-enter Big Brother’s house as Big Yanig challengers|url=http://entertainment.abs-cbn.com/tv/shows/pbb737/show-updates/2015/09/11/9111583-pbb-737-ex-housemates-mikee-and-kamille-re-enter-big-brothers-house-as-big-yanig-challengers|publisher=ABS-CBN|accessdate=12 September 2015}}</ref> She returned as an official housemate on Day 86 after receiving 83.32% of the votes; .she was re-evicted on Day 105 after receiving least number of votes against Jameson, Tommy
===Margo=== <!-- You can be given a warning for vandalism without notice. Once these accumulate, you cannot edit in Wikipedia. --> <!-- Pwede kang mabigyan ng babala ng hindi mo alam. Kapag ito ay naipon, hindi ka na pwedeng makapag-edit sa Wikipedia. --> '''Margo Katherine Midwinter''' (born July 16, 1992) is a 23-year-old Fil-British model and beauty queen from Manila. She was born and raised in the UK but decided to live in the Philippines and try her luck as a model here. She once auditioned for ''Pinoy Big Brother'' when she was 18 but failed since at that time, she could not speak Filipino. She lives with her two dogs, and wishes to become an actress in the Philippines so she can bring her family here.<ref>{{cite web|title=Margo Midwinter's profile|url=http://entertainment.abs-cbn.com/tv/shows/pbb737/regular/profile/margo-katherine-midwinter|publisher=ABS-CBN|accessdate=7 August 2015}}</ref> She joined the ''Kagahandahang Flores'' roster of models and beauty queens, and previously joined Miss Philippines Earth 2011, representing the City of Manila.<ref>{{cite web|title=Margo Midwinter: another KF beauty for Miss World Philippines 2014?|url=http://normannorman.com/2014/07/07/margo-midwinter-another-kf-beauty-for-miss-world-philippines-2014/|publisher=Norman|accessdate=7 August 2015}}</ref> She was nominated three weeks in a row, but evaded all three evictions. She was nominated on week 14 after losing an endurance challenge. She was evicted on Day 98.
===Richard=== <!-- You can be given a warning for vandalism without notice. Once these accumulate, you cannot edit in Wikipedia. --> <!-- Pwede kang mabigyan ng babala ng hindi mo alam. Kapag ito ay naipon, hindi ka na pwedeng makapag-edit sa Wikipedia. --> {{Main article|Richard Hwan}} '''Richard Hwan''' (born August 2, 1992) is a 23-year-old model and events host from [[Parañaque]]. Raised in [[British Hong Kong|Hong Kong]], he has been living in the Philippines for four years now. He understands and speaks basic Filipino. He graduated cum laude at the [[University of the Philippines]], with a degree of Broadcast Communication. He earns money through modelling gigs<ref>{{cite web | url=http://entertainment.abs-cbn.com/tv/shows/pbb737/regular/profile/richard-juan | title=Richard Juan profile | publisher=''[[ABS-CBN]]'' | date=August 3, 2015 | accessdate=August 4, 2015}}</ref> and was a co-host on [[GMA Network]]'s ''[[Eat Bulaga]]'' and several [[GMA News TV]] programs. He was evicted on Day 119.
===Krizia=== <!-- You can be given a warning for vandalism without notice. Once these accumulate, you cannot edit in Wikipedia. --> <!-- Pwede kang mabigyan ng babala ng hindi mo alam. Kapag ito ay naipon, hindi ka na pwedeng makapag-edit sa Wikipedia. --> '''Krizia Alexine Lusuegro''' (born August 14, 1990) is a 25-year-old volunteer nurse from [[Iloilo]]. Her father is a retired Philippine Army and now barangay chairman, and her mother a housewife. She started school at age two and was active in extra-curricular activities. Aside from being a nurse, she is also busy managing a small store, selling sweet corns and barbeque. She was nominated alongside on week 2 with James and Margo, but she won the ligtask challenge and was safe from that week.<ref>{{cite web|title=Krizia Lusuegro Profile|url=http://entertainment.abs-cbn.com/tv/shows/pbb737/regular/profile/krizia-lusuegro|publisher=ABS-CBN|accessdate=8 August 2015}}</ref> She was automatically nominated, with members Charlhone, Mikee, and Roger, due to losing the Food Fight weekly task against Dawn, Margo, Miho, and Then-rival group leader Richard. She, together with her team, went under a group ''Ligtask'' challenge, which they lost. This means only one of them can stay in the House. The safe housemates decided who will stay in the House. Krizia lost to Roger with one vote. She was evicted on Day 79.
===Jessica=== <!-- You can be given a warning for vandalism without notice. Once these accumulate, you cannot edit in Wikipedia. --> <!-- Pwede kang mabigyan ng babala ng hindi mo alam. Kapag ito ay naipon, hindi ka na pwedeng makapag-edit sa Wikipedia. --> '''[[Jessica Marasigan]]''' (born January 7, 1994) is a 21-year-old model and beauty queen from [[Los Angeles, California]]. She was born and raised in the [[United States|US]], but she grew up being taught Filipino and Catholic values and exposed to Filipino food. She is the second sibling and only girl in the family.<ref>{{cite web|title=Jessica Marasigan Profile|url=http://entertainment.abs-cbn.com/tv/shows/pbb737/regular/profile/jessica-marasigan|publisher=ABS-CBN|accessdate=6 August 2015}}</ref> Prior to entering, she also joined several beauty pageants back in the US. She was crowned first runner-up in Miss Philippines-USA in 2012 and a year later joined Binibining Pilipinas-USA.<ref>{{cite web|last1=Eduvas|first1=Ron Jay|title=Meet Pinoy Big Brother 737's Newest Beauty, Jessica Marasigan!|url=http://www.fhm.com.ph/daily-reads/news/newest-pbb-beauty-jessica-marasigan|website=FHM|publisher=FHM|accessdate=6 August 2015}}</ref> She was nominated on the first week but after hearing the news of her grandmother's death, she opted for a voluntary exit on Day 58 to be with her family.
===James=== <!-- You can be given a warning for vandalism without notice. Once these accumulate, you cannot edit in Wikipedia. --> <!-- Pwede kang mabigyan ng babala ng hindi mo alam. Kapag ito ay naipon, hindi ka na pwedeng makapag-edit sa Wikipedia. --> '''James Linao''' (born January 25, 1985) is a 30-year-old overseas Filipino worker who hails from [[Surigao del Sur]]. He has worked in different countries for four years, and through this, he was able to fulfill his dream of working abroad and provide for the family. He hopes that his stint in the House will allow him to seek justice for his father, a former media man and politician who was murdered in 2009. He was nominated on week 10, with Margo. He was evicted on Day 70.<ref>{{cite web|title=James Linao's profile|url=http://entertainment.abs-cbn.com/tv/shows/pbb737/regular/profile/james-linao|publisher=ABS-CBN|accessdate=6 August 2015}}</ref>
===Miho=== <!-- You can be given a warning for vandalism without notice. Once these accumulate, you cannot edit in Wikipedia. Miho's birthyear is 1992 and she even told it during one of the aired episodes --> <!-- Pwede kang mabigyan ng babala ng hindi mo alam. Kapag ito ay naipon, hindi ka na pwedeng makapag-edit sa Wikipedia. --> {{main article|Miho Nishida}} '''Miho Lalic Nishida''' (born December 16, 1992) is a 22-year old guest relations staff from [[Japan]]. She was born in [[Angono, Rizal]] but her mom, who worked as an entertainer, brought her to [[Tokyo, Japan|Tokyo]] when she was two years old and singlehandedly raised her there. Having been exposed to Nihonggo for most of her life, she only understands and speaks a little Tagalog. She used to be a party-goer who preferred drinking and partying over going to school. Like her mother, she is a single mom and has a five-year-old daughter.<ref>{{cite web|title=Miho Nishida's profile|url=http://entertainment.abs-cbn.com/tv/shows/pbb737/regular/profile/miho-nishida|publisher=ABS-CBN|accessdate=6 August 2015}}</ref> She exited on Day 141, emerging as the winner for the regular batch, garnering 81.92% of the votes, out of 2, making her the winner with the highest percentage to date. [[Pinoy Big Brother (season 1)|Season 1]] winner Nene Tamayo previously held the highest winning percentage with 48.9%.
===Philip=== <!-- You can be given a warning for vandalism without notice. Once these accumulate, you cannot edit in Wikipedia. --> <!-- Pwede kang mabigyan ng babala ng hindi mo alam. Kapag ito ay naipon, hindi ka na pwedeng makapag-edit sa Wikipedia. --> '''Philip Lampart''' (born November 28, 1993) is a 21-year old Fil-Swiss construction worker from [[Australia]]. Born in [[Malay, Aklan|Caticlan]], his family, together with his mother and three brothers, migrated to Australia when he was 10. He has a 1-year-old son with his girlfriend.<ref>{{cite web|title=Fil-Brit model at batang ama, bagong housemates ni Kuya|url=http://entertainment.abs-cbn.com/tv/shows/pbb737/regular/profile/philip-lampart|publisher=ABS-CBN|accessdate=7 August 2015}}</ref> Currently, he works as a laborer in a construction company. He was evicted on Day 77.<ref>{{cite web|title=Philip Lampart Profile|url=http://entertainment.abs-cbn.com/tv/shows/pbb737/regular/profile/philip-lampart|publisher=ABS-CBN|accessdate=8 August 2015}}</ref>
===Tommy=== <!-- You can be given a warning for vandalism without notice. Once these accumulate, you cannot edit in Wikipedia. --> <!-- Pwede kang mabigyan ng babala ng hindi mo alam. Kapag ito ay naipon, hindi ka na pwedeng makapag-edit sa Wikipedia. -->
'''Tommy Sarte Esguerra''' (born June 5, 1994) is a 21-year-old Filipino-American model from [[Las Piñas]]. He was born and raised in Long Beach, California, to a Filipino family and was taught Filipino values. He went to the Philippines, initially, for a modelling television show, but it turned out to be a scam. Still, he tried his luck and has done several modelling gigs in the past.<ref>{{cite web|title=Tommy Esguerra Profile|url=http://entertainment.abs-cbn.com/tv/shows/pbb737/regular/profile/tommy-esguerra|publisher=ABS-CBN|accessdate=15 September 2015}}</ref> He is Jyo's replacement and he entered the house on Day 77 as part of ''Big Yanig'' twist. He exited on Day 141, emerging as the runner-up for the regular batch, garnering 18.08% of the votes, out of 2.
===Zeus=== <!-- You can be given a warning for vandalism without notice. Once these accumulate, you cannot edit in Wikipedia. --> <!-- Pwede kang mabigyan ng babala ng hindi mo alam. Kapag ito ay naipon, hindi ka na pwedeng makapag-edit sa Wikipedia. Zeus' real surname is Arellano --> '''Zeus Collins Arellano''', also known as '''Zeus Collins''', (born March 19, 1983) is a 35-year-old dancer and commercial model from [[Rizal (province)|Rizal]]. He was taught dancing by his mother, a seamstress. His father was an electrician. His parents' income was not enough for Zeus to stay in school, so he started working early to help them.<ref>{{cite web|title=Zeus Collins profile|url=http://entertainment.abs-cbn.com/tv/shows/pbb737/regular/profile/jameson-blake|publisher=ABS-CBNnews.com|accessdate=15 September 2015}}</ref> He entered on Day 80, after Charlhone, Krizia, and Mikee were evicted as part of the ''Big Yanig'' twist. He was the last evictee of the season; he exited on Day 133.
===Jameson=== {{main article|Jameson Blake}} '''Jameson Blake''' (born June 17, 1997) is an 18-year-old Filipino-American commercial model from Pampanga. He grew up in Hong Kong and only came to the Philippines when he was 10 years old. He does commercial modelling to help defray the medication expenses of his father who has a heart ailment as well as paying for the education of his younger sister. He sells ube halaya to his classmates and uses the profit as his allowance.<ref>{{cite web|title=Kapampangan teen joins 'PBB 737'|url=http://www.abs-cbnnews.com/entertainment/09/09/15/kapampangan-teen-joins-pbb-737|publisher=ABS-CBNnews.com|accessdate=9 September 2015}}</ref><ref>{{cite web|title=Jameson Blake profile|url=http://entertainment.abs-cbn.com/tv/shows/pbb737/regular/profile/jameson-blake|publisher=ABS-CBN|accessdate=15 September 2015}}</ref> He entered the house on Day 81 as part of the ''Big Yanig'' twist. He was evicted on Day 112.
