revision.text:
A Lithuanian personal name, like in mostly [[Europe]]an cultures, consists of two main elements: the [[given name]] (''vardas'') followed by [[family name]] (''pavardė''). The usage of [[personal name]]s in [[Lithuania]] is generally governed (in addition to personal taste or family custom) by three major factors: [[civil law (legal system)|civil law]], [[canon law]], and tradition. Lithuanian names always follow the rules of the [[Lithuanian language]]. Lithuanian male names, as well as the rest of words, have preserved the [[Indo-European languages|Indo-European]] masculine endings (''-as''; ''-is''), although the rules are not as rigid as [[Latvian name]]s, which preserve masculine/feminine endings even for foreign names.
== ''Vardas'' (given name) == A child in Lithuania is usually given one or two given names. Nowadays the second given name is rarely used in everyday situations, the use of a [[middle name]] being considered pretentious. In addition to modern names, parents normally choose a name or names for their child from a long list of traditional names which may be:
* a [[Lithuanian language|Lithuanian]] name of pre-Christian origin.
It is the most ancient layer of Lithuanian personal names; a majority of them are dual-[[word stem|stemmed]] personal names, of [[Proto-Indo-European language|Indo-European]] origin. These ancient Lithuanian names are constructed from two interconnected [[Word stem|stem]]s, the combination of which has been used to denote certain beneficial personal qualities, for example ''Jo-gaila'' mean "a strong rider". Although virtually extinct following the [[Christianization of Lithuania]], they continued to exist as [[surnames]], such as [[Goštautas]], [[Kęsgaila]], [[Radvila]] or in their Slavicised versions, as well as in [[toponym]]s.<ref>Notably, [[Gelgaudiškis]] from ''Gedgaudas'', [[Radviliškis]] from ''Radvila'', [[Buivydiškės]] from ''Butvydas'', etc.</ref> The existing surnames and written sources have allowed the reconstruction of names by linguists, such as [[Kazimieras Būga]]. During the [[Interbellum]] these names returned to popular use after a long period of neglect. Children are often named in honor of the most revered historical Lithuanian rulers, making their names one of the most popular. They include [[Vytautas]], [[Gediminas]], [[Algirdas]], [[Sigismund Kęstutaitis|Žygimantas]]. In line with the double-stemmed names, shorter variants containing only one stem were also used, such as [[Vytenis]] and [[Kęstutis]]. Since there are few pre-Christian female names attested in written sources, they are often reconstructed from male variants, in addition to the historical [[Birutė]], [[Aldona of Lithuania|Aldona]], [[Rimgailė]] etc.
* a [[Christian name]], i.e., a [[List of Biblical names|Biblical name]] or a [[saint's name]].
The use of Christian names in the Lithuanian language long predates the adoption of Christianity by Lithuanians. The linguistic data attest that first Biblical names were started to be used in [[Aukštaitija]] as early as in the 11th century. The earliest strata of such names originates from [[Old Church Slavonic]]; they were borrowed by [[Eastern Orthodoxy]] in their [[Byzantine]] versions. The examples of such names are ''Antanas'' ([[Anthony the Great|St. Anthony]]), ''Povilas'' or ''Paulius'' ([[Paul the Apostle|St. Paul]]), ''Andrius'' ([[St. Andrew]]) and ''Jurgis'' ([[St. George]]). The later influx of Christian names came after the adoption of Christianity in 1387. They are mostly borrowed in their [[Polish language|Polish]] versions: ''Jonas'' ([[John the Apostle|St. John]]), ''Vladislovas''/''Vladas'' ([[St. Ladislaus]]), ''Kazimieras''/''Kazys'' ([[St. Casimir]]), etc.
* a [[Lithuanian language|Lithuanian]] [[common noun]] or [[hydronym]] used as a name.
There are popular names constructed from the words for celestial bodies (''Saulė'' for the [[Sun]], ''Aušrinė'' for [[Venus]]), events of nature (''Audra'' for the storm, ''Aušra'' for the [[dawn]], ''Rasa'' for the [[dew]], ''Vėjas'' for the wind, ''Aidas'' for the [[Echo (phenomenon)|echo]]), plants (''[[Linas]]''/''Lina'' for [[flax]], ''Eglė'' for [[spruce]]), river names (''Ūla'', ''Vilija'' for [[River Neris]]).
* an invented name from literature.
Some names were created by the authors of literal works and spread in public use through them. Such names were invented following the rules of the Lithuanian language; therefore it is sometimes difficult to tell whether the name is fictitious and had never existed before. Notably, ''Gražina'', ''Živilė'' by [[Adam Mickiewicz]], ''Daiva'' by [[Vydūnas]], ''Šarūnas'' by [[Vincas Krėvė]] and others.
* names of Lithuanian pagan deities and mythological figures.
There are some popular names of gods and goddesses from [[Lithuanian mythology]] that are used as personal names, such as ''[[Laima]]'', goddess of luck, ''[[Žemyna]]'', goddess of earth, ''[[Gabija]]'', goddess of fire; ''Žilvinas'', a serpent prince from the fairy tale ''[[Eglė the Queen of Serpents]]'', ''Jūratė'', goddess of the sea, and ''Kastytis'', from the legend about ''[[Jūratė and Kastytis]]''.
A distinctive practice dominated in the [[Regions of Lithuania|ethnic region]] of [[Lithuania Minor]], then being a part of [[East Prussia]], where Lithuanized [[German name|German personal names]] were common, such as ''Ansas'' ([[Hans (name)|Hans]]), ''Grėtė'' ([[Gretchen]]), ''Vilius'' ([[Wilhelm (name)|Wilhelm]]) among [[Prussian Lithuanians]]. Some of them are still in use among Lithuanians at present.
The choice of a given name is largely influenced by fashion. Many parents may name their child after a [[Folk hero|national hero]] or heroine, some otherwise famous person, or a character from a book, film, or [[TV show]]. In spite of this, a great number of names used in today's Lithuania have been in use since the ancient times.
===Sex differentiation===
Lithuanian male and female names are different grammatically. Almost all Lithuanian female names end in the vowels ''-a'' or ''-[[ė]]'', while male names almost always end in ''-s'', and rarely in a vowel ''-a''. When the male name ending in ''-a'' has its female counterpart, it ends in ''-ė'', such as ''[[Jogaila]]'' and ''Jogailė''. Female double-stemmed Lithuanian names always end in ''-ė''.
===Diminutives===
[[Diminutive]]s are very popular in everyday usage, and are by no means reserved for children. The [[Lithuanian language]] allows for a great deal of creativity in this field. Most diminutives are formed by adding a [[suffix]]. For female names it may be ''-elė'', ''-utė'', ''-ytė'', ''-užė''; certain suffixes are more common to specific names over the rest.
Also, as in many other cultures, a person may informally use a [[nickname]] (''pravardė'') in addition to or instead of a given name.
== ''Pavardė'' (surname) == Lithuanian surnames, like those in most of Europe, are hereditary and generally [[Patrilineality|patrilineal]], i.e., passed from the father on to his children.
A married woman usually adopts her husband's name. However, other combinations are legally possible. The wife may keep her [[maiden name]] (''mergautinė pavardė'') or add her husband's surname to hers, thus creating a [[double-barrelled name]]. It is also possible, though rare, for the husband to adopt his wife's surname or to add his wife's surname to his family name.
=== History ===
Family names first appeared in Lithuania ca. end of 14th century beginning 15th century<ref name='Schmalstieg'>{{cite journal|title=Lithuanian names|journal=[[Lituanus]]|year=1982|first=William R.|last=Schmalstieg|volume=28|issue=3|url=http://www.lituanus.org/1982_3/82_3_01.htm|accessdate=2007-09-06 }}</ref> and were only reserved to the [[Lithuanian nobility]]. They usually derived from [[patronymic]]s.
The most striking peculiarity of the historical Lithuanian heraldic system, which is adopted from the Polish one in the [[Union of Horodlo]] in 1413, is that '''a coat of arms does not belong to a single family'''. A number of unrelated families (sometimes hundreds of them), usually with a number of different family names, may use a coat of arms, '''and each coat of arms has its own name'''.
The use of family names gradually spread to other social groups: the [[townsfolk]] by the end of the 17th century, then the [[peasantry]]. People from the villages did not have last names until the end of the 18th century. In cases like this their village of origin was usually noted in documents. The process ended only in the mid-19th century, and due partial [[Polonization]] of society at the time many names were influenced by Polish form of the name.<ref name='Schmalstieg'/>
===Classification===
Based on origin, several groups of Lithuanian family names may be recognized.
==== Cognominal ==== A [[cognominal surname]] derives from a person's nickname, usually based a physical or character trait.
Examples: * Naujokas, Naujokaitis – from ''naujas'' ("new one") * Kairys, Kairelis, – "[[leftie]]", from ''kairė'' ("left side")
====Occupational==== Examples of [[occupational surname]]s: * Kalvis, Kalvelis, Kalvaitis – from ''kalvis'' ("[[blacksmith]]")
==== Toponymic ==== A [[toponymic surname]] usually derives from the name of a village or town, or the name of a topographic feature.
Examples: * Užugiris – from across the forest (''už girios''); * Kalnietis – from the mountains (''kalnai'').
==== Patronymic ==== A [[patronymic surname]] derives from a given name of a person and usually ends in a suffix suggesting a family relation.
Examples: * Jonaitis, Janavičius, Januitis – derived from ''Jonas'' ([[John (name)|John]]); * Adomaitis, Adamonis, Adamkus – derived from ''Adomas'' ([[Adam (name)|Adam]]); * Lukauskis, Lukša, Lukošius, Lukoševičius – derived from ''Lukas'' ([[Luke (name)|Luke]]).
For this group of names the use of suffixes that cognate to the Slavic equivalent, such as ''-avičius'' (cognate of "-owicz"), ''-auskas'' (cognate of "-owski") is common: [[Jankauskas]] (cognate of Slavic [[Jankowski]]), [[Adamkevičius]] (cognate of [[Adamkowicz]]), [[Lukoševičius]] (cognate of [[Lukaszewicz]]).
====Diminutives==== A number of surnames are [[diminutive]]s of popular first names.<ref>American surnames, by Elsdon Coles Smith, 1986, {{ISBN|0806311509}}, [https://books.google.com/books?id=OfHBWBK1wQQC&pg=PA83&dq=%22lithuanian+surnames%22&lr=#v=onepage&q=%22lithuanian%20surnames%22&f=false p. 83]</ref> *[[Butkus]] from Butkintas *[[Minkus]] from Minkantas *[[Norkus]] from Norkantas *[[Rimkus]] from Rimkantas
=== Feminine forms === Lithuanian surnames have specific [[Grammatical gender|masculine and feminine]] forms. While a masculine surname usually ends in ''-as'', ''-ys'' or ''-is'', its feminine equivalent ends in ''-ienė'' or rarely ''-uvienė'' for married women and ''-aitė'', ''-utė'', ''-iūtė'' or ''-ytė'' for unmarried ones. Examples: {| class="wikitable sortable" ! Father / husband ! Married woman or widow ! Unmarried woman |- | Paulauskas | Paulauskienė | Paulauskaitė |- | Bimbirys | Bimbirienė | Bimbirytė |- | Adamkus | Adamkienė | Adamkutė |- | Mielkus | Mielkienė/Mielkuvienė | Mielkutė |- | Kulėšius | Kulėšienė | Kulėšiūtė |}
In 2003, Lithuanian laws allowed women to use a short form, without disclosing the marital status (ending in -ė instead of -ienė/-aitė/etc.: Adamkus –> Adamkė)<ref>{{Cite web|url=https://e-seimas.lrs.lt/portal/legalAct/lt/TAD/TAIS.214783|title=N-2(87) Dėl moterų pavardžių darymo|website=e-seimas.lrs.lt|access-date=2018-11-07}}</ref>. These names are used, although traditional forms are still predominant.<ref name="veidas">[http://www.veidas.lt/lt/leidinys.full/47c94b0032aff Naujoviškos pavardės tradicinių neišstūmė. Veidas magazine, 2008/9] {{webarchive|url=https://web.archive.org/web/20080305202828/http://www.veidas.lt/lt/leidinys.full/47c94b0032aff |date=2008-03-05 }}</ref> According to the [[Department of Statistics of Lithuania]], the most popular feminine family names are:<ref name="veidas"/> # Kazlauskienė # Jankauskienė # Petrauskienė # Stankevičienė # Paulauskienė
== Formal and informal use == Lithuanians pay great attention to the correct way of referring to or addressing other people depending on the level of social distance, familiarity and politeness. The differences between formal and informal language include: * using surnames vs. given names; * using vs. not using honorific titles such as ''Ponas'' / ''Ponia''; * using the third person singular forms vs. second person singular; * using second-person singular personal pronoun vs. second-person plural personal pronoun to address a single person.
=== Formal language ===
==== Ponas/Ponia ==== ''Ponas'' and ''Ponia'' ([[vocative case]] ''Pone'', ''Ponia'') are the basic honorific styles used in Lithuanian to refer to a man or woman, respectively. In the past, these styles were reserved to members of the ''[[szlachta]]'' and played more or less the same roles as "Lord" or "Sir" and "Lady" or "Madam" in English. Since the 19th century, they have come to be used in all strata of society and may be considered equivalent to the English "Mr." and "Ms." There is a separate style, ''Panelė'' ("Miss"), applied to an unmarried woman.
==== Given name/surname order ==== The given name(s) normally comes before the surname. However, in a list of people sorted alphabetically by surname, the surname usually comes first. In many formal situations the given name is omitted altogether.
=== Informal language === Informal forms of address are normally used only by relatives, close friends and co-workers. In such situations diminutives are often preferred to the standard forms of given names.
==See also== * [[Name of Lithuania]] * [[Lithuanian nobility]] * [[Onomastics]]
==Footnotes== {{reflist|2}}
==Further reading==
* Jūratė Čirūnaitė, "Lietuvos totorių pavardžių formavimasis XV–XVII a." (The Formation Of Tatar Naming Practices in Lithuania in the 15th–17th centuries), ''Baltistica,'' vol. 36, no. 2 (198) pp. 299–306. * Alfred Senn, "Lithuanian Surnames," ''American Slavic and East European Review,'' vol. 4, no. 1/2 (Aug. 1945), pp. 127–137. [https://www.jstor.org/stable/info/2491865 in JSTOR]

revision.text:
{{Third-party|date=June 2012}} [[File:MarianaMontes1.jpg|thumb|Mariana Montes]] '''Mariana Montes''' (born on Monday, 5 March 1979, [[Buenos Aires]], [[Argentina]]) is an Argentine [[Argentine tango|tango]] dancer and teacher.
Since 1998, she has been pairing with [[Sebastián Arce]] and have travelled the world teaching and performing. As of 2011, they have visited more than 140 cities in 35 countries. Along with Sebastián, they created a dance performance ''Piazzoleando'' they choreographed and danced in the dance performance ''Exodo Tangueado''. She also appeared in the 2010 documentary [[Ad occhi chiusi]] by [[Simonetta Rossi]].
She lives in [[Cagliari]] where she teaches tango in regular classes.
==External links== *[http://www.tangomeet.com Tangomeet.com] - online tango school
{{DEFAULTSORT:Montes.'Mariana}} [[Category:1979 births]] [[Category:Argentine female dancers]] [[Category:Tango dancers]] [[Category:Living people]]
{{dance-bio-stub}}

{{BLP sources|date=February 2015}}
{{Use dmy dates|date=December 2013}} {{Infobox musical artist | name = Michael Hoenig | image = | caption = | image_size = | background = non_vocal_instrumentalist | alias = | birth_date = {{birth date and age|df=y|1952|1|4}} | birth_place = [[Hamburg]], [[West Germany]] | instrument = [[Synthesizer]] | genre = [[Electronic music|Electronic]] | occupation = Musician, songwriter | years_active = 1971–present | label = [[Warner Bros. Records]] | associated_acts = [[Tangerine Dream]], [[Agitation Free]] | website = }} '''Michael Hoenig''' (born 4 January 1952) is a [[Germans|German]] composer who has composed music for several films and games, in addition to two solo albums, including the highly acclaimed 1978 album ''[[Departure from the Northern Wasteland]]''. In 1997, he was nominated for a [[Primetime Emmy Award for Outstanding Main Title Theme Music]] for composing the theme to the [[science fiction]] series ''[[Dark Skies]]''.<ref>{{cite web |url=http://www.emmys.com/shows/dark-skies |title=Dark Skies |publisher=[[Emmy Award|Emmys.com]] |accessdate=February 8, 2015}}</ref>
==Early career== As the editor of the underground magazine ''LOVE'' in the late sixties, Hoenig was part of the burgeoning progressive rock scene in Berlin, which fostered bands like [[Tangerine Dream]], [[Ash Ra Tempel]] and [[Agitation Free]]. His interest in [[avant-garde]] music, [[sound generator]]s and prepared tapes caught the eye of Michael Guenther, the bassist of [[Agitation Free]], and he joined the band in February 1971. In March 1975, Hoenig was hired to replace [[Peter Baumann]] in Tangerine Dream for an Australian tour and a London [[Royal Albert Hall]] concert, and subsequently left Agitation Free, which broke up shortly after. Baumann rejoined Tangerine Dream soon after, and Hoenig went on to collaborate with [[Klaus Schulze]] on the short-lived project, [[Timewind]]. In 1976 he had a brief collaboration with Manuel Göttsching of Ash Ra Tempel; a recording of one of the sessions was released in 1995 under the title "Early Water". In 1977, he released his first solo album, the highly acclaimed [[Berlin School of electronic music|Berlin School]] classic ''[[Departure from the Northern Wasteland]]'', and left for [[Los Angeles]] shortly after it was released.<ref>{{cite web |url=http://www.allmusic.com/album/departure-from-the-northern-wasteland-mw0000194408 |title=Departure from the Northern Wasteland – Michael Hoenig |work=[[AllMusic]] |publisher=[[Rovi Corporation]] |accessdate=February 8, 2015}}</ref>
==Later career== Hoenig owns a recording studio in Los Angeles and through his company Metamusic Productions, he has composed the scores for several movies (see filmography below) and television shows. In addition to this, he has composed music for the extremely popular [[Baldur's Gate series|Baldur's Gate]] PC games by [[BioWare]]. In 1987, Hoenig released his second solo album, [[Xcept One]]. The track Bones on the Beach from the Xcept One album was installed in the roller coaster CHAOS at [[Opryland USA|Opryland]] in [[Nashville]], making the attraction the first roller coaster to be synced to music. Bones on the Beach has also been used at a similar roller coaster, [[Revolution (Bobbejaanland)|Revolution]], at [[Bobbejaanland]], a family park in [[Lichtaart]], [[Belgium]] from 2004-2008 and since 2011.
==Discography==
===Albums=== *''[[Departure from the Northern Wasteland]]'' (1978) *''[[Xcept One]]'' (1987) *''[[The Blob (1988 film)|The Blob]]'' soundtrack (1988) *''[[Dark Skies]]'' score (1997)
===with Tangerine Dream=== *''Bootleg Box Set Vol. 1'' (2003)
===with Manuel Göttsching=== *''Early Water'' (1997)
===Producer=== *''[[Lovely Thunder]]'' – [[Harold Budd]] (1986)
==Filmography==
===Films=== *''[[Dracula 3000]]'' (2004) *''Contaminated Man'' (2000) *''[[After Alice]]'' (1999) *''[[Her Costly Affair]]'' (1996) *''[[Thrill (film)|Thrill]]'' (1996) *''[[Above Suspicion (1995 film)|Above Suspicion]]'' (1995) *''Terminal Justice'' (1995) *''Search for Grace'' (1994) *''[[Eyes of Terror]]'' (1994) *''[[Visions of Murder]]'' (1993) *''[[The Amy Fisher Story]]'' (1993) *''[[The Last of the Finest]]'' (1990) *''[[Class of 1999]]'' (1990) *''[[I, Madman]]'' (1989) *''[[The Blob (1988 film)|The Blob]]'' (1988) *''[[The Gate (1987 film)|The Gate]]'' (1987) *''[[Shattered Spirits]]'' (1987) *''[[The Wraith]]'' (1987) *''[[9½ Weeks]]'' (1986 – additional music) *''[[Silent Witness]]'' (1985) *''[[Night Patrol]]'' (1984) *''Deadly Encounter'' (1982) *''[[Koyaanisqatsi]]'' (1982 – additional music)
===Television series=== *''[[The District]]'' (2000–2004) *''[[Strange World]]'' (1999) *''[[Dark Skies]] (1996–1997) *''[[Max Headroom (TV series)|Max Headroom]]'' (1987–88)
===Games=== *''[[Baldur's Gate]]'' (1998) *''[[Baldur's Gate: Tales of the Sword Coast]]'' (1999) *''[[Baldur's Gate II: Shadows of Amn]]'' (2000)
==References== {{reflist}}
==External links== *{{IMDb name|id=0006129|name=Michael Hoenig}} *[http://www.ocremix.org/artist/419/michael-hoenig Artist profile] at [[OverClocked ReMix]] * {{Allmusic|class=artist|id=mn0000466206}} *[http://www.audionautas.com/2011/09/michael-hoenig-departure-from-northern.html Departure From The Northern Wasteland review (in Spanish)]

revision.text:
{{BLP sources|date=April 2017}} {{EngvarB|date=August 2014}} {{Use dmy dates|date=August 2014}} {{Infobox person | name = Mimi Coertse | birth_name = Maria Sophia Coertse | image = Mimi Coertse Wien.JPG | caption = Mimi Coertse in Vienna | birth_date = {{Birth date|df=yes|1932|06|12}} | birth_place = Durban, South Africa | nationality = South African | death_date = | death_place = | death_cause = | years_active = | occupation = Opera singer (Soprano) | spouse = Dawid Engela (1953-57)
Diego Brighi (1965-69)
Werner Ackerman (1970-1994) | children = 2 | signature = }} '''Mimi Coertse''' (born 12 June 1932) is a South African [[soprano]]. ==Early life== Coertse, born in [[Durban]], matriculated at the [[Helpmekaar Kollege|Helpmekaar Girls High School]] in [[Johannesburg]].{{rp|5}} She began vocal studies in South Africa in 1949.H. Rosenthal and J. Warrack, ''Concise Oxford Dictionary of Opera'' (OUP, London 1974 printing). Her first vocal coach in Johannesburg was Aimee Parkerson.{{cite news|url=http://www.iol.co.za/entertainment/celebrity-news/international/onse-mimi-coertse---a-formidable-woman-1317038|title=‘Onse’ Mimi Coertse - a formidable woman|work=IOL|date=12 June 2012|accessdate=6 August 2017|author=de Beer, Diane}} Her debut performance in South Africa was singing Handel's ''[[Messiah (Handel)|Messiah]]'' at the [[Johannesburg City Hall]] on 11 December 1951. In July 1953 she married broadcaster and composer [[Dawid Engela]].{{rp|5}} She left South Africa in September 1953 for London, and then went via [[The Hague]] to [[Vienna]]. In January 1954 she started training with Maria Hittorff and [[Josef Witt]]. ==Opera career== {{BLP sources section|date=April 2017}} Coertse made her debut in January 1955 as the "first flower girl" in [[Richard Wagner|Wagner]]'s ''[[Parsifal]]'' at the [[Teatro San Carlo]] in [[Naples]], [[Karl Böhm]] conducting. She also sang in [[Basle]] at the Teatro San Carlo. On 17 March 1956 she made her debut at the [[Vienna State Opera]] as the Queen of the Night in ''[[Die Zauberflöte]]'' by [[Wolfgang Amadeus Mozart|Mozart]] and remained with the Vienna State Opera until 1978. Her [[Royal Opera House|Covent Garden]] debut was in 1956, in the same role. Her roles were limited in the United Kingdom as the [[Equity (trade union)|Equity]] boycott of South Africa due to [[Apartheid]], prevented its members from having anything to do with South Africa's entertainment industry. [[File:Mimi Coertse Johannesburg.JPG|thumb|180px|Mimi Coertse in Johannesburg, next to a sculpture depicting her]] [[File:Mimi Coertse - 1959 (1).jpg|thumb|Mimi Coertse in die rolprent Nooi van my hart.]] Coertse sang the soprano part in [[Johann Sebastian Bach|Bach]]'s ''[[Matthäus-Passion]]'' at [[Fritz Wunderlich]]'s first appearance in Vienna in 1958, when he performed the tenor arias with [[Julius Patzak]] singing the [[Four Evangelists|Evangelist]]. In 1958, Coertse and Fritz Wunderlich again worked together at the [[Aix-en-Provence]] festival in ''Die Zauberflöte''.{{cn|date=March 2018}} In 1965, she sang Konstanze in ''[[Die Entführung aus dem Serail]]'' at the Vienna State Opera which also featured Fritz Wunderlich as Belmonte. In 1966, Mimi was honoured by the President of Austria with the title ''Österreichischer Kammersänger'', for her ten years of work as a permanent member at the Vienna State Opera.{{rp|5}} Her repertoire also includes: * ''[[Zauberflöte|The Magic Flute]]'' ([[Wolfgang Amadeus Mozart]]) – Queen of the night * ''[[Die Entführung aus dem Serail|Il Seraglio]]'' ([[Wolfgang Amadeus Mozart]]) – Constance * ''[[Ariadne auf Naxos]]'' ([[Richard Strauss]]) – Najade, later Zerbinetta * ''[[Rigoletto (opera)|Rigoletto]]'' ([[Giuseppe Verdi]]) – Gilda * ''[[Les contes d'Hoffmann|The Tales of Hoffmann]]'' ([[Jacques Offenbach]]) – Olympia, Antonia, Giulietta, Stella * ''[[Palestrina (opera)|Palestrina]]'' ([[Hans Pfitzner]]) – the Angel * ''[[Carmen]]'' ([[Georges Bizet]]) – Frasquita * ''[[Martha (opera)|Martha]]'' ([[Friedrich von Flotow]]) – Martha * ''[[Mignon]]'' ([[Ambroise Thomas]]) – Philine * ''[[La traviata]]'' ([[Giuseppe Verdi]]) – Violetta * ''[[I Pagliacci]]'' ([[Ruggiero Leoncavallo]]) – Nedda * ''[[Arabella]]'' ([[Richard Strauss]]) – Fiaker-Milli * ''[[Bastien und Bastienne]]'' ([[Wolfgang Amadeus Mozart]]) – Bastienne * ''[[The Merry Widow]]'' ([[Franz Lehár]]) – Hanna Glawari * ''[[Lucia di Lammermoor]]'' ([[Gaetano Donizetti]]) – Lucia * ''[[Die Fledermaus]]'' ([[Johann Strauss II]]) – Rosalinde * ''[[L'heure espagnole]]'' ([[Maurice Ravel]]) – Concepcion, staging [[Otto Schenk]] * ''[[Don Giovanni]]'' ([[Wolfgang Amadeus Mozart]]) – Donna Elvira * ''[[La bohème]]'' ([[Giacomo Puccini]]) – Musetta * ''[[Norma (opera)|Norma]]'' ([[Vincenzo Bellini]]) – Norma * ''[[Così fan tutte]]'' ([[Wolfgang Amadeus Mozart]]) – Fiordiligi * ''[[Falstaff (opera)|Falstaff]]'' ([[Giuseppe Verdi]]) – Mrs. Alice Ford * ''[[Turandot]]'' ([[Giacomo Puccini]]) – Liu, a young slave * ''[[Don Giovanni]]'' ([[Wolfgang Amadeus Mozart]]) – Donna Anna * ''[[Die schweigsame Frau]]'' ([[Richard Strauss]]) – Aminta, Timida 1968 Premiere Vienna State Opera, staging [[Hans Hotter]] * ''[[Die ägyptische Helena]]'' ([[Richard Strauss]]) – Aithra * ''[[Daphne (opera)|Daphne]]'' ([[Richard Strauss]]) – Daphne * ''[[Don Carlos]]'' ([[Giuseppe Verdi]]) – Elisabeth von Valois ==Later years== {{moresources|section|date=March 2018}} Since returning to South Africa in 1973 she has been a regular guest on South African stages and also a frequent broadcaster on radio and television. She remained contracted to the Vienna State Opera until 1978. In recent years she has devoted her time to exposing young South African singers to the neglected art of [[Lieder]] singing which can be artistically even more demanding than opera singing. Her support for her fellow South African musicians has been outstanding – as may be witnessed in her ''Debut with Mimi'' and through the ''Mimi Coertse Bursary''. In 1996, Austria's Federal Ministry for Science and Art awarded her the [[Austrian Decoration for Science and Art]] (Austrian Honour, first class) honour, the highest honour an artist can receive in that country. In 1998, she received an honorary doctorate from the [[University of Pretoria]] and another in 2013 from the [[University of South Africa|Unisa]]. In 2002 she would receive the Golden Rathausmann from the mayor of Vienna. In 1998, Coertse and Neels Hansen founded ''The Black Tie Ensemble'', a development project which enables young, classically trained singers to bridge the gap between training and professional performance.{{cite news|url=http://www.iol.co.za/entertainment/music/opera-in-limbo-facing-reality-of-funds-1748042|title=Opera in limbo, facing reality of funds|work=IOL|date=9 September 2014|accessdate=6 August 2017|author=de Beer, Diane}} This project has developed into the most exciting classical singing ensemble in South Africa, and is now on the brink of becoming a vibrant, new, young opera company. A project for future stars of Africa! The Ensemble, sponsored by [[Sappi]], performs operas at the [[State Theatre, South Africa|State Theatre]] ([[Pretoria]]), [[Walter Sisulu National Botanical Garden]] (Johannesburg) and the [[Joburg Theatre|Civic Theatre]] (Johannesburg).{{cn|date=March 2018}} ==Marriage== Mimi was married three times. Her first marriage was to South African composer Dawid Engela in 1953 but the marriage ended in divorce in 1957.{{rp|5}} Her second marriage was to Italian business man Diego Brighi in 1965 and was again divorced in 1969.{{rp|5}} Her last marriage was to a businessman, Werner Ackerman, in 1970 and lasted until 1994.{{rp|5}} After five miscarriages, she would adopt a son and daughter, Walter and Mia. ==Honours and awards== * 1961: Medal of Honour of the South African Academy for Science and Art (''Suid-Afrikaanse Akademie vir Wetenskap en Kuns'') {{citation needed|date=April 2017}} * 1966: Title of ''[[Kammersängerin]]''{{cite news|title=My lewe het verloop soos dit moet, se Mimi|work=Die Burger|date=5 August 2017|author=Teresa Coetzee}}{{rp|5}} * 1985: [[Decoration for Meritorious Services]] (South Africa) in recognition of her contribution to the Arts{{rp|5}} * August 1996: [[Austrian Cross of Honour for Science and Art]]{{cite web|url=http://www.parlament.gv.at/PAKT/VHG/XXIV/AB/AB_10542/imfname_251156.pdf|title=Reply to a parliamentary question|accessdate=25 January 2013|format=pdf|page=1067|language=German}} * 1998: Honorary Doctor of Philosophy (h.c.) from the [[University of Pretoria]], South Africa{{Cite web|url=http://whoswho.co.za/maria-coertse-3964|title=Maria Coertse|website=whoswho.co.za|access-date=9 January 2018}}{{rp|5}} * 2002: Golden "Rathausmann"{{rp|5}} * In 2004: Voted 45th in the [[SABC3's Great South Africans|Top 100 Great South Africans]]{{citation needed|date=April 2017}} * In 2008: Mimi Coertse Museum van Afrikaans opened at [http://www.hoovers.com/company-information/cs/company-profile.huis_vir_afrikaanse_poesie_cc.0b13f9c92a13e408.html HAP - Huis van Afrikaanse Poësie] in Capital Park, Pretoria.{{rp|5}} * 2012: 1 July–30 September: special exhibition in [[Vienna State Opera|Staatsoper]] museum Vienna: "Mimi Coertse, a Viennese woman from South Africa"{{citation needed|date=April 2017}} ==References== {{reflist}} ==Literature== * Helmuth Furch, 'Die Wiener Jahre von Kammersängerin Mimi Coertse,' ('The Viennese years of Kammersängerin Mimi Coertse'), ''Bulletin of Museums- und Kulturverein Kaisersteinbruch'' No. 41, 20–56, March 1996: also 'Mimi Coertse, die hochgeschätzte Konzert- und Liedsängerin' ('A reverence for a great Concert- and Lieder-singer'), ''ibid.'' No. 52, 33–54, December 1998. * Helmuth Furch, Eva Hilda Smolik and Elfriede Werthan, ''Kammersängerin Mimi Coertse, eine Wienerin aus Südafrika'' (''Kammersängerin Mimi Coertse, a Viennese woman from South Africa'') (with a preface by [[Marcel Prawy]]), (Vienna 2002). {{Authority control}} {{DEFAULTSORT:Coertse, Mimi}} [[Category:1932 births]] [[Category:Living people]] [[Category:Musicians from Durban]] [[Category:Afrikaans-language singers]] [[Category:Afrikaner people]] [[Category:South African female singers]] [[Category:South African operatic sopranos]] [[Category:20th-century opera singers]] [[Category:20th-century South African singers]] [[Category:University of Pretoria alumni]] [[Category:Classical music radio presenters]] [[Category:Recipients of the Austrian Cross of Honour for Science and Art]] [[Category:Österreichischer Kammersänger]] [[Category:20th-century women singers]]

{{Infobox Politician | image = | birth_date = [[London]], [[UK]] | name = Nancy Dinah Elly Khedouri | residence = [[Bahrain]] | office =Jewish representative in the [[National Assembly of Bahrain|National Assembly]] | term_start = 2013 | term_end = present | successor = | constituency = }}
'''Nancy Dinah Elly Khedouri''' ({{lang-ar| نانسي دينا إيلي خضوري}}; {{lang-he| נאנסי ח'דורי}}) is a [[Bahrain]]i politician, businesswoman and writer. She has been a [[National Assembly of Bahrain]] member since 2010. ==Biography== The Khedouris family are one of the Jewish families in [[Bahrain]], a family of importers of tablecloths and linens. Her direct family is third generation in Bahrain, and she is the cousin of [[Houda Nonoo]], the Bahraini Ambassador to the [[United States]] from 2008 to 2013.<ref name="alarabiya retracing">Ismaeel Naar, [https://english.alarabiya.net/en/features/2017/02/26/Long-history-of-Jewish-Bahraini-contributions-to-Gulf-economics-and-politics.html Retracing Bahrain’s Jewish contributions to Gulf economics and politics], ''Alarabiya.net'', 26 February 2017</ref><ref>Michael Slackman, [https://www.nytimes.com/2009/04/06/world/middleeast/06bahrain.html In a Landscape of Tension, Bahrain Embraces Its Jews. All 36 of Them.], ''Nytimes.com'', 5 April 2009</ref>
In her 2007 book ''From Our Beginning to Present Day'', she documented the history of Bahraini Jews from the first settlers (late 1880s) to our days.<ref name="alarabiya retracing"/>
In 2010, Nancy Khedouri became a member of the [[National Assembly of Bahrain]].<ref>Souad Mekhennet, [https://www.washingtonpost.com/posteverything/wp/2014/06/09/one-persian-gulf-monarchys-surprising-embrace-of-jews/ One Persian Gulf monarchy's surprising embrace of Jews], ''Washingtonpost.com'', 9 June 2014</ref> She has worked on smoothening relationships with Israel by appearing publicly with political figures such as [[Yisrael Katz (politician, born 1955)|Yisrael Katz]].<ref>Ben Caspit, [https://www.al-monitor.com/pulse/originals/2017/09/israel-bahrain-saudi-arabia-iran-yisrael-katz-parliament.html Bahrain goes public with shifting stance on Israel], ''Al-monitor.com'', 18 September 2017</ref> In April 2017, she represented her country at the [[World Jewish Congress]].<ref>Justin Cohen, [http://jewishnews.timesofisrael.com/welcome-to-the-jew-nited-nations/ Welcome to the Jew-nited Nations], ''Timesofisrael.com'', 26 April 2017</ref>
==Works== *''From Our Beginning to Present Day'' ({{lang-ar|بداياتنا و حتى وقتنا الحاضر}}), Manama, Bahrain, 2007 {{ISBN|978-99901-26-04-4}} <ref>Jay Levinson, [http://www.jewishmag.com/120mag/bahrain/bahrain.htm Book Review], ''Jewishmag.com'', January 2008</ref>
==References== <references/>

{{EngvarB|date=June 2017}} {{Use dmy dates|date=June 2017}} {{Infobox ambassador | name = Nathan Anang Quao | birth_date = {{Birth date|1915|11|21|df=y|}} | birth_place = Adawso, [[Gold Coast (British colony)|Gold Coast]] | death_date = {{Death date and age|2005|2|15|1915|11|21|df=y}} | death_place = [[Accra]], [[Ghana]] | relations = {{unbulleted list|[[Carl Henry Clerk]] (brother-in-law)|[[Nii Amaa Ollennu]] (cousin)|[[Amon Nikoi]] (nephew)|[[Nicholas T. Clerk]] (nephew)|[[George C. Clerk]] (nephew)}} | education = {{unbulleted list|[[Accra Academy]]|[[University of London]] ([[B.A.]], [[Postgraduate Certificate in Education|PGCE]])}} | alma_mater = | occupation = {{hlist|[[Civil Servant]]|[[Diplomat]]|[[Educator]]}} }} '''Nathan Anang Quao''' (21 November 1915 – 15 February 2005) was a [[Ghanaian people|Ghanaian]] [[diplomat]], [[education]]ist and [[Civil service|public servant]] who became a senior [[presidential advisor]] on governance to the administrations of multiple [[List of heads of state of Ghana|Heads of State of Ghana]].<ref name=":0">{{Cite news|url=https://www.modernghana.com/news/74014/nathan-quao-to-be-given-state-burial-on-april-8.html|title=Nathan Quao to be given state burial on April 8|work=ModernGhana.com|access-date=2017-06-11|language=en-GB}}</ref><ref name=":1">{{Cite web|url=http://www.ghanaweb.com/GhanaHomePage/NewsArchive/Nathan-Quao-to-be-given-state-burial-on-April-8-77485|title=Nathan Quao to be given state burial on April 8|website=www.ghanaweb.com|language=en|access-date=2017-06-11}}</ref><ref name=":2">{{Cite web|url=http://www.ghanaweb.com/GhanaHomePage/NewsArchive/Nathan-Quao-s-life-epitomises-the-Civil-Service-78893|title=Nathan Quao's life epitomises the Civil Service|website=www.ghanaweb.com|language=en|access-date=2017-06-11}}</ref> Quao was the founding principal of the [[Keta Secondary School]] in [[Keta, Ghana]], started in 1953.<ref name=":6" /> He was described by independent observers as part of “diminishing survivors of an era, which many consider to have been high-noon of quality and dedication in the [[Civil service|Civil Service]].”<ref name=":2" />
== Early life and education == Quao was born at [http://www.latlong.net/place/adawso-ghana-10826.html Adawso] in the [[Eastern Region (Ghana)|Eastern Region]] on 21 November 1915 where his father Daniel James Quao of [[Labadi Beach|La]] was based as a [[Merchant|general commodities merchant]].<ref name=":0" /><ref name=":1" /><ref name=":3">{{Cite web|url=https://familysearch.org/search/collection/results?count=75&query=+surname:CLERK~&collection_id=1496208|title=FamilySearch.org|website=familysearch.org|language=en|access-date=2017-06-11|deadurl=no|archiveurl=https://web.archive.org/web/20170822012904/https://www.familysearch.org/search/collection/results?count=75&query=%20surname%3ACLERK~&collection_id=1496208|archivedate=22 August 2017|df=dmy-all}}</ref> His mother was Dinah Naa Densua Addy of [[Ga-Mashie]].<ref name=":3" /> His maternal grandfather, Nii Ngleshie Addy I was of royal lineage and the oldest son of Nii Tetteh Tsuru I, the founder and ruler of the Otuopai Clan in [[Ga-Mashie|Ga Mashie]]. He was a member of the [[Ga-Adangbe people|Ga people]] of Accra.<ref name=":2" /> After his elementary education at [[Presbyterian Church of Ghana|Presbyterian]] schools and [[secondary education]] at the [[Accra Academy]], he studied for his [[Bachelor of Arts]] degree from the [[University of London]] as an external student.<ref name=":0" /><ref name=":1" /> He later obtained a [[Postgraduate Certificate in Education|postgraduate certificate in education (PGCE)]] at the [[University of Ghana|University College of the Gold Coast]], then a constituent college of the [[University of London]].<ref name=":0" /><ref name=":1" />
== Career == His early career was in [[Education|teaching]].<ref name=":0" /><ref name=":1" /> He taught at the [[Accra Academy]] and was the first [[headmaster]] of the [[Keta Secondary School]] from 1953 to 1956.<ref name=":0" /><ref name=":1" /> He also served as the Acting Principal of the [[University of Education, Winneba|Winneba Training College]].<ref name=":0" /><ref name=":1" /><ref name=":6" /> Additionally, he taught at the Department of Teacher Training of the [[Kwame Nkrumah University of Science and Technology|Kumasi College of Technology]] in 1957 and earlier on, at the Extra Mural Department of the [[University of Ghana|University College of the Gold Coast]] from 1950 to 1951.<ref name=":0" /><ref name=":1" />
Quao joined the foreign service of the Ghanaian civil service in 1959, becoming a [[Diplomat|career diplomat]] and [[Civil service|civil servant]] in [[Belgrade]], [[Ottawa]] and [[Paris]] and as Counsellor to Ghana's Permanent Mission to the [[United Nations]] in [[New York City|New York]].<ref name=":0" /><ref name=":1" /><ref>{{Cite book|url=https://books.google.com/books?id=iMADAAAAMBAJ&pg=PA38&lpg=PA38&dq=nathan+anang+quao&source=bl&ots=8lpkx23XwV&sig=1tPCm-N2ZkpPNWZgXxJzeGIm8KI&hl=en&sa=X&ved=0ahUKEwi0m4685YPbAhWmxFkKHVK3BUoQ6AEIXTAM#v=onepage&q=quao&f=false|title=Jet|last=Company|first=Johnson Publishing|date=1965-03-18|publisher=Johnson Publishing Company|language=en|deadurl=no|archiveurl=https://web.archive.org/web/20180513230708/https://books.google.com/books?id=iMADAAAAMBAJ&pg=PA38&lpg=PA38&dq=nathan+anang+quao&source=bl&ots=8lpkx23XwV&sig=1tPCm-N2ZkpPNWZgXxJzeGIm8KI&hl=en&sa=X&ved=0ahUKEwi0m4685YPbAhWmxFkKHVK3BUoQ6AEIXTAM#v=onepage&q=quao&f=false|archivedate=13 May 2018|df=dmy-all}}</ref> Later on, he was appointed the Principal Secretary at the [[Ministry of Foreign Affairs]] in 1966.<ref name=":0" /><ref name=":1" />
After the [[Coup d'état|overthrow]] of [[Kwame Nkrumah|Nkrumah]], the military junta transferred him to the Office of the [[National Liberation Council]] (NLC) where he was originally Deputy Secretary to the NLC government and later Secretary to the Executive Council which acted as a collective Presidency before the election of the [[Busia government|Prime Minister in the Second Republic]].<ref name=":0" /><ref name=":1" /> He held the positions of Secretary to the Presidential Commission in 1969 and Secretary to the [[Council of State (Ghana)|Council of State]] in 1970 and subsequently Secretary to the Prime Minister in the [[Busia government|Busia government of the Second Republic]].<ref name=":0" /><ref name=":1" /> Under the leadership of [[Ignatius Kutu Acheampong]] and the [[National Redemption Council]] (NRC), Nathan Quao served as the Secretary to the Council and Head of the Civil Service, retiring in 1973.<ref name=":0" /><ref name=":1" /> In 1974, Quao was appointed the Chairman of the Ghana Teaching Council and a member of the Manpower Board.<ref name=":7">{{Cite book|url=https://books.google.com/books?id=IaxnW86XtfQC&pg=PA22&lpg=PA22&dq=nathan+quao+chief+of+staff&source=bl&ots=gnpExgiMf8&sig=CedqFzJl0_mSU6uV-uzmJS9S8bU&hl=en&sa=X&ved=0ahUKEwizpqbd8oLYAhVChuAKHc8mCQQQ6AEITjAH#v=onepage&q=nathan%20quao%20chief%20of%20staff&f=false|title=The Mirror: Issue 2,208 March 22 1997|last=Provencal|first=E. N. O.|date=1997-03-22|publisher=Graphic Communications Group|language=en|deadurl=no|archiveurl=https://web.archive.org/web/20171211213323/https://books.google.com/books?id=IaxnW86XtfQC&pg=PA22&lpg=PA22&dq=nathan+quao+chief+of+staff&source=bl&ots=gnpExgiMf8&sig=CedqFzJl0_mSU6uV-uzmJS9S8bU&hl=en&sa=X&ved=0ahUKEwizpqbd8oLYAhVChuAKHc8mCQQQ6AEITjAH#v=onepage&q=nathan%20quao%20chief%20of%20staff&f=false|archivedate=11 December 2017|df=dmy-all}}</ref> In 1980, he became a member of the [[University of Cape Coast]] Council.<ref name=":7" />
He was however plucked out of retirement in 1985 and appointed the Secretary and Advisor at the Office of the [[Provisional National Defence Council|PNDC]]. Upon return to civilian rule in 1992, he became a Special Advisor to [[Jerry Rawlings|Jerry John Rawlings]] from 1993 to 2001.<ref name=":0" /><ref name=":1" /><ref>{{Cite web|url=http://www.ghanaweb.com/GhanaHomePage/NewsArchive/ANNUAL-REPORT-TO-PARLIAMENT-ON-PRESIDENTIAL-OFFICE-STAFF-JANUARY-DECEMBER-1996-3151 |title=ANNUAL REPORT TO PARLIAMENT ON PRESIDENTIAL OFFICE STAFF - JANUARY - DECEMBER, 1996 |website=www.ghanaweb.com |language=en |access-date=2017-06-11 |deadurl=no |archiveurl=https://web.archive.org/web/20161009214932/http://www.ghanaweb.com/GhanaHomePage/NewsArchive/ANNUAL-REPORT-TO-PARLIAMENT-ON-PRESIDENTIAL-OFFICE-STAFF-JANUARY-DECEMBER-1996-3151 |archivedate=9 October 2016 |df= }}</ref>
== Personal life and family == He was married to Dora Tawia Quao (née Mettle) with two children.<ref name=":0" /><ref name=":1" /> Quao was the maternal uncle of the Ghanaian economist and diplomat, [[Amon Nikoi]], who was the [[Governor]] of the [[Bank of Ghana]] from 1973 to 1977 and [[Finance minister]] from 1979 to 1981.<ref>{{Cite web|url=http://www.ghanaweb.com/GhanaHomePage/NewsArchive/Former-Bank-of-Ghana-Governor-buried-at-La-28089 |title=Former Bank of Ghana Governor buried at La |website=www.ghanaweb.com |language=en |access-date=2017-06-11 |deadurl=no |archiveurl=https://web.archive.org/web/20170421092109/http://www.ghanaweb.com/GhanaHomePage/NewsArchive/Former-Bank-of-Ghana-Governor-buried-at-La-28089 |archivedate=21 April 2017 |df= }}</ref><ref>{{Cite web|url=http://www.ghanaweb.com/GhanaHomePage/people/person.php?ID=171 |title=Dr Amon Nikoi, Former Governor of the Bank of Ghana |website=www.ghanaweb.com |language=en |access-date=2017-06-11 |deadurl=no |archiveurl=https://web.archive.org/web/20161027192942/http://www.ghanaweb.com/GhanaHomePage/people/person.php?ID=171 |archivedate=27 October 2016 |df= }}</ref> In addition, Quao's cousin was the Ghanaian [[barrister]] and [[judge]], [[Nii Amaa Ollennu]] who was elected the [[Speaker (politics)|Speaker]] of the [[Parliament of Ghana]] during the [[Busia government|Second Republic]] as well as serving as the Chairman of the Presidential Commission and acting [[President of Ghana]] from 7 August 1970 to 31 August 1970.<ref>{{Cite web|url=http://www.judicial.gov.gh/history/list_lawyers/home.htm |title=Official Web Site for the Judicial Service of the Republic of Ghana |date=2005-04-14 |access-date=2017-06-11 |deadurl=bot: unknown |archiveurl=https://web.archive.org/web/20050414064831/http://www.judicial.gov.gh/history/list_lawyers/home.htm |archivedate=14 April 2005 |df= }}</ref><ref>{{Cite web|url=http://rulers.org/rulg1.html#ghana |title=Countries Ga-Gi |website=rulers.org |access-date=2017-06-11 |deadurl=no |archiveurl=https://web.archive.org/web/20070403074857/http://www.rulers.org/rulg1.html |archivedate=3 April 2007 |df= }}</ref> His brother-in-law, the Reverend [[Carl Henry Clerk]] (1895 – 1982) was a [[Ghanaian people|Ghanaian]] [[Agricultural education|agricultural educator,]] [[Head teacher|administrator]], [[journalist]], [[Editor-in-chief|editor]] and [[Presbyterian minister]] who was elected the fourth Synod Clerk of the [[Presbyterian Church of Ghana|Presbyterian Church of the Gold Coast]] from 1950 to 1954.<ref>{{Cite book|url=https://books.google.com/books?id=nL8DAAAAMBAJ&pg=PA47&lpg=PA47&dq=carl+henry+clerk+gold+coast&source=bl&ots=OOY7DOpf-W&sig=gFZwpVK6_fm38SYCEfqu1bVK6c4&hl=en&sa=X&ved=0ahUKEwi-jYWErOXSAhVK6GMKHVXKCOQQ6AEIGjAA#v=onepage&q=carl%20henry%20clerk%20gold%20coast&f=false|title=Jet|last=Company|first=Johnson Publishing|date=1954-08-26|publisher=Johnson Publishing Company|language=en|deadurl=no|archiveurl=https://web.archive.org/web/20170329232757/https://books.google.com/books?id=nL8DAAAAMBAJ&pg=PA47&lpg=PA47&dq=carl%20henry%20clerk%20gold%20coast&source=bl&ots=OOY7DOpf-W&sig=gFZwpVK6_fm38SYCEfqu1bVK6c4&hl=en&sa=X&ved=0ahUKEwi-jYWErOXSAhVK6GMKHVXKCOQQ6AEIGjAA#v=onepage&q=carl%20henry%20clerk%20gold%20coast&f=false|archivedate=29 March 2017|df=dmy-all}}</ref><ref name=":4">{{Cite book|title=Obituary: The Reverend Carl Henry Clerk|last=Clerk|first=Nicholas, T.|publisher=Presbyterian Church of Ghana, Funeral Bulletin|date=5 June 1982|isbn=|location=Accra|pages=}}</ref> Clerk was also the [[Editor]] of the [[Christian Messenger (Ghana)|Christian Messenger]], the newspaper of the [[Presbyterian Church of Ghana]] from 1960 to 1963.<ref name=":4" /> Carl Clerk's sons were the [[academics]], [[Nicholas T. Clerk]] and [[George C. Clerk]].<ref name=":02">{{Cite web|url=http://www.odadee.net/school|title=PRESEC {{!}} ALUMINI PORTAL|date=2016-11-11|access-date=2017-06-11|deadurl=bot: unknown|archiveurl=https://web.archive.org/web/20161111065106/http://www.odadee.net/school|archivedate=11 November 2016|df=}}</ref><ref name=":12">{{Cite web|url=http://www.odadee75.org/downloads/70years.pdf|title=70 years of excellent secondary education|last=|first=|date=|website=|archive-url=https://web.archive.org/web/20110722010817/http://www.odadee75.org/downloads/70years.pdf|archive-date=22 July 2011|dead-url=no|access-date=|df=}}</ref>
== Death and state funeral == Nathan Quao died in [[Accra]] on 15 February 2005 of [[Death by natural causes|natural causes]]. He was accorded a [[state funeral]] on Friday 8 April 2005 at the Forecourt of the ''State House'' and buried at the [[Labadi Beach|La]] Public Cemetery by the Ghanaian government as a token of the state’s appreciation of his distinguished service to the country.<ref name=":0" /><ref name=":1" />
== Legacy and honours == He was a recipient of several national awards including Member of the [[Order of the Volta]] (Civil Division) and the Officer of the [[Order of the Star of Ghana]] (Civil Division).<ref name=":0" /><ref name=":1" /> In recognition of his service to the Ghanaian [[Civil service|Civil Service]], the Civil Service and Local Government Staff Association (CLOGSAG) renamed its auditorium in his memory.<ref name=":5">{{Cite news|url=http://www.ghananewsagency.org/social/clogsag-honours-nathan-quao-118825 |title=CLOGSAG honours Nathan Quao |access-date=2017-06-27 |deadurl=no |archiveurl=https://web.archive.org/web/20170626172854/http://www.ghananewsagency.org/social/clogsag-honours-nathan-quao-118825 |archivedate=26 June 2017 }}</ref><ref>{{Cite web|url=http://m.peacefmonline.com/pages/local/news/201706/318453.php|title=Public Servants Have no Excuse to be Mediocre - Rawlings|last=Online|first=Peace FM|website=m.peacefmonline.com|language=en-US|access-date=2017-12-11|deadurl=no|archiveurl=https://web.archive.org/web/20171211213323/http://m.peacefmonline.com/pages/local/news/201706/318453.php|archivedate=11 December 2017|df=dmy-all}}</ref> In addition, the Association made a book compilation of Quao’s writings and memoirs in order to preserve his legacy.<ref name=":5" /> Furthermore, the Local Government Service of Ghana instituted “an Annual Awards Scheme as part of the [[United Nations]] / [[African Union]] Public Service Day to be sponsored by the [[Government of Ghana]] in his honour.”<ref name=":5" /> A boys' dormitory at the [[Keta Secondary School]], ''[[Keta Senior High Technical School#Quao|Quao House]]'' was named in his honour as the founding [[Head teacher|headmaster]] of the school.<ref name=":6">{{Cite web|url=http://dzolali85.webs.com/schoolhistory.htm|title=School History|website=Ketasco 1985 Year Group|access-date=2017-07-14}}</ref>
== References == {{Reflist|2}}

revision.comment: Rescuing 11 sources and tagging 1 as dead. #IABot (v1.6.2)
revision.text:
{{redirect|Nicholas Morris}} '''Nick Morris''' is a [[film maker]] who began writing and making amateur films at school, one of which was shown at the NFT. His professional career began in the 1980s with music videos for "[[The Final Countdown (song)|The Final Countdown]]" by [[Europe (band)|Europe]], "[[Kyrie (song)|Kyrie]]" by [[Mr. Mister]] and "[[Everytime You Go Away]]" by [[Paul Young]]. After making approximately 100 promos for artists such as [[Elton John]], [[Celine Dion]], [[Alison Moyet]], [[Warrant (American band)|Warrant]], [[Terence Trent D'Arby]], [[Stevie Wonder]], [[Paul Carrack]], [[Prefab Sprout]], [[Kirsty MacColl]], [[Go West (band)|Go West]], the [[Kane Gang]], [[The Alarm]], [[Status Quo (band)|Status Quo]], [[Toto (band)|Toto]], [[Natalie Cole]], [[Nena]], [[Scorpions (band)|Scorpions]] and the number one charity single [[Ferry Aid]], he moved into longer form projects including the [[Cirque du Soleil]] show ''[[Alegría (Cirque du Soleil)|Alegría]]'', which was nominated for a primetime [[Emmy]], ''[[Jesus Christ Superstar]]'', which won an International Emmy, and [[AC/DC]]'s ''[[Stiff Upper Lip Live]]'' in Munich. He has also directed DVDs for comedians such as [[The Mighty Boosh]], [[Mitchell and Webb]] and [[Bill Bailey]]. Other work includes numerous trailers and music clips for West End shows such as ''[[The Producers (musical)|The Producers]]'', ''[[Spamalot]]'', ''[[Calendar Girls]]'', ''[[Guys and Dolls]]'', ''[[Edward Scissorhands]]'' and ''[[The Rocky Horror Show]]''. in 2009 he captured [[Spandau Ballet]]'s triumphant homecoming concert at the [[The O2 Arena (London)|O2 Arena]] in [[London]] and [[Jude Law]]'s portrayal of [[Hamlet]].
==Selected music video credits== ===1985=== *[[Paul Young]] - "[[Everytime You Go Away]]" *[[Mr. Mister]] - "[[Kyrie (song)|Kyrie]]"<ref name="Clipland">{{cite web|url=http://www.clipland.com/Name/0008066/|title=Nick Morris at Clipland|publisher=clipland.com|accessdate=2008-08-17}}</ref>

revision.comment: Corrected "founder" to "co-founder". Refer article Telectronics Pty Ltd.
revision.text:
{{Use dmy dates|date=December 2010}} {{Primary sources|date=March 2008}} '''Noel Desmond Gray''' (26 December 1920 – November 1999) Senior design engineer at the Philips subsidiary Kriesler and medical student at the University of Sydney after War service in the Royal Australian Electrical and Mechanical Engineers. He formed the desire to start the Medical Device Industry at Med School and co-founded Telectronics [[ Pty Ltd]].<ref name="gray">{{cite book |last=Gray |first=Christopher|last2=Gray|first2=Noel|title=The Early Years of Telectronics |year=1993 |publisher= (self-published)| url=https://books.google.com/books?id=OAZZAQAACAAJ&dq |isbn=0-646-15134-7 }}</ref>
==Early life== Noel Gray was born to Hilda Alice Gray on [[Boxing Day]] 1920 in [[Crookwell, New South Wales]], Australia. Separated from his father Jo Gray, Hilda took him to grow up with her father at Middle View near Dalgety on the Snowy River. His grandfather brought him up. George Hedger was son of a man that newspaper reports said was the original inspiration for the [[Banjo Paterson]] poem "[[The Man from Snowy River (poem)|The Man from Snowy River]]".<ref>{{cite news| work=Monaro Mercury| date=3 August 1912| title=Death of George H. Hedger}}</ref>
Noel and Hilda moved to Sydney and he attended a number of technical schools and at the Sydney Technical School passed the [[Intermediate Certificate (Australia)|Intermediate Certificate]] He then went to worked in the radio industry culminating in a position at Kriesler as a technician before the War.
==World War II== Gray enlisted in the army in August 1942.<ref name = "WW2NomRoll">{{cite web|url = http://www.ww2roll.gov.au/Veteran.aspx?serviceId=A&veteranId=210360| title = Listing for Noel Desmond Gray| work = World War II nominal roll| publisher = Australian Government - Department of Veterans' Affairs| accessdate = 1 May 2008}}</ref> During World War II he was trained at the Army School of Radio Physics, whereupon he became a [[radar]] technician and Senior Radar Artificer. He also attended No. 6 OCTU.
Gray returned to LHQ where he was placed in charge of the Drawing Office and maintenance section. He helped to install the radar defenses on [[Rottnest Island]] for Western Australia and was the Senior Radar Artificer at [[Exmouth Gulf]].<ref>Dunn, Peter. [http://home.st.net.au/~dunn/japsland/land03.htm Peter Dunn's Australia at War.]</ref> He worked on the first US-designed radar unit in Australia, which was subsequently used to direct bombers during the [[Battle of the Coral Sea]].<ref name="gray"/>
Gray was discharged from the army on 10 May 1946 with the rank of Staff Sergeant posted to 2 SPECIAL RADAR DET RAA.<ref name = "WW2NomRoll"/>
==Post war== In 1948 Gray was accepted to study medicine at the [[University of Sydney]] but withdrew from his studies in 1950 to get married. He work for the Department of Civil Aviation on RADAR installation at [[Sydney Airport]], and on engineering projects for the Metropolitan Water, Sewerage & Drainage Board.
In 1952 he returned to work for the Philips' subsidiary Kreisler to work on a secret project for LRWE, then as senior design engineer. He designed and developed [[printed circuit board]] production methods that he incorporated into his designed [[Kriesler Duplex]] radios, but were not adopted until a later date. A number of [[patent]]s were taken out on his work and he was sent on a World study tour by Phillips where he introduced his printed circuits to their founder.<ref name="gray"/>
Gray resigned from Kreisler in 1959 to start a medical electronics business, an ambition he had developed while studying medicine from 1948 - 50.<ref name="gray"/> To finance this venture he started a specialist TV repair business<ref>''Mingay's Weekly'', 27 November 1959</ref> and was a founder of ESA (later called TESA).<ref name="gray"/>
Telectronics Pty Limited was incorporated in Sydney, Australia, in 1963<ref name = "austehc">{{cite web | last = Smith | first = Ailie | authorlink = | coauthors = | year = 2000 | url = http://www.austehc.unimelb.edu.au/asaw/biogs/A000354b.htm | title = Telectronics Holdings Limited ( - 1988) | work = Australian Science at Work (Corporate entry) | publisher = Australian Science and Technology Heritage Centre | accessdate = 2006-12-04}} and also {{cite web | last = Smith | first = Ailie | authorlink = | coauthors = | year = 2006 | url = http://www.austehc.unimelb.edu.au/asaw/biogs/A000347b.htm | title = Telectronics Pty Ltd (1963 - 1996) | work = Australian Science at Work (Corporate entry) | publisher = Australian Science and Technology Heritage Centre | accessdate = 2006-12-04}}</ref><ref name = "wickham">"Telectronics and The History Of Pacemaking In Australia", Wickham G G, Jeffcoat KW, 1987 manuscript held by http://www.austehc.unimelb.edu.au. University Of Melbourne .(www.austehc.unimelb.edu.au.)</ref><ref name = "gray"/> by technician and initial financier [[Noel Gray]] and engineer [[Geoffrey Wickham]] initially designing and manufacturing industrial and scientific instruments but diversifying into medical electronics and commencing cardiac pacemaker research in 1964.<ref name = "TrainorObit">{{cite news | first= Robert | last= Foot | author= | url= http://www.smh.com.au/news/obituaries/rare-breed-of-native-industrialist/2006/04/13/1144521458280.html?page=fullpage#contentSwap1 | title=Rare breed of native industrialist: Paul Murray Trainor, AO Industrialist 1927-2006 | newspaper=[[Sydney Morning Herald]] | date= 2006-04-14 | accessdate=2006-12-04}}</ref><ref name = "powerhouse">{{cite web | last = | first = | authorlink = | coauthors = | year = | url = http://www.powerhousemuseum.com/collection/database/?irn=331255 | title = Display panels tracing the history of 'Telectronics' cardiac pacemakers and defibrillators, 1990 | work = Objects from the collection of the Powerhouse Museum, Sydney, Australia | publisher = [[Powerhouse Museum]] | accessdate = 2006-12-04}}</ref> The corporate name was derived from "Television and Electronic Services", operated by Noel Gray as a sole trader from 1959 to 1964.<ref name="gray"/> The company made significant contributions to pacemaker technology including the first definition of the relationship between surface area of the heart electrodes & pacing pulse characteristics, the first use of [[integrated circuit]]s and the first [[Hermetic seal|hermetic]] [[titanium]] encapsulation.<ref name = "gray"/><ref name = "wickham"/>
Nucleus Holdings Pty Limited, a company incorporated in 1967, became a 50% shareholder of Telectronics in January 1968. In 1975 Nucleus Holdings Pty Limited transferred its shares in Telectronics to Nucleus Corporation Pty Limited and reduced the holding by sale of shares to a French multinational leaving a 33.33% holding by Nucleus Corporation Pty Ltd which became the publicly listed company Nucleus Limited 1980.<ref> Corporate Affairs records of Nucleus Holdings Pty Nucleus Corporation Pty Limited</ref> In turn Nucleus Limited was acquired by [[Pacific Dunlop]] in 1988. Legal action over the sale of faulty "J Lead" electrodes, inherited by Telectronics in acquisition of pacemaker manufacturer [[Cordis (medical)|Cordis]] corporation of Miami led to the company having to settle extensive worldwide compensation claims. This led to the sale of Telectronics assets to, eventually, [[St. Jude Medical]] of Minneapolis and Pacific Dunlop restructuring itself into [[Ansell]].{{Citation needed|date=July 2009}}
==Death== Noel Desmond Gray died in November 1999. He was survived by his wife Beth, daughter Robyn, and son Christopher.
==References== {{Reflist}}
{{Authority control}}

{{Other uses}} {{See also|Public speaking|Rhetoric}} {{Refimprove|date=September 2008}} An '''orator''', or '''oratist''', is a public speaker, especially one who is eloquent or skilled.<ref>{{Cite web|url=https://en.oxforddictionaries.com/definition/orator|title=orator {{!}} Definition of orator in English by Oxford Dictionaries|website=Oxford Dictionaries {{!}} English|access-date=2018-06-05}}</ref>
==Etymology== Recorded in English c. 1374, with a meaning of "one who pleads or argues for a cause", from Anglo-French ''oratour'', Old French ''orateur'' (14th century), Latin ''orator'' ("speaker"), from ''orare'' ("speak before a court or assembly; plead"), derived from a Proto-Indo-European base *''or-'' ("to pronounce a ritual formula").
The modern meaning of the word, "public speaker", is attested from c. 1430.
==History== In ancient [[Rome]], the art of speaking in public (''Ars Oratoria'') was a professional competence especially cultivated by [[politician]]s and [[lawyer]]s. As the [[Ancient Greece|Greeks]] were still seen as the masters in this field, as in philosophy and most sciences, the leading Roman families often either sent their sons to study these things under a famous master in Greece (as was the case with the young [[Julius Caesar]]), or engaged a Greek teacher (under pay or as a slave).{{Citation needed|date=September 2008}}
In the young revolutionary French republic, ''Orateur'' (French for "orator", but compare the Anglo-Saxon parliamentary [[speaker (politics)|speaker]]) was the formal title for the delegated members of the [[Tribunat]] to the [[Corps législatif]], to motivate their ruling on a presented bill.
In the 19th century, orators and [[lecture]]rs, such as [[Mark Twain]], [[Charles Dickens]], and Col. [[Robert G. Ingersoll]] were major providers of [[popular entertainment]].
A '''pulpit orator''' is a Christian author, often a clergyman, renowned for their ability to write or deliver (from the [[pulpit]] in church, hence the word) rhetorically skilled religious [[sermon]]s.
In some [[university|universities]], the title 'Orator' is given to the official whose task it is to give speeches on ceremonial occasions, such as the presentation of [[honorary degrees]].
== Orators == The following are, by necessity, '''those who have been noted as famous specifically for their oratory abilities''', or for a particularly famous speech or speeches. Most religious leaders and politicians (by nature of their office) may perform many speeches, as may those who support or oppose a particular issue. To include them all would be prohibitive.
=== [[Classical antiquity|Classical era]] === *The ten [[Attic orators]] ([[Greece]]) **[[Demosthenes]], champion of the [[Philippic]] **[[Aeschines]] **[[Andocides]] **[[Antiphon (person)|Antiphon]] **[[Dinarchus]] **[[Hypereides]] **[[Lysias]] **[[Isaeus]] **[[Isocrates]] **[[Lycurgus of Athens]] *[[Aristogeiton (orator)|Aristogeiton]] *[[Claudius Aelianus]], ''meliglossos'', 'honey-tongued' *[[Cicero]] *[[Corax of Syracuse]] *[[Gaius Scribonius Curio]] *[[Gorgias]] *[[Hegesippus (orator)|Hegesippus]], [[Athenian]] *[[Julius Caesar]], [[Roman dictator]] *[[Licinius Macer Calvus]], [[Roman Republic|Roman]] poet and orator *[[Marcus Antonius (orator)]], [[Roman Republic|Roman]] *[[Nicetas of Smyrna]], 1st century AD, [[Ancient Greece|Greek]] [[sophist]] and orator *[[Pericles]], Athenian statesman *[[Quintilian]] *[[Quintus Hortensius]] *[[John Chrysostom]] (literally ''golden-mouthed''), Christian preacher
=== [[Modern history|Modern era]] === *[[Allied leaders of World War II|Allied]] and [[Axis leaders of World War II|Axis]] leaders of [[World War II]] noted for their speeches: **[[Winston Churchill]] ([[Prime Minister of the United Kingdom|British Prime Minister]]) **[[Charles de Gaulle]] ([[Free French Forces|Free French]] general; [[President of France]]) **[[Joseph Goebbels]] ([[Nazi]] [[Propaganda]] Minister) **[[Adolf Hitler]] ([[Führer]] of [[Nazi Germany]]) **[[Douglas MacArthur]] - ''[[wikisource:MacArthur's Farewell Speech to Congress|Farewell Speech to Congress]]'' **[[Benito Mussolini]] **[[Franklin D. Roosevelt]] ([[President of the United States|US President]]) * The [[Great Triumvirate]]: **[[Henry Clay]] **[[John C. Calhoun]] **[[Daniel Webster]] *[[Jawaharlal Nehru]] - ''[[Tryst with Destiny]]'' *[[William Jennings Bryan]] - ''[[Cross of Gold speech]]'' *[[Frederick Douglass]] - ''[[Self-Made Men (Frederick Douglass)|Self-Made Men]]'' *[[Ralph Waldo Emerson]] - ''[[The American Scholar]]'' *[[Patrick Henry]] - ''[[Give me Liberty, or give me Death!]]'' *[[John F. Kennedy]] ([[President of the United States|US President]]) - ''[[Wikiquote:John F. Kennedy#Inaugural Address (1961)|Inaugural Address]]'' *[[Martin Luther King, Jr.]] - ''[[I Have A Dream]]'' *[[Abraham Lincoln]] ([[President of the United States|US President]]) - ''[[Gettysburg address]]'' *[[Richard M. Nixon]] ([[Vice-President of the United States|US Vice-President]]) - ''[[Checkers speech]]'' *[[Ronald Reagan]] ([[President of the United States|US President]]) - ''[[First Inaugural address of Ronald Reagan|First Inaugural Address]]''; ''[[Tear down this wall|Mr. Gorbachev, tear down this wall!]]'' *[[Margaret Thatcher]] - ''[[The lady's not for turning]]'' *[[Sojourner Truth]]<ref name = "Leeman ">African American Orators: A Bio-Critical Sourcebook, edited by Richard W. Leeman, Greenwood Publishing Group, 1996. {{ISBN|0-313-29014-8}}</ref> - ''[[Ain't I a Woman?]]'' *[[Malcolm X]] - ''[[The Ballot or the Bullet]]'' *[[Nelson Mandela]] - ''[[I Am Prepared to Die]]'' *[[Leon Trotsky]]

Leeman, Greenwood Publishing Group, 1996. {{ISBN|0-313-29014-8}} *The Will of a People: A Critical Anthology of Great Speeches by African Americans, edited with critical introductions by Richard W. Andrews and David Zarefsky, Longman Publishing Group, 1991. {{ISBN|0-8013-0218-8}} {{ISBN|978-0-8013-0218-3}} *Contemporary American Public Discourse. 3rd Edition. edited by Halford Ross Ryan, Waveland Press, 1991. {{ISBN|0-88133-629-7}} | {{ISBN|978-0-88133-629-0}}

{{Infobox officeholder | honorific_prefix = [[Count]] [[Peerage of France|Peer]] | name = Pellegrino Rossi | image = Rossi bridi.jpg | office = [[List of Prime Ministers of the Papal States|6th Papal Minister of Interior]] | monarch = [[Pope Pius IX]] | term_start = 10 September 1848 | term_end = 15 November 1848 | predecessor = [[Edoardo Fabbri]] | successor = [[Carlo Emanuele Muzzarelli]] | office1 = [[Minister of Finance]] | monarch1 = [[Pope Pius IX]] | term_start1 = 16 September 1848 | term_end1 = 15 November 1848 | predecessor1 = ''Position created'' | successor1 = ''Position abolished'' | office2 = [[Chamber of Peers (France)|Member of the French Chamber of Peers]] | monarch2 = [[Louis Philippe I]] | term_start2 = 1838 | term_end2 = 15 November 1848 | birth_date = {{Birth date|df=yes|1787|7|13}} | birth_place = [[Carrara]], [[Grand Duchy of Tuscany|Tuscany]] (now [[Italy]]) | death_date = {{Death date and age|df=yes|1848|11|15|1787|7|13}} | death_place = [[Rome]], [[Papal States]] (now [[Italy]]) | resting_place = [[San Lorenzo in Damaso]], Rome | nationality = [[Italian nationality law|Tuscan]]
[[Swiss nationality law|Italian]]
[[French nationality law|French]] | party = [[Moderate Party (Italy)|Moderate]] | alma_mater = [[University of Pisa]]
[[University of Bologna]] | profession = [[Teacher]], [[economist]], [[diplomat]] | branch = [[File:Flag of the Kingdom of Naples (1811).svg|20px]] [[Army of the Two Sicilies|Neapolitan Army]] | serviceyears = 1815 | rank = [[Soldier]] | battles = {{hlist|[[Neapolitan War]]}} }} '''Pellegrino Rossi''' (13 July 1787 – 15 November 1848) was an [[Italian people|Italian]] economist, politician and jurist. He was an important figure of the [[July Monarchy]] in France, and the Minister of Justice in the government of the [[Papal States]], under [[Pope Pius IX]]. ==Biography== Rossi was born in [[Carrara]], then under the [[Duchy of Massa and Carrara]]. Educated at the [[University of Pisa]] and the [[University of Bologna]], he became professor of law at the latter in 1812. In 1815 he gave his support to [[Joachim Murat]] and his [[Kingdom of Naples|Neapolitan]] anti-[[Austrian Empire|Austrian]] expedition: after the latter's fall, he escaped to France, and then proceeded to [[Canton of Geneva|Geneva]], where he began teaching a course of [[jurisprudence]] applied to [[Roman law]], the success of which gained him the unusual honour of [[naturalization]] as a [[Swiss people|citizen of Geneva]]. In 1820 he was elected as a deputy to the [[Cantons of Switzerland|cantonal council]], and was a member of the diet of 1832; Rossi was entrusted with the task of drawing up a revised constitution, which was known as the ''Pacte Rossi''. This was rejected by a majority of the diet, a result which deeply affected Rossi, and made him accept the invitation of [[François Guizot]] to settle in France. Here he was appointed in 1833 to the chair of [[political economy]] in the [[Collège de France]], vacated by the death of [[Jean-Baptiste Say]]. He was naturalized as a French citizen in 1834, and in the same year became professor of [[constitutional law]] in the faculty of law of the [[University of Paris|Paris University]]. In 1836 he was elected a member of the [[Academy of Political and Moral Sciences]], was raised to the [[Peerage of France|French peerage]] in 1839, and in 1843 became [[dean (education)|dean]] of the faculty of law. In 1842 Rossi and Count Ferdinand-Charles-Philippe d' Esterno (1805–83) organized the first meetings of what would become the [[Société d'économie politique]].{{citation|page=670 |last=Garnier|first=Joseph|title=Dictionnaire de l'économie politique contenant l'exposition des principes de la science, l'opinion des écrivains qui ont le plus contribué a sa fondation et a ses progrés, la bibliographie générale de l'économie politique par noms d'auteurs et par ordre de matiéres, avec des notices biographiques et une appréciation raisonnée des principaux ouvrages: A-I|url=https://books.google.com/books?id=qY7KFHk43q0C&pg=PA670|accessdate=2017-08-18|year=1852|publisher=Meline, Cans|chapter=Économie Politique (Société d’)}} In 1845, Guizot appointed Rossi ambassador of France to the Papal States, with a specific mission to discuss the question of the [[Jesuits]]. However, the [[French Revolution of 1848]] toppled Guizot's regime, and the [[revolutions of 1848 in the Italian states|revolution in Italy]] fully severed Rossi's connection with France. Rossi thus remained at Rome and became Minister of the Interior under Pius IX. Rossi's program of [[Liberalism|liberal reforms]], however, never took off, as his brand of [[conservative liberalism]], in which suffrage was to be limited to the well-off and the economic and social disruptions created by industrialization went unaddressed, had narrow appeal.{{cite podcast |last=Duncan|first=Mike|author-link = Mike Duncan (podcaster)|title=The Flight of the Pope|website=Revolutions|publisher=|date=18 February 2018|time= |url=http://www.revolutionspodcast.com/2018/02/727-the-flight-of-the-pope.html|access-date=22 February 2018}} His assassination took place on the stairs at the opening of the Parliament in the [[Palazzo della Cancelleria]] on 15 November 1848 by a stab wound to the neck. This was one of the causes of the flight from Rome of Pope Pius IX and the beginning of the series of events that led to the proclamation of the [[Roman Republic (19th century)|Roman Republic]]. The murderer was said to be Luigi Brunetti, the elder son of Angelo Brunetti (or Ciceruacchio), who acted at the instigation of [[Pietro Sterbini]], and with the cooperation of some veterans or ''reduci'' of the conflict in Lombardy. After the murder, the senate adjourned without much sorrow, and little to no attention to the murder victim. That night crowds at the house of Rossi's widow chanted ''Blessed is the hand that stabbed the Rossi''. Sterbini went on to play a prominent role in the [[Roman Republic (19th century)|Roman Republic]] in 1849, but fled into exile after its fall, until 1861.[https://books.google.com/books?id=Z0UmLbpjJYYC&pg=PA80&lpg=PA80&dq=who+murdered+Pellegrino+Rossi&source=bl&ots=EJp2dp9t52&sig=c8kpAii6gtgfBXqsFeyel0ZaN5Y&hl=en&sa=X&ei=7r_fUJXWMYL8qAHS_4GwDg&ved=0CF0Q6AEwBw#v=onepage&q=who%20murdered%20Pellegrino%20Rossi&f=false ''Garibaldi's Defence of the Roman Republic''], (1907) by [[George Macaulay Trevelyan]], 3rd edition, Longmans, Green, and Company, 39 Paternoster Row, London. In a trial held in 1854, a man by the name of Gabriele Constantini was convicted and executed. The city of Carrara erected a statue in honour of Pellegrino Rossi. ==Selected works== *''Cours d'économie politique'' (1838–54) *''Traité de droit pénal'' (1829) *''Cours de droit constitutionnel'' (1866–67) *''Melanges d'économie politique, d'histoire et de philosophie'' (1857, 2 volumes) ==References== *{{EB1911|wstitle=Rossi, Pellegrino Luigi Edoardo, Count|volume=23|page=751}} *Claudio Rendina, ''Enciclopedia di Roma'', Newton Compton, Rome, 1994 *{{cite web|url=http://www.newadvent.org/cathen/13204a.htm|title=Pellegrino Rossi|work=[[Catholic Encyclopedia]]}} {{Authority control}} {{DEFAULTSORT:Rossi, Pellegrino}} [[Category:1787 births]] [[Category:1848 deaths]] [[Category:People from Carrara]] [[Category:University of Pavia alumni]] [[Category:University of Bologna alumni]] [[Category:Italian economists]] [[Category:Italian politicians]] [[Category:Italian emigrants to France]] [[Category:Naturalized citizens of France]] [[Category:Collège de France faculty]] [[Category:Members of the Chamber of Peers of the July Monarchy]] [[Category:People of the Revolutions of 1848]] [[Category:History of the Papal States]] [[Category:Italian people of the Italian unification]] [[Category:Assassinated Italian politicians]] [[Category:Members of the Académie des sciences morales et politiques]] [[Category:Burials at San Lorenzo in Damaso]]

{{Infobox person |name = Reeta Chakrabarti |image = |caption = |birth_name = Reeta Chakrabarti |birth_date = {{Birth date and age|1964|12|12|df=yes}} |birth_place = [[Ealing]], [[London]], [[England]] |nationality = British |occupation = [[Journalist]], [[News presenter|Newsreader]] and [[Correspondent]] |years_active = 1992–present |credits = ''[[BBC Breakfast]]''
''[[BBC News at One]]''
''[[BBC News at Six]]''
''[[BBC News at Ten]]''
''[[BBC Weekend News]]''
''[[BBC Radio 4]]''
''[[BBC Radio 5 Live]]'' | URL = }} '''Reeta Chakrabarti''' (born 12 December 1964) is a British news journalist, presenter and correspondent for [[BBC News]]. ==Early life== Chakrabarti was born in [[Ealing]], [[London]] to an [[India]]n [[Bengali people|Bengali]] [[brahmin]] family and was raised in [[Birmingham]], also having spent time in [[India]] as a teenager as a student at the [[Calcutta International School]] in [[Kolkata]].[http://www.uel.ac.uk/news/latest_news/stories/letters.htm#reeta University of East London] {{webarchive |url=https://web.archive.org/web/20081007075054/http://www.uel.ac.uk/news/latest_news/stories/letters.htm#reeta |date=October 7, 2008 }} She has a degree in [[English language|English]] and [[French language|French]] from [[Exeter College, Oxford|Exeter College]], [[Oxford]], where she graduated in 1988, and she also spent a year in [[France]] while a student.{{cite web|last1=Chakrabarti|first1=Reeta|title=Reeta Chakrabarti on language and culture|url=http://www.open.edu/openlearn/languages/more-languages/linguistics/reeta-chakrabarti-on-language-and-culture|website=OpenLearn|publisher=The Open University|accessdate=9 June 2016}} ==Journalism career== In 1994, Chakrabarti became a reporter for the Breakfast Programme on the newly launched [[BBC Radio 5 Live]].{{cite web|url=http://news.bbc.co.uk/1/hi/programmes/breakfast/reporters/4237722.stm|title=Reeta Chakrabarti|date=12 September 2005|publisher=|via=news.bbc.co.uk}} She later became a general news correspondent working on television as well as radio. In 1997, she became the BBC Community Affairs correspondent, covering the [[Stephen Lawrence Inquiry]] and also working on Home Affairs. In 1999 Chakrabarti secured her role as political correspondent for the BBC, working across a range of programmes in television and radio, reporting on politics for BBC One, BBC Two, the BBC News Channel, BBC Radio 4 and BBC Radio 5 Live. In January 2011 she was the education correspondent for [[BBC News]]. In May 2014 she was appointed as presenter and reporter on BBC One. ==Other work== Reeta has also chaired and hosted a number of corporate events, including the 2003 and 2004 Educational Television Awards Dinners for the [[Royal Television Society]].{{cite web|url=http://www.rts.org.uk/Information_page_+_3_pic_det.asp?id=426&sec_id=383|title=rts.org.uk|publisher=}} She also hosted the 2018 TV Journalism awards for the RTS. ==Personal life== Chakrabarti is married and lives in [[North London]]. She has three children. She is a fan of the poet [[John Keats]] and chose this as her specialist subject on the BBC television quiz ''[[Celebrity Mastermind]]'' broadcast on 22 December 2016.{{cite web|url=http://www.bbc.co.uk/programmes/b0876m3f|title=''Celebrity Mastermind'' 2016/2017, episode 4}} Reeta is a Patron of Pan Intercultural Arts, a UK charity that uses the arts to empower marginalised young people and unlock their potential.{{cite web|title=Trustees and Patrons|url=http://www.pan-arts.net/pages/trustees-and-patrons.html|website=Pan Intercultural Arts|publisher=Pan Intercultural Arts|deadurl=yes|archiveurl=https://web.archive.org/web/20150712043312/http://www.pan-arts.net/pages/trustees-and-patrons.html|archivedate=2015-07-12|df=}} ==References== {{reflist|30em}} ==External links== *{{IMDb name|id=2151189|name=Reeta Chakrabarti}} *[http://news.bbc.co.uk/1/hi/programmes/breakfast/reporters/4237722.stm BBC Profile] *[https://twitter.com/rchak100 Reeta Chakrabarti] on [[Twitter]] *[http://www.rts.org.uk/Information_page_+_3_pic_det.asp?id=426&sec_id=383 The Royal Television Society] *[http://www.uel.ac.uk/news/latest_news/stories/letters.htm#reeta Profile at University of East London website] *[http://www.naz.org.uk/ The Naz Project] *[https://web.archive.org/web/20060924235818/http://www.uel.ac.uk/nmc/ The National Mentoring Consortium] {{DEFAULTSORT:Chakrabarti, Reeta}} [[Category:1964 births]] [[Category:Living people]] [[Category:English people of Indian descent]] [[Category:English people of Bengali descent]] [[Category:Bengali people]] [[Category:English political commentators]] [[Category:People from Ealing]] [[Category:BBC newsreaders and journalists]] [[Category:People educated at King Edward VI High School for Girls, Birmingham]] [[Category:Alumni of Exeter College, Oxford]]
